Is Microsoft trying to commit suicide?
By Charlie Stross

The breaking tech news this year has been the pervasive spread of "AI" (or rather, statistical modeling based on hidden layer neural networks) into everything. It's the latest hype bubble now that Cryptocurrencies are no longer the freshest sucker-bait in town, and the media (who these days are mostly stenographers recycling press releases) are screaming at every business in tech to add AI to their product.

Well, Apple and Intel and Microsoft were already in there, but evidently they weren't in there enough, so now we're into the silly season with Microsoft's announcement of CoPilot plus Recall, the product nobody wanted.

CoPilot+ is Microsoft's LLM-based add-on for Windows, sort of like 2000's Clippy the Talking Paperclip only with added hallucinations. Clippy was rule-based: a huge bundle of IF ... THEN statements hooked together like a 1980s Expert System to help users accomplish what Microsoft believed to be common tasks, but which turned out to be irritatingly unlike anything actual humans wanted to accomplish. Because CoPilot+ is purportedly trained on what users actually do, it looked plausible to someone in marketing at Microsoft that it could deliver on "help the users get stuff done". Unfortunately, human beings assume that LLMs are sentient and understand the questions they're asked, rather than being unthinking statistical models that cough up the highest probability answer-shaped object generated in response to any prompt, regardless of whether it's a truthful answer or not.

Anyway, CoPilot+ is also a play by Microsoft to sell Windows on ARM. Microsoft don't want to be entirely dependent on Intel, especially as Intel's share of the global microprocessor market is rapidly shrinking, so they've been trying to boost Windows on ARM to orbital velocity for a decade now. The new CoPilot+ branded PCs going on sale later this month are marketed as being suitable for AI (spot the sucker-bait there?) and have powerful new ARM processors from Qualcomm, which are pitched as "Macbook Air killers", largely because they're playing catch-up with Apple's M-series ARM-based processors in terms of processing power per watt and having an on-device coprocessor optimized for training neural networks.

Having built the hardware and the operating system Microsoft faces the inevitable question, why would a customer want this stuff? And being Microsoft, they took the first answer that bubbled up from their in-company echo chamber and pitched it at the market as a forced update to Windows 11. And the internet promptly exploded.

First, a word about Apple. Apple have been quietly adding AI features to macOS and iOS for the past several years. In fact, they got serious about AI in 2015, and every Apple Silicon processor they've released since 2016 has had a neural engine (an AI coprocessor) on board. Now that the older phones and laptops are hitting end of life, the most recent operating system releases are rolling out AI-based features. For example, there's on-device OCR for text embedded in any image. There's a language translation service for the OCR output, too. I can point my phone at a brochure or menu in a language I can't read, activate the camera, and immediately read a surprisingly good translation: this is an actually useful feature of AI. (The ability to tag all the photos in my Photos library with the names of people present in them, and to search for people, is likewise moderately useful: the jury is still out on the pet recognition, though.) So the Apple roll-out of AI has so far been uneventful and unobjectionable, with a focus on identifying things people want to do and making them easier.

Microsoft Recall is not that.

"Hey, wouldn't it be great if we could use AI in Windows to help our users see everything they've ever done on their computer?" Is a great pitch, and Recall kinda-sorta achieves this. But the implementation is soemthing rather different. Recall takes snapshots of all the windows on a Windows computer's screen (except the DRM'd media, because the MPAA must have their kilo of flesh) and saves them locally. The local part is good: the term for software that takes regular screenshots and saves them in the cloud is "part of a remote access trojan". It then OCRs any text in the images, and I believe also transcribes any speech, and saves the resulting output in an unencrypted SQLite database stored in:

C:\Users\$USER\AppData\Local\CoreAIPlatform.00\UKP{GUID}

And there are tools already out there to slurp through the database and see what's in it, such as TotalRecall.

Surprise! It turns out that the unencrypted database and the stored images may contain your user credentials and passwords. And other stuff. Got a porn habit? Congratulations, anyone with access to your user account can see what you've been seeing. Use a password manager like 1Password? Sorry, your 1Password passwords are probably visible via Recall, now.

Now, "unencrypted" is relative; the database is stored on a filesystem which should be encrypted using Microsoft's BitLocker. But anyone with credentials for your Microsoft account can decrypt it and poke around. Indeed, anyone with access to your PC, unlocked, has your entire world at their fingertips.

But this is an utter privacy shit-show. Victims of domestic abuse are at risk of their abuser trawling their PC for any signs that they're looking for help. Anyone who's fallen for a scam that gave criminals access to their PC is also completely at risk.

Worse: even if you don't use Recall, if you send an email or instant message to someone else who does then it will be OCRd and indexed via Recall: and preserved for posterity.
Now imagine the shit-show when this goes corporate.

And it turns out that Microsoft is pushing this feature into the latest update of Windows 11 for all compatible hardware and making it impossible to remove or disable, because that tactic has worked so well for them in the past at driving the uptake of new technologies that Microsoft wanted its ~~customers~~ victims to start using. Like, oh, Microsoft Internet Explorer back in 2001, and remember how well that worked out for them.

Suddenly every PC becomes a target for Discovery during legal proceedings. Lawyers can subpoena your Recall database and search it, no longer being limited to email but being able to search for terms that came up in Teams or Slack or Signal messages, and potentially verbally via Zoom or Skype if speech-to-text is included in Recall data.

It's a shit-show for any organization that handles medical records or has a duty of legal confidentiality; indeed, for any business that has to comply with GDPR (how does Recall handle the Right to be Forgotten? In a word: badly), or HIPAA in the US. This misfeature contravenes privacy law throughout the EU (and in the UK), and in healthcare organizations everywhere which has a medical right to privacy. About the only people whose privacy it doesn't infringe are the Hollywood studios and Netflix, which tells you something about the state of things.

Recall is already attracting the attention of data protection regulators; I suspect in its current form it's going to be dead on arrival, and those CoPilot+ PCs due to launch on June 18th are going to get a hurried overhaul. It's also going to be interesting to see what Apple does, or more importantly doesn't announce at WWDC next week, which is being trailed as the year when Apple goes all-in on AI.

More to the point, though, Windows Recall blows a hole under the waterline of Microsoft's trustworthiness. Microsoft "got serious" about security earlier this decade, around the time Steve Balmer stepped down as CEO, and managed to recover somwhat from having a reputation for taking a slapdash approach to its users data. But they've been going backwards since 2020, with dick moves like disabling auto-save to local files in Microsoft Word (your autosave data only autosaves to OneDrive), slurping all incoming email for accounts accessed via Microsoft Outlook into Microsoft's own cloud for AI training purposes (ask the Department of Justice how they feel about Microsoft potentially having access to the correspondence for all their investigations in progress), and now this. Recall undermines trust, and once an institution loses trust it's really hard to regain it.

Some commentators are snarking that Microsoft really really wants to make 2025 the year of Linux on the Desktop, and it's kind of hard to refute them right now.

Update (June 14th): Recall pulled from CoPilot+ release:

We are adjusting the release model for Recall to leverage the expertise of the Windows Insider community to ensure the experience meets our high standards for quality and security. This decision is rooted in our commitment to providing a trusted, secure and robust experience for all customers and to seek additional feedback prior to making the feature available to all Copilot+ PC users. Additionally, as we shared in our May 3 blog, security is our top priority at Microsoft, in line with our Secure Future Initiative (SFI). This is reflected in additional security protections we are providing for Recall content, including "just in time" decryption protected by Windows Hello Enhanced Sign-in Security (ESS), so Recall snapshots will only be decrypted and accessible when the user authenticates.

(Source: Microsoft.)

So the reverse-ferret maneuver took just 10 days. Not bad for a $3Tn corporation!

It can be disabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/windows/privacy-and-control-over-your-recall-experience-d404f672-7647-41e5-886c-a3c59680af15

You can turn on or off saving snapshots at any time by going to Settings > Privacy & security > Recall & snapshots. You can also pause snapshots temporarily by selecting the Recall icon in the system tray on your PC and selecting the pause option.

For enterprise customers, IT administrators can disable automatically saving snapshots using group policy or mobile device management policy. If a policy is used to disable saving snapshots, all saved snapshots from users' devices will be deleted, and device users can't enable saving snapshots. For more information, see Manage Recall."

 dwm | June 5, 2024 12:46
16:

Given the releases with Intel, AMD, NVidia, Qualcomm, etc. this seems like a coordinated effort between Microsoft and those hardware manufacturers to get everyone to chuck out their (perfectly functional) hardware and get everyone to buy more kit. Hence the CoPilot+-capable branding.

Microsoft probably like this because they have now ended free upgrades from Windows 10 to Windows 11, and so can exact an OS tax for everyone upgrading.

It's artificial carrot and stick, and the new carrot isn't needed. Recall has already been demonstrated to work perfectly happily on Azure VMs that don't even have NPUs, so it seems to my untutored eye to be mainly a power-efficiency thing rather than a hard requirement.

If Microsoft's goal was to get the features in front of people, then they'd just ship it for everyone.

So the motivation instead seems to be to ship more hardware and OS licenses. So far, so normal.

But this new carrot is rotten. And Microsoft, even having now realised the disastrous reception on security grounds, presumably can't easily back out because they've already signed agreements with various hardware manufacturers committing to this software rollout.

Time to see how good the regulators are.

 Ovid | June 5, 2024 13:17
21:

My prediction: even if users disable Recall, black hats around the world are going to see that silently re-enabling this is mission number one.

Next step: state-level actors are going to be spending their taxpayers hard-earned dollars on zero-day exploits so they can grab that Recall data.

Next step: targeting mid-level managers/bureaucrats around the world to get access to that now-enabled Recall feature and exfiltrating the SQLite database their information is stored in. These people have so many common "secrets" available and so much access to the day-to-day information of companies/governments that they're going to be a prime target.

For black hats Recall is going to be the goose that lays the golden eggs. For intelligence, it's both a gold mine (when they can acquire the databases) and a nightmare (when they have to defend against it).

If Recall can be silently enabled, exfiltrating the databases won't be too hard. This could seriously damage government and corporate security around the world.

Class action lawsuits against Microsoft to follow.

 Matthew Bloch | June 5, 2024 14:40
33:

This isn't incompetence, it's (outrageous) kite-flying.

I think the strategy is this: MS see the data that big online providers gather on people, and they just can't force enough people to use Bing or Office365 or whatever where they might benefit from that continuous usage data. Windows users' offline data is staying stubbornly offline, and it's full of really juicy stuff!

So this feature turns every PC you pay for into a giant distributed data-gathering operation that Microsoft can tap into, very gradually.

Users get a stupid search box on day 1, but over the years they'll also get "exclusive benefits" from allowing limited API access to insurance providers, employers, advertisers etc. etc. And MS desperately want this data access to be the new normal, turning every Windows install into an ongoing revenue source.

They are seeing what they can get away with, and are happy to risk the reputational damage, even if they scrap it, or launch it in smaller markets or whatever. They can afford to be patient and work on people's tolerance.

Personally I already run a "decrapified" Windows with all kinds of major features turned off, and I'd expect this to be top of the list in future.

But Recall absolutely deserves shouting down now otherwise it'll become the most egregious betrayal of the "personal" computer.

 David L replied to this comment from Damian | June 5, 2024 15:03
35:

autosave vs. Autorecover

Autosave was implemented to allow live editing between multiple people. Which is why it always goes to "the cloud". It would be nice if it could go to an SMB share but I can also see failures due to varying SMB implementations.

Autorecover saves your typing every few minutes to a local storage spot in case of a crash.

At least on a Mac. I have a Windows system to stand up today or tomorrow but can't check until then.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from JohnS | June 5, 2024 16:33
42:

Would younger users who grew up with computers have more IT literacy?

They often have less literacy. There's a current fuss in academics teaching CS about how current/new students fundamentally don't understand directory structures, or computers in general -- they've grown up with smartphones and they're used to finding items like photos in a pile of images by swiping, not by structuring data hierarchically. If you get lucky they understand tagging, but the way modern UIs hide what's going on under the hood makes for an illiterate population.

 Simon Bisson | June 5, 2024 16:59
45:

One point to the discovery issue: lawyers are already pulling Slack, Teams, and whatever data. They're not unaware of the tools used for business communication, they use them themselves. So they're grabbing browser histories, any system logs, all enterprise socials, and anything else they can think of.

So for that matter Recall is just an alternate search tool to the ones they're already using to concatenate and parse those terabytes of data they're already working with. It might make it a little easier to pinpoint things, but not that much.

eDiscovery tooling is a fascinating area, I wrote some whitepapers for a company that developed one package a decade or so ago, and they clearly had ex-black hat hackers working for them. The state of the art has only got better since then,,,

(As an aside I was at the launch of the Copilot+ PCs, and what's being described in the preview build that folk have activated is not what I was told the internals were. For one thing they were very clear as to the database being used and it wasn't SQLite. Instead it was a proper graph database.)

That could finally break the keyboard & screen stranglehold. But such interpretation depends on access to user context -- breaking the privacy silos.

 Guy Rixon | June 5, 2024 17:44
48:

Why are MS doing this? Beyond specific business plans that are crazy or naive or evil (or all three), they may just have a generational problem.

In any IT-heavy organisation, there is a population of recent-hires who get the code but don't get what the users want. They cannot get what the users want because they are not functionally human, and they're only hired because they may turn out to be brilliant coders. They'll use any shiny tech and allow any weird side effects on the off-chance that their stuff does something (that they consider) cool. Their output has to be filtered through a layer of functionally-human analysts and managers before it's safe to let out.

Over time, some of the crazy-Eddie coders grow up into moderating leads and managers. I've been there, on both sides. The all-growed-up-now coders get mixed in with the career managers and the business analysts.

Now suppose the org buys the myth that managers just slow projects down and analysts are all wasters. Over time they employ fewer card-carrying humans and the moderating body reduces to just the aging coders...who no longer moderate the products. It's the RBMK-negative-void-coefficient of software development.

 Moz replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 6, 2024 01:39
75:

that's what "overwrite with random" is for. First you write random data to the file, then you replace it with a new zero-byte version of the file. Then after your weekly removing of unwanted files and system backup you zero fill the free space.

This burns write cycles on your SSD but makes it harder to recover the files you deleted. AFAIK the only way to securely delete data off an SSD is physically. Hydraulic Press Channel recommends thermite grenades but I'm sure a hammer also works.

Even better are scroll bars and menus that change shape when the mouse passes over them, but the new "keep it active" area is not where the mouse cursor is so you end up moving the cursor one pixel at a time until you find the magic spit where you can touch it just the right way to expand it and keep it expanded.  Poul-Henning Kamp | June 6, 2024 07:59
90:

I want to protest the way "end-to-end-encryption" is being thrown around as some kind of magic spell these days.

E2EE merely means that some data is moved from A to B in encrypted form and never decrypted along the way.

E2EE does not say /anything/ about the encryption keys.

It does not say who has copies of the keys.

It does not say if (part of) the keys are static

Absent information about the key-handling, all E2EE does, is hide your data from a random sysadm and his tcpdump(8)

 David L replied to this comment from Retiring | June 6, 2024 08:35
96:

https://gs.statcounter.com/os-market-share/desktop/worldwide

While this is an interesting set of stats, and I refer to such things at times, it is also a very imperfect way to measure things. These sites basically track, as best they can, visits to web sites or instances of tracking code in software run on various systems. So while they have a wide statistical sample, it also has a lot of missed chunks of the market.

In broad terms (and I just seriously want to know how co-pilot will work for all of these sitautions) there are "this computer is yours for work" at one end and an embedded system like the POS notes above. My wife worked for a major airline (I know I've said it before.) She as assigned a laptop for her use at while at HQ. But in the call centers or at the gate the computers were assigned to the seat and the user logged in. At the call center the computer was owned by the airline. At the airport gates they belonged to the authority running the airport. And behind the scenes it was a seemingly insane random mix. Plus things like the monster flight schedule displays tend to be run by the authority, and the display over the gate the same. But the display next to it giving more details about the specific flight may or may not be owned by the airline or the authority.

And you have a huge mix of these running Windows 7 (if someone actually uses a keyboard) or older at times in these various behind the screen displays. Some running Windows (you can spot them with a BSOD at times), some running Lunix, some a few embedded things and some running iOS or Android. And the huge collection of Windows options. Embedded, LT whatever, etc... Wheee. Isn't this all fun.

Now co-pilot makes it more fun.

And how many of these get picked up by one of these stat counting services?

 Graham replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 6, 2024 13:13
110:

You're assuming corporate wrangling is the worst that could happen. That's probably true in North America and Western Europe.

In a range of other countries though (Russia, China, Syria, Iran or Saudi Arabia spring instantly to mind). infosec is literally crucial to staying alive. Currently, known dissidents regularly have their places turned over, but "at least" (ha!) the state is limited on how many people they can pick on because it needs human resources. Once it becomes trivially possible to automate the process of scraping data from all your citizens' computers, you're in a whole different world. Suddenly AI can take a guess at who your suspects are, and the thought police can put their human resources into door-breaking and torturing instead. That's the purpose of AI assistants, after all - automating pattern-recognition.

And even in the West, you're not guaranteed safe. Remember that abortion is a crime in many states in the US, and women have already been tried and convicted in the US because it was believed they'd had an abortion and had not naturally miscarried. (And the crime is premeditated murder, which in some of those states still leaves the death penalty as an option.) Even if the state government isn't doing the digging, the US has many well-funded and highly-organised religious organisations which do actively persecute people getting abortions, and they already do this by illegally violating people's privacy. Would they extend this by illegally hacking people's PCs? It's hard to think that they wouldn't, because they're all on record as believing that "God's laws" supersede human laws.

 David L replied to this comment from SFReader | June 6, 2024 16:07
116:

On behalf of the non-techies here [raises hand], whenever possible, please provide a mundane/plain language explanation/example.

MDM -> Mobile Device Management

Which is a bit of a misnomer these days. I THINK Apple coined the phrase back when large corps came to them and said, "we want to buy 10,000 iphones for our staff every 2 years but need a way to manage them".

So Apple started down the process. Now most everyone has such support. Microsoft has built it into Windows.

When you buy a Mac, iPhone, or iPad (and a few other things) from Apple or VARs you can have them enrolled into your ABM/ASM MDM account and you then control them. If you want. You CAN put all kinds of pre-loaded settings and restrictions. And brick them if not returned or stolen. And more.

And you can also add things into your setup later but it will not be a locked to your setup.

Microsoft has similar now.

Some MDM systems are fantastic. Some suck. Buyer beware.

David L @ 137:

I have a lot of friends and folks who have worked for IBM in all kinds of capacities and divisions. Even me in a weird way back 30 years ago. Most all of us tend feel they have never figured out what to do since mainframes stopped being the end all and be all of computing.

The first work I ever did out at IBM was as a contractor on weekends (early 1994) pulling cables under a raised floor in that DATA warehouse - pulling cables OUT when one of the computers was sold & pulling cables IN when a new computer came into the warehouse & was being set up.

 Moz replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 6, 2024 23:58
165:

intel that Walmart loves and every other megacorp craves

One of the shockingly obvious things that comes out of the data is which products are out of stock. I've worked for two companies who sold that information.

The naive idea that someone who works in the shop wanders round and looks at what products are low stock then checks the store room and orders stuff is wildly out of date. These days the computer updates stock on hand as each item is scanned so they always know exactly how many are left on the shelf. Because people never pick stuff off shelves then leave it elsewhere in the shop or take it without paying for it.

So in practice the key metric is "how many did we sell today divided by how many we normally sell" and when that plummets it's time to restock. Often the restocking person reports back how many items were on the shelf, but that's not essential.

This single number is worth 5-10% of sales on most products, 1% on others and over 100% on some. In the extreme it can lead to urgent deliveries of single items, for example when soft drink sells out due to an unexpected public event nearby.

As one of those younger users who grew up with computers I can say that I am frankly shocked about the lack of IT literacy Most of my friends know how to use a computer to an extent (Although they are typically far more comfortable with their phones), but they have absolutely no idea how it works under the hood Of course computers are not the only thing that people of my generation use but generally don't understand Most people of my generation wouldn't know how to change a car's oil or fix flat tire let alone something more recondite like figuring out that a belt has gotten loose and is missing with the engine's timing or something myself very much included the only reason I know that those kinds of issues can even happen is because my flatmate is in his mid-60s and actually understands how cars works and wanted my help to try and diagnose a fault with a car's infotainment system (Something I actually somewhat understand) and proceeded to talk my ear off about the other issues he had fixed.

Interestingly, both cars and computers have something in common which might explain the decrease in literacy. Initially when they first became available they required you have a great deal of skill and understanding of them to operate them (or employ someone who did) as time has gone on the user experience has gotten better and better with a lot of complexity under the hood (so to speak) increasingly abstracting away the actual underlying mechanisms To the point where operation is sufficiently simple that a user does not need to understand them and The underlying mechanisms are now so complex that your average user gives up long before they achieve any level of understanding because there's no real motivation for them to do so because it is unnecessary for operation.

There is probably some theoretical optimal point which is likely in the past, where there is enough abstraction that it's easy enough to pick up enough for something to be useful enough that you're motivated to learn more but not so complex or so easy that you can't be bothered to learn more If I'm making sense

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from JohnS | June 7, 2024 05:01

Primarily (IIRC) blend modes on adjustment layers. It's been a while since I last tried it. And at the time NIC Filters didn't work with GIMP.

Affinity Photo has those, and lots else as well. It has more features than Photoshop CS5 (which is the last version of Photoshop I own). It's a lot faster than Photoshop CS5, despite being more capable — edits that took seconds now seem instantaneous.

You can also install some Photoshop plugins. The Nik suite (ColorEfex, SilverEfex, et al) work nicely. I couldn't get Flexify to work (someone who actually understands the guts of the OS like David might be able to).

Some of the tools have different names, which took me some getting used to. Serif tech support was really good about answering "how do I do xxx" questions.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from Rocketpjs | June 7, 2024 13:18
188:

No need, I have my own devices for personal use anyway.

There is a growing trend for organizations to allow the use of personal devices; indeed, to sometimes require them because no company device is provided.

A few years before the pandemic my school board dealt with the lack of teacher computers (which were increasingly required to as more administration shifted online) not by providing more computers but by encouraging teachers to install software on their phones so they could access email and other board resources. Which software could remotely erase the entire phone (not just the work-related functionality).

I ruffled feathers by advising against it, pointing out that several teacher had already had problems with mistaken identities such as mail meant for them being sent to teachers at other schools with the similar names, money intended for them being reimbursed to other people, and could the board really be trusted to not erase the wrong phone by mistake? (There were by then several cases of other employers doing just that, with no legal recourse for the workers because by installing the software you had to click-through a license giving the employer that right.)

 David L replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 7, 2024 13:57
190:

not by providing more computers but by encouraging teachers to install software on their phones so they could access email and other board resources. Which software could remotely erase the entire phone (not just the work-related functionality).

The hallmark of an MDM that shouldn't be used. Or a decent one that was poorly used. There is some pull back these days with companies less interested in allowing customer devices to access data at the level same as organization devices. Security is harder to control on BYOD things.

 DeMarquis replied to this comment from alantyson | June 7, 2024 17:49
205:

"Ubuntu sounds pretty great as a distribution, but just for fun, do folks have any other recommendations for a couple of Windows 10-11 converts with basic computer literacy and the ability to read an install doc?"

So, with Linux, there is a separation between the underlying operating system, and the user interface that you see on the screen. In that, almost any operating system can use almost any user interface. Ubuntu is an operating system, and the user interface that most closely resembles a Windows experience is called "Mate". When you download Ubuntu, it gives you various options regarding which UI you want, including that one.

As I write this, I am running Mate on Ubuntu Linux. It works great : )

 SFReader replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 7, 2024 23:50
236:

Re: Learned helplessness

Don't know any clinical stats on this but often this is a condition that is forced on people not something they opt for. Teasing/making fun of people who don't have the same level of skill and often elbowing them aside instead of encouraging/offering to teach them taking into account their abilities/disabilities. IOW, it's the result of intellectual/knowledge/skill bullying.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learned_helplessness

This is different from: 'I'm making enough money to hire a pro, so I will ... instead of spending cognitive time/energy on this task as opposed to something I'd rather be doing.' Also different from: 'I've tried to do this myself a few times and I absolutely suck at it.' Hey, each person is unique.

OOC - my impression is that the field of computer science/programming has grown a lot - very many areas (old & new) have been discussed on this blog. So, is your typical uni compsci grad actually able to do any compsci task on day 1 at any compsci org or has the real world of compsci at the point where new recruits require specialized training before they're allowed to touch anything?

Related to both of the above: how bad is bullying (specifically insulting a person's intelligence/know-how) at compsci orgs?

Learned Helplessness is still alive & kicking I'm afraid ... Sigh. DIY is a pain in the ass afterwards.

My mom and her brother were both serious DIY types. Then they went into nursing homes and the fun started for the rest of us. Fun being spending thousands to tens of thousands getting their houses up to code so that it can be sold. It’s that last decade of independence, when physical ability and income wain in tandem, that produce the really problematic “fixes.” It’s really educational to listen to a master electrician or plumber wax eloquent to the apprentice helping him about why something is wrong, and sometimes really dangerous. Probably it’s even better to hear it hand in private embarrassment, rather than be the family member deciding who they need to share the anecdotes with.

Then there’s all the zombie tools that sat for decades in case they’d be needed again. Are they even useful enough now to donate? And the endless runs to the toxics disposal center with the scary chemicals that were legal 50 years ago and have been sitting ever since they were used once, the lead acid batteries so old they haven’t just foamed out, the anode fell off, ewaste galore, et merde.

So to the DIY crowd out there, I’ll offer the path of my other uncle: budget ahead, downsize regularly, hire help when you can’t do it anymore yourself, and enjoy what you still can do. That’s the Way I’m studying now.

 Damian replied to this comment from SFReader | June 8, 2024 05:47
250:

Don't know any clinical stats on this but often this is a condition that is forced on people not something they opt for.

Yes, this.

Learned helplessness is a term that refers to a specific trauma response. People develop it primarily in a context where they expect to be punished for achieving stuff. It has nothing to do with DIY or anything about real concrete skills, or for that matter preparedness to take a high-risk scofflaw approach to building maintenance or speeding. And frankly IMHO it's a perfectly reasonable response to some of the crap people live through. Anyone might adopt an otherwise uncharacteristic passivity in response to certain stimuli, we should all feel relatively privileged when it doesn't happen to us.

It is a thing to have them in the attic in the UK and under or inside the house in the US. Or maybe in the basement.

 David L replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 8, 2024 09:39
255:

changing a tire vs. ad hoc wiring... not in the same category... as always in blog threads, there's been a bit of drift... my old fart's complaint being there's a decidedly shallow grasp of basics

Sorry folks. But life moves on. My grandfather's generation who didn't live in the city could shoe, saddle, hitch, and in general deal with a horse. My father born in 1925 on a working farm (not a ranch) not so much. But he could do plumbing, wiring, slaughter cattle and hogs, etc... I can do most of the mechanicals he could do but not the slaughter bits. Can can change a tire, fix a flat, tube or not (without the machine if I must but I also know how to use the tire changing machine), rebuild a carb, etc... My kids not as much.

As the world's tech moves forward, the skills you need for daily life change. Tires last 30K to 60K miles and minor punctures don't cause a flat. And you can drive on them a while as they slowly lead down. Roadside gas stations had inventories of common tire sizes as people driving more than an hour from home often needed a replacement tire. Now, nope. There is NO timing to set on modern auto engines. And more and more lawn mowers are electric or if not just work for 2 to 5 years OR MORE before needing ANY engine work.

All of these things many of us grew up and older with as life skills were the result of what was needed to get through daily life. Those things for most of the younger folks just last a much longer time.

Now nothing I said above means I don't think many people just toss aside things that should be repaired. But this was true 50 and 100 years ago. But man, the 1930s did a number on the repair mindset of a large percentage of the US population. But WWII production and use in the military in some ways stood that on it's head.

PS: The plumber came this morning and I have hot water again. Kind of made me feel like a complete prat because it turned out to be a tripped breaker and I had checked the breaker panel FIRST thing before crawling under the house to get to the hot water heater (had to get info off the labels to identify brand & model).

In my defense I will say this house has a breaker panel with Cutler-Hammer breakers and I've always worked with Square-D equipment.

When Square-D breakers trip the handle flips half-way to off and a little red flag appears in the breaker window. The breaker that I thought was for the water heater goes to something else & I still haven't identified what that is.

 Howard NYC replied to this comment from SFReader | June 9, 2024 01:37

VBA == Visual Basic for Applications

a built-in piece of all MS Office apps

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Basic_for_Applications

especially heavily exploited by financial sector rainmakers who would build eye-poppingly complex modeling into MS Excel way beyond anything Microsoft ever envisioned and utterly impossible in pre-cursors such as VisiCalc and Lotus 1-2-3...

fundamental feature of spreadsheets being a tangled formula in each cell... but to really do things at the bleeding edge, the calculations require calculus rather than simple math of adding and subtracting... nearly impossible logic branching in a formula can easily be achieved in VBA...

by way of VBA if you wanted to do the legwork, you could extract real time pricing per ton of copper, get latest housing starts in Phoenix AZ, compare 'n contrast the latest 'price fix' of gold and then attempt to guess which way the overall economy is moving...

...and yeah that example is from personal experience... about seven thousand lines of code... and three months of sleepless weekends in 2006

we did not believe our numbers in 2006 and 2007 when playing out best vs worst case scenarios if growth in housing suddenly stopped... because why would the dance ever end?

...till it did in 2008

(if we trusted our analysis, we'd all be near-billionaires now thanks to deep shorting and CDO/CDS/etc bets against AIG)

The closest non-techie analogy I can think of is: just because you've been invited over to dinner at a friend's does not give you the right to rummage through their closets/drawers, take some of their stuff or rearrange their belongings.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Guy Rixon | June 9, 2024 10:19
288:

»Extreme technology enthusiasts in software development aren't idiots or evil. We admit --- welcome -- them into the craft because sometimes they do brilliant work and sometimes they drive things forward.«

At BSDcon2002 somebody had the genius idea to invite John R. Mashey to do a retrospective on his "Software army on the march" talk from 1982.

I cannot seem to locate a video of his talk, but at least USENIX has preserved the original slides:

https://www.usenix.org/legacy/publications/library/proceedings/bsdcon02/mashey_army/index.html

The people you call "extreme technology enthusiasts" he calls "scouts".

His very clear message about them is on slide 30:

Identify dangerous and uncertain areas -> GET SCOUTS MOVING ASAP!!

Then on the next slide comes all the cautions:

For side-trips - NOT the army
Continuous process, not just start
Scouts tend to be flakes and tinkeres
Get lost in the woods; talk with the enemy
Drive over narrow bridges [on motorbike] and say OK [for tanks]

That bit of advice, and much else from his talk, has saved my customers a LOT of money in the past two decades.

Hypothetical - She's still living in NYC when they have another regional crisis (widespread power outage à la 1977 or 2003 or another Hurricane Sandy floods all the subways & underground infrastructure) and your niece has to be at the hospital STAT. Needed life skills.

Must of this discussion seems stuck in the past. And if civilization falls, then maybe much of what has been mentioned here will be needed again. But if it falls much then even these skills could be a waste.

How many of these things are still needed day to day or even in odd situations these days?

Saddle or hitch a horse
Pump gas out of a manual pump or one you crank back to zero
Patch a tubed tire
Light the pilot light on a furnace or water heater
Use a pay phone
Send a telegram (see first of movie "North by Northwest"
Use a single or double edge razor
Send a text message via T9
Operate a dial telephone
Flash hook a phone
Make your own soap
Slaughter a animal for food
Prepare meat for long storage without a fridge
Tune up a car engine


Things change. The skills I needed day to day in the 1960s and 1970s seem quaint.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Moz | June 10, 2024 02:31
315:

You herd an echidna into a metal trash can with a gentle shovel and quickly take them back to their Country? Something like that?

As for disassembling whales…. Back in grad school I knew people who did beach necropsies on dead whales for that part of the coast. Apparently one wears tyvek and rubber boots. Or waders, maybe, as falling chest deep into a rotting whale carcass is regarded as a rite of passage. Clothing quickly gets that unforgettable dead whale smell and is discarded afterwards. Whether you intend to or not.

Anyway, the small tools they used were large butcher knives. The big tools were straight out of Moby Dick, long handled flensing knives, front loaders and the like. No point in carrying a SAK in such a situation. You’d just lose it by dropping it into the carcass when your gloves got too slimy.

Usual SOP was to figure out what killed it and disassemble it for disposal.

Since this was a university, fairly frequently the skull was buried on the beach so the invertebrates could clean off the meat. Some years later the skull would be exhumed and become part of the zoology teaching collection. There was a row of old cetacean skulls lined up against a wall behind a teaching lab on campus They still had that delightful dead whale smell on foggy days, and I have rather nostalgic memories of walking past them. Ah youth!

Pleasant dreams, Howard.

 Moz replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 10, 2024 02:53

Surprisingly often they will walk onto my hand if I just stay still (allegedly this is very unusual). They often panic when I move and hold on tight which is a bit hard on the hand. I've seen enough whaling museums and photos to have an idea of the industrial scale of cutting up even a small great whale. Which is why it's such a great counter to "I can butcher anything using just my pocket knife. And your pocket 20T hydraulic excavator...

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 10, 2024 06:35
318:

Over 300. Heh heh…. I’m going to propose an annoying Howard: HPL pastiche, working title: The Highest Game

It’s a mashup of Tolkien and Lovecraft. Basically it’s a LOTR knockoff quest trilogy, mashed up with Pickman’s Model and the Dream Quest of Unknown Kadath. Replace elves with ghouls, orcs with humans, set it in the modern day and the high fantasy dreamlands, and make it a mission of MacGuffin Destruction, with a bunch of changelings a la Pickman’s Model in the hobbit roles.

And what is the One Ring in The Highest Game? It’s the artifact that gives money its value: the Quantizer. We’ve said here for years that money is in some ways a god whose value is created by belief in it. We’ll posit instead that a magisterial sorcerous act in the Dreamlands created the Quantizer, which causes people to see value as a quantity rather than a quality, a perception that makes money possible. Under the Quantizer’s influence, destructive, money-based civilizations have taken over the world in a way that Bronze Age civilizations, which were pre-money, never did. Now we humans are cooking the world with civilization and utterly immersed in systems that quantify reality and tell this is how it must be.

So if the Quantizer is destroyed, qualia replace quanta, the fire of civilization gutters out to be replaced by (heh heh) gentler systems of gift economics, and humans return to the raw state of human nature and dreamy Lovecraftian And with that return to a Romantic Arcadian Idyll, the tradition of the high game re-emerges into the daylight of the dream. And those who devote themselves to the high game become immortal….as ghouls. Better than scouring the Shire any day and elves sailing west any day. Heh heh.

Have fun with this if it smells right to you. It might make an interesting Call of Cthulhu scenario. Or even hopepunk. Cli-fi?

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 10, 2024 14:22
327:

Actually, I do know what to tell you: it’s an inversion. Since you’re struggling to process it, here’s what’s going on.

The good guys are the ghouls, who eat dead bodies.. the bad guys are modern civilized human beings, who routinely poison/embalm dead bodies or burn them. So far this is a bit like the old Mike Rowe series Dirty Jobs, where those who do the dirty jobs become immortal, perhaps because no one else wants to do them?

HPL was pretty clear in Pickman’s Model that the ghouls were his equivalent of the fairies who live underground in hollow hills, and who leave changelings. They also inhabit the Dreamlands, which are sort of a collective unconscious. So the obvious protagonists for this story are a bunch of changelings—goths and other misfits, people who are okay with being, say, garbage men or coroners, and alienated by how normies deal with the darker parts of existence. In our modern era of plastics and virtual reality, only a few places are safe for them, squats rather than the shire.

The standard dystopian fall of civilization that usually precedes any post apocalyptic story is made analogous to the final battle in Return of the King, where the Ring is unmade and orcish civilization falls apart. In this case, though, us normies are the orcs, and modern civilization falls apart as the magic underlying it (money) is unmade. The victors reinstate an older order, and the world is made safe for all the dirty jobs that every surviving human now has to do. This is the scouring of the shire part. And the protagonists wisely go West into the Dreamlands to become immortal, avoid martyrdom, and keep doing the dirty jobs that give meaning to their existence.

Does it make more sense now?

Contraception has been a bugaboo in US politics for decades. Really forever. Griswold sort of put it on the back shelf politically.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Griswold_v._Connecticut
But not everyone has accepted this as final.

While we're not historical Ireland, we have a lot of Roman Catholics here. Many from southern and eastern Europe. So there's that faction. For the last 10 years or so the quiver full (Duggars anyone) and such have been yelling louder. (Ain't the Internet Grand.)

Now add at least one more layer. Depending on when you think a person begins existence, and how you might think a birth control method works, correctly or not, you now get to have a debate on is it contraception or abortion. With some strong emotions on all sides. (I'm not trying to start that discussion, just explaining that it exists.)

So now you have some committed voters (the ones who show up in primary elections) wanting to elect anti contraception politicians. Maybe not as a single issue but those that lean hard that way along with other things. Which leads to some of the R primary winners being from the wing nut caucus. (See M. Romney, Ken Buck, and my fave, Mark Robinson for gov of North Carolina.)

Now after everyone has taken a deep breath, you suddenly see how some want to outlaw IVF. Which a LOT of Christian anti abortionists have been using. (Cue up Mark Pence.) Say what!?!?!? And on the anti-abortion front you have exit polls when it is on the ballot showing 60-40 splits to keep it legal in at least some form and the only way to get to those numbers in some deep hard R states is if R's vote that way. And it seems to be mostly R women. My state Senate leader, a hard core R, says he will not go there as the people are in no way for it. Even if Mark Robinson wins the governor's race. (I think this is free for a few views.)
https://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/election/article289099339.html


How does this all play out in the election? Well 1/3 will vote R no matter what. 1/3 will vote D no matter what. So who can catch the 1/3 in the middle. And it may only be 1/6 or smaller. But D's are running hard on these topics and it seems to be a winning message. Don't let R's take away these rights. But you have some (many?) R's who will just not vote for a D no mater how much they dislike the R candidate. So they might stay home or write in a name. Which gives 1/2 of a vote to each side on a practical level.

The end result? No one knows. The debates might be deciding. The Supremes will be releasing some big decisions in a few weeks. And maybe the middle east gets better or worse. All of these things are big enough to move the needle on the gauge.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 10, 2024 22:52
362:

»I therefore also do not know whether or not the actual procedure is also specific to the US phone system, of course.«

It was not, all automated electro-mechanical (or later) phone systems supported "flashing".

The dial and the contact which is activated when the receiver is on-hook are electrically in parallel, so if you lift the receiver off-hook, you can simulate a dial by hitting the plastic doo-dad the receiver pushes when on-hook.

To dial a one you it hit once, then pause for the next "digit", to dial a two you hit it twice as fast as you can, then wait etc. dialing a zero takes ten hits.

The nominal speed of a dial is 100msec per pulse, but the telephone switches were very tolerant because as dials got older and worn, they also got slower.

The "flashing" terminology comes from the old manual switch boards, where hitting the on-hook switch quickly would blink the lamp at the operators panel, without dropping the connection. The operator would then connect her "cord" to the conversation in progress, and answer whatever query the participants had for her ("Do you know if the doctor is home ?" etc.)

Detecting "flashing" were carried forward in most electro-mechanical and later electronic and computerrized switches, where it was used to implement "extra services" such as call-waiting.

 Moz replied to this comment from whitroth | June 10, 2024 22:54

I'm also horrified by the "put used razor blades into a wall cavity" idea. All the wee boxes of blades I've ever bought have an in surface and an out surface, the idea being that you slide out a new blade from the "top" then slide the old blade into a slit on the "bottom". Eventually you're looking at an old blade on the top and it's time to buy a new one. These days the blades are wrapped in thin paper because unwrapping a razor blade is obviously safe and fun. In the olden days they used to just have a slip saying "one blade left" then another saying "no more blades". Well, the advertising version of that.

 Leroy F. Berven | June 10, 2024 23:36
365:

whitroth @ 360: What it means is that there is no dial (or keypad). You pick up the phone, and work the on/off hook several times, and an operator will pick up and talk to you.

During the latter half of the 1970s (at about the time the US "Ma Bell" telephone monopoly was being disassembled by US Federal regulators), I learned how to manipulate the on/off hook on an analog phone unit that had no dial mechanism (reason: to prevent outbound calls) to make those outbound calls. With the handset off the hook, one could quickly depress and release the hook by hand. Each such cycle would generate a tone functionally equivalent to the tone made by the dialing mechanism normally present in this type of phone unit.

With careful timing, it was possible to space the tones to mimic the tone sequence for each individual numeric character, and thus in due course the full target telephone number, that you wanted to connect to. It worked quite well.

 JohnS replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 10, 2024 23:53
366:

Pigeon @ 359:

"I don't even know what "flash hook a phone" means"

I don't either. I strongly suspect the term is a piece of US-specific vocabulary. I therefore also do not know whether or not the actual procedure is also specific to the US phone system, of course.

It's something from really OLD phone systems.

Hook Flash

Back in the day when even local calls were operator mediated, jiggling the receiver "hook" several times would alert an operator to plug into the circuit.

Later it became possible to enter system commands from the keypad with touch-tone phones, but you had to "flash the hook" to get the system's attention.

What it means is that there is no dial (or keypad). You pick up the phone, and work the on/off hook several times, and an operator will pick up and talk to you.

Flashing the hook was also used to activate some services. For example, if I subscribed to three-way-calling I could call you and get you on the line, then flash the hook and call David, and when he answered flash again and we now had a three-way call. (Or something like that — I haven't done it since the 80s so might have the details wrong, but flashing the hook was definitely part of it.)

IIRC it could also be used to park a call or put someone on hold, again depending on how the phone was configured.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 11, 2024 09:41
388:

»good possibility, by 2050 for the EU to forgive UK and offer re-admittance... after suitable groveling from 2045 thru 2050«

Tl;dr: Dream on, Not happening.

It was UK who insisted on the treaty forcing anyone who left to enter through the front door, and they are not ever going to get an exception from that

UK also pushed very hard for the Copenhagen Criteria to be such that no country could be admitted if there were /any/ chance of it becoming an economic liability or political troublemaker.

Before attaining "candidate" status, UK will have to get over the "emotional hangups" which prevent them from even applying /and/ have a robust EU-like market and economy.

No country can be admitted to EU until all territorial disputes with EU members have been resolved peacefully, so before it can even apply, Gibraltar and Northern Ireland has to be "resolved peacefully."

Next the £ will have to be exchanged for €. That's going to upset a lot of people, in particular owners of some large stashes physical money.

Finally, neither the hereditary peers, nor the special status of the square mile is compatible with the EU's democratic criteria.

The self-rule of Scotland and Wales, if they have not eloped already, will probably not have to be resolved before applying, but will have to be resolved before being admitted as full EU member.

So it's going to take some serious motivation to become ready to apply, and the Copenhagen Criteria prevents that motivation from being "our economy has gone south".

To meet the economic and market criteria, the tax-evasion and money-laundering will have to be stopped, and the UK industry have to be robust enough to survive the competition. I wont even get into the land-ownership thing.

Going by the book, this amounts to: Have a revolution, throw the rich bastards into the sea, rebuild the economy and society from scratch, then apply.

But if UK is /really/ motivated, it can rejoin EU in a few hours any time it wants: Declares war on Denmark, fire a single shot to land indisputably within 12 miles of the Danish coast and surrender without conditions.

 Damian replied to this comment from Rocketpjs | June 11, 2024 10:43

When I was in high school I learned how to take apart the handheld part of a payphone and short circuit the connection with a coin to get a free call.

For at least a period when I was in high school in the 80s, as I understand it the way some payphones worked was by disconnecting the rotor pulse from the line until a coin was inserted.  David L replied to this comment from Damian | June 11, 2024 18:32
422:

but from the mid 80s to the early 90s payphones were phased in for which this did not work at all.

Back in the day, in the US, when you dropped in a quarter, dime, or nickle each coin type rang a bell with a different tone. And that was how an operator knew you have dropped in the correct amount when you wanted to place a non local call. This meant the operators needed to have the skill to decipher the 3 tones and add out the money amounts in their head or a note pad quickly in real time.

This gradually went away. Especially as some people started bringing their own bells. Of course it was hard to catch them as it was only when the money box was emptied and the area totals started coming up short that a serious problem could be noticed. I'm thinking in the pre-computer days no one audited individual phones as the paper work would be immense to tie together all the details for each phone.

 David L replied to this comment from Retiring | June 11, 2024 18:36
423:

No doubt this will work wonderfully and without hacks of any kind!

I get the impression that at one level they will be spinning up VMs on demand and toss them as soon as the request is processed and the results returned.

Local research lab data centers were headed this way a few years ago to be able to avoid malware infestations. I was at a talk by an admin who had it down to a week at most for most of their VMs and some down to a day of life. The goal was on demand spin up then toss.

Not that the bad guys will not try hard to get access to the data and results of such setups.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from David L | June 11, 2024 23:21
441:

»The problem with these debates is none of us on this blog have details knowledge and experience of the situation in both countries.«

As it happens my first kid was born in USA and the second in Denmark.

What surprised me most, is that it is small details you wouldn't even imagine, which throw you of.

The hospital in US had a nonnegotiable policy: The father cannot hold the child unless a nurse is also in the room. They implemented this by having the maternity ward on the top floor, and a nurses station right in front of the lifts, and any male person entering from the visitors lift got a nurse "bodyguard" who did not leave his side, until he entered the lift again.

I can think of may reasons why they have that policy, and I hate to say it, but in hindsight it was probably both a good and sound policy to have, but in the situation it upset me. (So much that they called the hospital's lawyer, around 2am, and got an exception, but /only/ because I was from Denmark.)

Similarly, my ex-wife, with her run-of-the-mill quasi-neurotic US relationship to healthcare, was very concerned that nobody in Denmark hangs their diplomas in their offices: How can you know they are qualified and not imposters ? (Our family doctor kindly brought his education and authorization certificates to work so she could see them. Not nearly as impressive as the US ones.)

But what /really/ threw her, was us entering the maternity ward, where a smiling and seemingly not-a-care-in-the-world midwife greeted her with a cheerful "You look like somebody who's going to have a baby one of these days...". (She must also have activated some kind of signal because in no time two nurses and two porters with a bed rushed to our side.)

Add to that, that even inside tiny Denmark, your experience and satisfaction depends on which precise nurse, doctor or hospital you encounter and when.

So, yeah, good for that dude in Wisconsin, but single cases are no way to compare healthcare systems.

And yes, before you ask: I've seen the invoice for my sons birth, and even after the heavy discount to the HMO at my wife's work, that was still an eye-watering amount of money.

 Moz replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 11, 2024 23:36

nobody in Denmark hangs their diplomas in their offices

It's a weird mix in Australia. My dentist has a whole wall of qualifications and awards in the waiting area... that belong to the semi-retired person who owns the practice, not anyone who actually works there*. My GP's office has a similar wall that's much smaller and mostly shows the names and photos of the various doctors but has their qualifications after their names for those who happen to know that M.A.C.G.P.A.G. means "member of the australiasian college of general practitions and gynecologists" or whatever the various sets of letters translate to.

Meanwhile I care that they're eligible for the various government payments and trust that the process for auditing that means that when I see a "doctor" or a "nurse" I'm actually seeing someone with relevant qualifications and experience.

(* he's a board member of some important-sounding medical union and has prizes for being best in show at some dentistry thing (in 2004) but there's no way to make an appointment to see him using the booking system in the practice)

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 12, 2024 00:31
450:

"At 6pm on a Tuesday night the town centre was desolate, all the shops and restaurants and cafes shuttered..."

Er, and this is a bad thing why exactly? It's basically what I still tend to think of my town (Worcester) as being like, because that's how it always was in the days when I was likely to be passing through the town centre at 6pm on a (any) weekday night. Half the shops closed at 5pm, by 5:30pm the other half would also have closed, then by 6pm everyone would have fucked off home and the place would be more or less deserted. To propose that this was somehow "bad" would, perhaps, have had a good 70% probability of simply making whoever you proposed it to toddle off to the nearest phone box and ring up Powick to report an escaped inmate. And it did have the significant advantage - less apparent then, but very noticeable now by comparison with current conditions - that the term "rush hour" was chronologically accurate.

(Powick: just on the other side of the river, half a mile from the site of the first battle of the Civil War, motto: "Still proudly force-feeding people equine doses of LSD into the 80s". It's "posh" flats now, though why the fuck anyone wants to live in them is beyond me; even if you don't know the history one look at the architecture makes it pretty bleeding obvious what kind of history it was.)

What shops were there to be closing? Usual Smiths, Boots, M&S etc, same as more or less every town - all still there, and all still close by 5:30pm - plus a wide variety of shops whose only instances were in Worcester and maybe also a couple of other places, selling things like stationery, china (MASSIVE place, MASSIVE range), tools and ironmongery, electronic parts, kitchen appliances, bicycle parts, car parts, industrial rubber items (drive belts, seals, etc), books, music (recorded), music (gear for making), TVs/radios/gramophones/tape recorders (and related consumables) from the utterly crud all the way to the excellent, plumbing stuff, camera gear and film, haberdashery, agricultural supplies (BIG one, that), the veg/fruit the farms produced (all fresh, of course) and meat (ditto, cut off dead animals while you watched), it goes on and on and on... Where relevant, they would have a truly astounding range of small and obscure items stashed somewhere in the crumbling recesses of their titchy little jerry-built Victorian brick boxes (FSVO "brick", and "mortar" come to that), which they would go and dig out for you if you asked, or if they didn't have something they would either be able to get it for you in a few days odd or tell you who could. All (apart from obvious "luxury" items, of course) broadly at "normal people" prices (for locally representative values of "normal people"); not dirt cheap, but no rip-offs either, and if some item did happen to be remarkably cheap as a consequence of being shite, they would tell you the fact and the reason without trying to hide matters so you could make a sensible decision whether to still buy it or not. And of course all this was in the middle of town so it was within at least tolerably reasonable walking distance of a good proportion of the housing - or superbly convenient if you lived in a flat above a shop. (Indeed, we have a Green councillor/candidate, who was in my year at school, who considers restoring what is possible of these conditions as an important aim, and is guaranteed my vote if he stands in my ward.) You might have had to deal with the need to nick off work in time to reach the shops before 5pm, but there wasn't all that much, outside real exotica, that you wouldn't be able to get hold of eventually once you'd solved that one.

Unfortunately, one thing we did lack was any kind of useful defence against the ATTACK OF THE BREADHEAD WANKERS (some on the council, some nowhere near the town and with no conception of it other than as a means of acquiring money). Few of these shops actually owned the buildings they were in, so it was fairly trivial to kill them off simply by jacking the rent up, and because it was often quite easy to pick bits off the "brickwork" with your fingers (you still can in the housing built at the same time in the same manner; my sister had one for a few years) it was similarly easy to end up with A SITE. They would then build on the SITE something that was (to give it its due) at least structurally/materially sound, and rent out its sub-units at some bleeding horrendous rate that was unrealistic for nearly any potential occupier - but with a big chunk knocked off for the first 2 years of occupancy, so as to make it easier to con potential occupiers into thinking that by the time the 2 years is up they'll be coining it in enough to be able to manage the full rate. The buildings that were structurally sound to begin with (older ones built by respectable contractors, or more recent structures dating from after the advent of proper building regs) didn't get the replacement treatment, but the rest of the story was much the same.

So rather naturally the newly-constructed units are now used for playing Musical Shops; some anonymous hopeful turns up, manages to keep going for the first 2 years, can't then manage when the full rate comes in, and disappears, to be replaced by another barely distinguishable instance of the same species.

And what do these musical occupiers sell...? Crud. Shite. Market stall type plastic tat made in China, of marginally better quality than the stuff you find on an actual market stall but still not really able to withstand any useful degree of handling (the only things that might last are things like yet another nauseating "arty" picture of unicorns and surf (nowadays generated by Chat GPT) which you hang on the wall and don't touch, as long as you hang it somewhere the sun never touches it either). All the things are basically the same; if you don't find the specific items of tat in one shop to your taste, you can easily enough find two or three other shops selling a functionally identical item, which may be in a different-looking box but probably came out of the same factory, or at least the one next door, and isn't noticeably of either better or worse quality once you take it out of the box.

And they still all shut by 5:30pm.

If you want to buy anything that is actually useful and actually displays some vague approximation to the concept of manufacturing quality, you can get a predictable and distinctly limited choice by driving your car out to one of the instances of Same-Old-Crap Big Warehousey Place located right on the outskirts of the town (or just in the middle of a bloody field on the outskirts of other fields), driving it even further to Birmingham which is big enough that you can still get lucky, or just going "fuck it" and using one of the well-known giant international tax evader websites.

With the buildings that were structurally sound to begin with, the model does sometimes manage to work, in those cases where the building has a frontage on the actual High Street and the occupier is yet another sporulation of Same Shite Down Your Neck In Every Town (and therefore rich to begin with) - those outfits like Big Slab Of Concentrated Cholesterol, or A Pedestrian Underpass Is The Same Thing As A French Loaf, Isn't It?, or Coffee-Coloured Renal Efflux With Fake Italian Veneer That Real Italians Mock Mercilessly. Where one or both of those conditions are not met, the place is more likely to spend long periods boarded up looking derelict.

They've also tried to create a third flavour of the model by random mixing of elements from the first two flavours, plus a double helping of additional bleeding stupidity - to wit, firstly the notion that having loads of people sat out in chairs on the pavement getting in everyone else's way is somehow a good idea rather than just a bloody nuisance, and secondly that because people who live in balmy Mediterranean climates are observed to be fond of doing this, people who live in a soggy grey cold English climate will also want to do it just as much. The first phase of this was four years of disruption right bang in the town centre while sycophantic local newspapers gushed endlessly about what a bloody amazing way to spend millions and millions of pounds it was; the second phase was two years of a constant sickly random mixture of powerful smells from multiple different kinds of bad cooking; and the terminal phase is a load of brand new expensive units spending long periods with boards over the front, watched over by Sir Edward Elgar looking constipated with a road cone on his head and thinking "Land of Bloody Hope and Glory... what the fuck was I on?"

For sure we now have a rush hour which begins before 3pm and continues most of the way to midnight, and the relaxation of the licensing laws means that the town centre is now heaving with people walking from one boozer to another for a similar period, but this is not "prosperity", it's just that people like to get pissed.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Retiring | June 12, 2024 02:06
456:

"...and the number forced to wait more than 12 hours for admission to the hospital, which was near zero before the pandemic, is above 40,000 this year."

Does it get mentioned that those >12 hours waiting for admission may well be spent lying on a trolley in a corridor, along with other patients lying on trolleys up both sides of the corridor and in every other bit of spare space (some of them wailing endlessly in uncomprehending agony) while being used as the tiles of shuffle-puzzles so that yet more patients can eventually be wheeled past, while medically qualified staff (rank unknown; you can't tell who's what any more these days; but nothing very high) incompetently perform unpleasant and pointless "procedures" which they unthinkingly assume that patients, since they're not staff, are too thick to realise aren't ever going to actually achieve anything, in order to conceal the fact that you haven't actually been admitted yet by making you think that since they are indeed doing things to you, then you must have been?

"the number of people waiting for hospital treatment from the National Health Service has tripled since 2009"

One thing the NHS are still good at is dealing with actual emergencies; if there is a genuine risk of death looming for whatever reason, they will pull all the stops out to shove you past the queues and delays and get started on the heavy shit pronto before it looms too much.

On the other hand if you have some condition which may be painful but nevertheless won't really do anything more than just hurt even if the necessary surgery is delayed, it's quite possible to spend several months waiting for a surgical appointment. The surgery in such a case has a reasonably good chance of being actually quite simple and needing little more than a surgeon and an anaesthetist as far as its requirements for highly skilled and qualified operators are concerned, but nevertheless the NHS is so strapped for such people that you can end up repeatedly seeing patients who are at risk of consequences more serious than "it just hurts" being jumped past you in the queue.

So if someone does have such a condition and is also at least technically capable of scraping up a loan for several grand at a pinch, even if they hate the idea, they have a pretty bloody strong motivation to do so in order to pay for private treatment, because it fucking hurts for fuck's sake.

A private hospital doesn't have the same kind of obligations as the public NHS; the NHS has to do their best to treat someone no matter how complicated it's going to be, but the private outfit can pick and choose who they will and won't treat according to the level of skill and facilities that that one hospital has available. Similarly the private outfit is allowed to say "sorry, we're full, bugger off", but the NHS, although allowed to prioritise, just has to find the space if the need exists. So by aiming only to carry out such simple surgeries and refusing any request to do anything that isn't really simple, it's quite viable for a private hospital to function on the quantity of resources they can accommodate in a facility of comparable physical size to a biggish private house.

Of course even the most trivial surgery can turn into a horror show if something goes wrong. Private hospitals don't have to plan for the worst case because that could be beyond the capability of any single hospital to handle, but for some reason they don't have to plan for a reasonably-expected level of badness either; planning for just a plain boggo middle-of-the-curve case is apparently allowed... as in, only one actual doctor on duty in the whole establishment.

So they get set up as pure irresponsible money-extraction machines targeted at people with painful but non-dangerous conditions. Take big pile of money off someone desperate to jump the queue; take them in, do the surgery; oops, fucked that up a bit; dump the mess on the NHS, since it's now an emergency and the NHS has to deal with it stat; rub hands in glee and have big wank over pile of money.

For fuck's sake.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 12, 2024 11:45
479:

My doctor has her's on the wall

Here in the UK it is a mandatory legal requirement for any working pharmacy to display the registration certificate of the supervising pharmacist (including a locum if it's a shop and the regular pharmacist is absent for some reason). Goes back decades or more, the Pharmaceutical Inspectorate (who make random unannounced inspections of community pharmacies) will prosecute offenders.

(They do not approve of random uncertified shop staff being left in charge of quantities of controlled drugs, to put it mildly.)

I believe there are similar display-your-qualifications-or-else requirements for many but not all other professions (a "profession" in the strict sense of an occupation that is regulated by a statutory body with legal enforcement powers). Usually the ones where an imposter can kill people.

 amckinstry replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 12, 2024 15:55
498:

And well I remember the autosave fiasco.

In Word 6 they synchronized Word on Windows and MacOS; until then they were different. I was doing my MSc thesis on a shared PC for grad students at the time. I religiously kept backups all along on Floppies as well as the hard drive on the PC. Then the inevitable happened; someone upgraded the PC losing my thesis. So I reverted to the floppies.

Empty. Each one of them. It turns out that when you had a copy on HD, Word would use it, create an empty but present file on the floppy, but do all saving/opening to the HD copy only.

So I had 30 blank copies of my thesis, nearly 90% done.

It turned out later that MS knew of the bug at release time (and about 30+ others) but wanted to simultaneously release so they ignored it.
