 Pigeon replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 12, 2024 17:52
501:

I know fine what kind of town it is :) One of the lasses who used to hang around outside the barracks during WW1 to meet the soldiers was my gran, and one of the soldiers was my grandad, so all my ancestors and relatives on that side come from round there (and it's still full of 'em) (for which reason I reckon I must surely have some Scottish ancestry via the border reivers, even if nobody admits it). As it happens, I don't actually like the place - not for any reason to do with family history, it's an entirely and exclusively personal-idiosyncratic feeling - so most of what I know about it has come through my interest in railways (and history in general); it must be 40 years since I've last been there in person (outside the station, that is), and I haven't spent anything like as much time nerding over its development over the last 2-3 centuries as I have with Worcester, but I don't think that matters too much for the purposes of this discussion.

In respect of contextually-relevant parameters like size, age, historicity, layout, and so on, of the town itself, it's really quite similar to Worcester - the thing that most strikes me as different is, maybe somewhat oddly, that the cheap-arsed Victorian architecture tends to be rather less crumbly. I think the most important difference (again, for this discussion) between the two is on a rather wider geographical scale.

Carlisle's importance is basically that of an oasis in the middle of a desert; it may be a bit light on the aridity and camels, but functionally that's what it more or less is. The town itself is in a spot where the concentration of hydrological erosion/deposition processes has produced an area of relative clemency. For a pretty huge distance all around the land is bleak, forbidding, empty, distinctly sparsely populated, agriculturally poor (best suited for use with ruminants as first-stage nutritional enhancement processors, not so hot for direct production), difficult to travel over and likely to expose travellers to life-threatening environmental stresses. You have to go a considerable distance before you reach the densely-populated central belt of Scotland in one direction, and about the same to reach similarly hospitable regions of England in the other. But since we're talking about one of the rather few reasonable routes between the capital regions of two adjacent nations with a history of intense political interaction, a perversely large number of people have long been motivated to travel that way.

So for centuries Carlisle has been an important staging point where travellers between Scotland and England can rest and recharge. When your transport is based around legs oscillated by muscles, unless you've been bloody lucky with the weather you more or less have to pause at that point to refill the stores and recuperate from the insults. This, of course, all changed rather quickly and dramatically when the railways arrived; but at that time the same basic geographical factors were interacting with other developments closely related to the railways to make Carlisle an important traffic concentration point. In particular, the adjacent north-west coastal area of Cumbria was a major source of iron ore, coal, and the metallic iron you can make from those two; a bit further the other way is the Newcastle area which was another such major source; and the physical-chemical exigencies of iron and steel manufacture called for a lot of blending of different ores to get the right chemistry for the process. And perpendicularly to that we have the Scottish and more-southerly English coal and iron regions also participating in the same game of swapsies. So in addition to all the other traffic between Scotland and England over that route, there's a crapload of stuff from labour-intensive heavy extractive industries moving around, all by means of similarly labour-intensive steam railway transport. (Servicing the transport aspects of this kind of stuff is still functionally "oasis activity", the same basic conditions giving rise to the same kind of requirements, only based around feeding bunkers and boilers and fireboxes instead of stomachs.)

And so it goes (eliding evolutionary drift) until the fucking Tories could no longer handle the people who actually made all this industry function having the temerity to want decent pay and conditions while they were doing it, so bang goes the whole bloody lot. Meanwhile developments in transport technology had been enabling vehicles to go for longer and longer distances between oases. And with larger and larger homogeneous loads, so it had ceased to be logistically advantageous to be able to bring mixed loads together mid-journey and reshuffle the mixes by destination. (Another need which had ceased to exist was the provision of more-or-less similar functions in the area to support intensive military activity, though it's kind of hard to cast "we no longer need to be able to go and kill people so much" as a complaint.)

So all of a sudden, really, the major point of Carlisle's existence for as long as anyone can remember had kind of vanished. All it really had now was the rather self-referential justification of needing to continue existing because it already did exist. To be sure there is some hyperbole in my saying this, but not really all that much. And it has to be said that the justification for the existence of Worcester has also come to include a certain degree of self-referentiality, although for reasons whose detail is very different, and to a much lesser extent since it's in a much more hospitable wider region and has never been in any remotely similar condition of existing "as an island unto itself", as it were.

But the thing is that throughout all this, the situation regarding shopping facilities in the town centre HAS FOLLOWED VERY MUCH THE SAME pattern MORE OR LESS EVERYWHERE. The story of the profusion and variety of comprehensively useful shops in the town being eviscerated by breadheads and replaced by endless indistinguishable duplicates all selling basically the same distinctly limited range of functionally identical cruddy plastic tat from China, so that many of them end up spending much of the time boarded up entirely, is one that pretty much every town can tell in its own local variation - and it's one that already groans towards its depressing heat-death endpoint before the internet, again in very much the same way everywhere. Similarly the growth of the fungoid fringe of big barns selling a slightly less limited range of slightly less cruddy items, and being fucking useless anyway unless you use a car, is very similar everywhere and was also irretrievably embedded before the internet.

And all the shops closing before 6pm has been basically universal since before anyone currently alive was born, and it still is; although the handful of capital-scale towns like Edinburgh contain enough exceptions to make them noticeable, there are so few towns of that size that they aren't representative of anything except each other. When "Randomston, once prosperous, now dying" was still in its "prosperous" period, you would ABSOLUTELY expect to find the town centre deserted at 6pm because everywhere was like that... and because of the licensing hours that were the not-quite-universal norm in those days, the pubs mostly wouldn't be open yet. (At least in England; I don't know what the licensing hours were like then in Scotland.) A town that is still heaving at 6pm isn't so much heaving with prosperity as heaving like a corpse full of maggots: people who haven't spent all day at work don't need to go home as soon as they are allowed to, and relax thankfully, and have their dinner, and go to bed in time to get up for work the next day; they don't need to be primarily winding down and recharging for tomorrow, instead they can wander around the town centre because it's less boring than sitting at home, and they're not so skint that they can't spare anything for a drink (since these days the pubs are open that early, and the benefit system isn't quite that savage). (And if the place nevertheless is deserted I reckon it's more likely due to factors like people who live in the town preferring to drink in their local boozer rather than a town centre one, with the town centre pubs being preferred by people who live around the town but no longer dare to drive and there's no public transport to get home; pubs being shit these days because you can't smoke any more and it's too cold to stand around outside all the time; and pubs going bust because the landlord can't stand being skinned raw by the breweries any more.)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 12, 2024 20:51
521:

It gives the pharmaceutical society inspectors an easy-to-look-up license number (there's a central register maintained at national level), and they can check the pharmacist's driving license or other ID to confirm it's the right person.

Faking it is an imprisonable offense and you run a high probability of being found out and prosecuted if you keep it up for any length of time.

The certificate itself? Design changes over time: I have one and it's nothing like the ones they issue this century -- even the licensing body's name has changed.

(NB: my license expired a third of a century ago when I stopped paying my dues. Doubt it can be reactivated non-trivially without extensive retraining requirements.)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 12, 2024 20:56
522:

wouldn't it be simpler for Scotland to declare independence and join on its own, then send in the clans and conquer England?

The clans you're thinking of mostly don't exist outside history books. The highland clans were brutally suppressed in the first half of the 18th century -- wearing a tartan was illegal until the early 19th century -- following a couple of unfortunate wars. And then the highland clearances ensued, most of them were kicked off the land and ended up overseas, and the result is grouse moors.

Today 80% of the population of Scotland are in the lowlands and the largest ethnic minority (at 10-12% of the population) is "white, other British".

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Retiring | June 12, 2024 21:03
523:

This is your regular scheduled reminder that if that happened the UK would, based on population, be the 51st through 60th states if it joined the USA, or at minimum four states (and England would be the most populous in the US by a very long way indeed -- even Scotland and Wales wouldn't be on the trailing edge). Also, the former British states would all return, by US standards, far left Senators and mainly left-wing Congresspersons, so much so that it'd skew the electoral system decisively against the Republicans for at least a generation.

So no, the realistic prospects of the UK merging with the USA are approximately zero because the US ruling elite would take one look at the UK and scream then run away, very fast.

This is kind of hard for me to write, because I don't want my anger to overwhelm saying what I need to say.

The quality of medical care in the U.S. is the best in the world. But the availability - the distribution - of that care for everyone is probably the worst.

The problem with emergency room over-crowding is a direct effect of the for profit private equity banksters taking over the entirety of the national economy, including the health insurance industry and public hospitals. Most hospitals in the U.S. used to be operated by local governments with taxpayers providing the funding. But sometime during the Reagan administration's privatization via leveraged buyout scheme. They were acquired AT TAXPAYER EXPENSE by Wall Street's hedge fund robber barons.

One downside was the health insurance went from "non-profit" to "for profit" and many people became uninsured because of sky rocketing costs. And once you're no longer covered by ONE insurance policy (laid off from your job and didn't have the money to continue your insurance under COBRA) any previous medical needs became a "pre-existing condition" for which you could no longer get insurance coverage for love nor money.1

You also lost your "family doctor" because you were no longer covered by the insurance company's HMO and the HMO doctors did not see outside patients; leaving only the Emergency Room at the local hospital for routine medical needs. But emergency rooms are NOT a profit center, so they have to be shut down.2

Hospital consolidation is a problem. Smaller hospitals outside of the major metro areas are being bought by private equity and closed down.

For profit private equity health care is anathema and an abomination!

The U.S. should have a National Health System based on what the U.K. had pre-Thatcherism ... but it seems more likely y'all are gonna get a Private Equity takeover à la "Reaganomics" instead.

 Richard H replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 13, 2024 11:22
550:

"B" went unassigned though there'd be a floppy/mini disk drive designated "A"

so... if an app did mapping of drive letters to various subdirectories after "Z" was assigned then "B" was up

Not quite. B was an alias of A, to enable copying between floppies on a machine with only one floppy drive. At the DOS prompt you'd type

copy a: b:

(or whatever) and it would prompt you "insert destination disk", "insert source disk" repeatedly. You would insert alternate floppies in the single drive slot, as it read chunks from one floppy and wrote to the other. (and yes, IIRC it started with the destination, not the source.)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 13, 2024 14:33
556:

Drive letters predate MS-DOS -- DOS ripped them off from CP/M, which probably got them from something prehistoric by DEC.

If you had one floppy drive, it was A:. If you had two, you had A:, and B:. By convention only if you had a hard drive it got C:, and a second hard drive got D:. Dunno what happened if you had more than two floppy drives; back in the 70s and early 80s even 5.25" floppy drives were expensive (typically £250-350, or in today's money, on the order of £1000 each) and hard disks were eye-watering. (My first 10Mb hard disk, bought in 1987, was reduced on clear-out sale from £550 to £350 -- although that included the controller interface to couple it to an Amstrad PCW; a bare-bones drive was a bit cheaper.)

The aliasing of B: to A: was indeed a thing since way back when, because otherwise a single floppy machine couldn't copy files between disks.

I am, of course, following the pattern of PHK's "24-hour war with Denmark" idea, ie. pick some obscure point which is technically true but practically trivial, and then exaggerate the crap out of it for the purpose of amusement. (Only I'm using a scenario where I get to choose which side I'm on: the half of my ancestry that isn't from round Carlisle is from Wales, so it's 50/50 which side I "should" be on, and Wales is more fun.)

I'm also deliberately using really obscure things, so it's not to be wondered at if a native of New York doesn't get them; but there's a chance that some people on here might, and if you explain all the details of a joke it isn't funny any more.

So, to help you out, here's one bit unpicked, and people who did get it can stop reading now...

Tryweryn is a tiny Welsh village which was flooded in the creation of a reservoir for the purpose of flow control in the river Dee, which is where Liverpool gets its water from, and the least damaging means available to Liverpool of increasing the amount of water it could take before it started to fuck things up was to do some flow control stuff at the headwaters end. Of course everyone who lived in Tryweryn was furious, but we're literally only talking about a few houses, and most of them are dead now anyway. However, there is a dam, so as long as that exists there will be people who will see it and know that it destroyed a small village for the benefit of a big city, and that kind of thing actually is a valid point to complain about.

Far more people know about the English villages in the Lake District which were flooded to create reservoirs which directly supply water for the English city of Manchester, and there are also Welsh villages which were flooded to create direct supply reservoirs for Welsh cities, but with Tryweryn there is a national boundary involved, so the point is a valid candidate for use in the form of amusement being perpetrated here.

There was also a Welsh village destroyed to create direct supply reservoirs for the English city of Birmingham, but the thing about that scheme which is still vaguely sort of famous is that the first dam they built was a trial construction to get some hard data on what kind of difficulties they were likely to encounter, and once they'd got that, it became totally useless for anything... except for one final experiment during WW2 to demonstrate the effectiveness of the hydrostatic containment principle which Upkeep relied on. The bouncing bomb, The Dam Busters, 617 Squadron, famous raid, famous movie, der derrr der derderderderrr, etc. So we'll carefully not mention that one.

"Cofiwch Dryweryn" means "Remember Tryweryn". A lot of the graffiti actually says "Cofiwch Tryweryn", but in technical pedantic terms, that is wrong. And there are also people who get pissed off about the misspelling. To include this aspect demonstrates the level of niggliness involved.

I think that's quite enough of that, but the other things I came up with are of similar nature, so you ought to get where I'm coming from now. You very likely could find one person who genuinely would start a war over it, because you can always find a fanatic for any cause you care to name, but you'd have to search a bloody long time to find another one.

But as I understand it, with your coloured states thing, it's very easy to find people in significant numbers who really are keen on having a war, and some who have actually done something like firing a weapon. (Am I right?) So that is a completely different kind of matter.

 Kardashev replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 13, 2024 19:24

Where's the discussion?

Perhaps more an observation than a discussion, but one notes that the seven candidates arise from examining 5e6 stars. Our galaxy contains, as usually estimated, 10e10 stars, 20,000 times as many. So about 100,000 candidates in the galaxy.

As has been pointed out, construction of a Dyson sphere is a matter for a (ahem) Kardashev 2+ civilization, which could easily produce sublight fly-by interstellar probes. If such probes found something interesting enough, means of inserting vehicles into circumstellar orbit could probably be found, though it might take some time. But the time scale is probably 1e10 years.

So, to echo Fermi, "Where are they?"

 Mr. Tim | June 13, 2024 21:50
589:

About the drive letter thing:

Even Windows 11 is limited to A-Z for drive letters, I doubt MS-DOS is any different.

However, there was a question about adding the hardware. Little know fact is that (at least) early floppies could use two addressing modes. I forget what they were called, but one (that is usually used) used the 4 address lines on the floppy bus as device selects, meaning only one address line can be asserted at a time. BUT, there was support for using the address lines as an address, so you could have up to 15 drives connected (in theory) to a single controller. I have never seen this used.

Of course, the only way to use such a controller is via a custom device driver, so only MS-DOS 2.0 or later.

OTOH, you could write a RAM disk device driver and have it pretend to be 32 devices and see how MS-DOS reacts if you are REALLY curious.

About Dyson Swarms: It seems like Dyson Swarms (or Spheres) are never depicted favorably in Sci-Fi (except maybe for Banks). They usually are found by our intrepid crew as abandoned (Across a Billion Years) or in bad shape (Ringworld). Perhaps it has just left a bad taste.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Scott Sanford | June 14, 2024 00:02
599:

Once upon a time when I was actually being paid for programming on DOS, I did know at least some of these answers, but there was so little point having that information that I didn't even have much interest in retaining it at the time.

About that utility: did you ever actually use it? Because I do vaguely remember doing one myself once, but while it did work and was trivial to write, using it caused FAR more trouble than it was worth so it was probably very sensible of Microsoft never to provide the facility.

I've rewritten the following multiple times over about 4 hours, as each successive draft reminded me of new bits and pieces I'd forgotten, but I still think it's probably full of errors and omissions, so don't actually use it...

There was an interrupt for it (DOSese for "system call", because it used the 8086 INT instruction to call them), so all you needed was a few bytes of assembler in a .COM file that called it with the appropriate values and exited.

The way it worked was related to the way drive letters themselves worked. What DOS itself was using internally was not drive letters, but some kind of sequence-start-offset tuple - "sequence ID "floppies", drive letters start at A:, first letter (or second letter)", "sequence ID "hard drives", drive letters start at C:, first letter (or second, or third, etc)"; I can't remember if it exactly was that, but it was something along those lines.

You didn't come across it actually being expressed as a tuple; in accordance with DOS's usual habits of picking the stupidest ways of doing things, there was a different INT with a different parameter format and a different set of restrictions on when you could and couldn't safely call it for each parameter, because that was how they'd kludged it together bit by bit to keep up with how the original PC developed. And programmers used to think of the "offset" parameter for the "hard drive" sequence as being "the drive letter, minus 2", even though it wasn't, because it was hard enough to come across situations where you would get bitten in the arse by not taking account of that distinction that you'd likely not even realise there was a distinction.

DOS would set up sequence "floppies" for you, and sequence "hard drives" if you had any, so it always looked exactly like a strict alphabetical sequence with two or three entries (or more, if you were lucky), and consequently everyone thought it actually was that.

You were free to alter the "drive letters start at..." parameter, though, if you wanted, or create extra sequences starting wherever, so it was easy enough to make it give you a customised drive letter. As you say, though, it was very pointless so nobody ever bothered.

There was some project I had where there was some point to it, though. One bit of the code (probably for reasons connected with the silly API mentioned above and/or other similarly silly ones) was one of those infuriating things where no matter how hard you try, the code always comes out as some kind of a horrible mess that goes on and on. I figured out that there actually was some way to write decent code in this instance if you could assign arbitrary drive letters; and since the API was actually there and arbitrary drive letters were merely unconventional rather than formally incorrect, I tried it out.

And it worked fine, and since it was not only a purely internal thing to the company but one that only one or two people in the company would ever work with, and they would have had to have read my (comprehensive) documentation first to be able to work with any part of it at all, I reckoned this was great, and all I needed to do now was sand the rough edges off etc.

The trouble was that so, so many other people (including I think even some at Microsoft), who had written code where drive letters were actually important, had ignored the distinction between "offset" and "drive letter, minus 2" mentioned above, or assumed that because what you saw always came out looking like a strict alphabetical sequence it either really was one or at least DOS said it had to look like one, or done some other wrong thing of a like kind, that as soon as you tried to use the facility in any situation beyond the trivial, shit would start falling apart all over the place. In obscure and data-destroying ways that would probably fuck everything up beyond recovery before you noticed there was anything wrong. It even nearly did this to me just when I thought I could nearly put down the sandpaper. So although it was not incorrect, it nevertheless wasn't even remotely safe even in the severely restricted situation it was being used in, and I just had to act as if there was a formal rule specifying a strict alphabetical sequence and put up with having to write horrible messy code.

Even just having additional sequences wasn't entirely safe. We got hold of this package of an Apple Talk interface for the PC and a PC driver for it, that could map Macs' hard drives into the PC over Apple Talk, which eliminated a long-standing arseache. It figured out what the last hard drive letter DOS had assigned was and then carried on the letters for the mapped drives from there in strict alphabetical sequence, and for day-to-day purposes it was nearly safe, but it was still sufficiently possible to make it go bang that I reckoned the only way to use it regularly was connect/reboot, map network drive, copy stuff from network drive to PC hard drive, disconnect/reboot, and carry on from there.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Kardashev | June 14, 2024 00:03
600:

Fermi and Dyson swarms….where are the aliens?

Scale time. Interstellar stuff in our area, like ‘Oumuamua, tumbles along at around 15 km/sec relative to the Sun. New Horizons, the fastest thing we’ve ever launched, is currently cranking along at 13.68 km/sec, or around 526,000 years per light year. The nearest putative Dyson swarm IIRC is around 900 light years away would theoretically take New Horizons something like 472,500,000 years to reach the nearest one we’ve found.

Just to add in some weirdness, the most durable dense information storage medium we know of—DNA— only appears to last 150 million years, if that bacteria they revived from a salt crystal is legit. Otherwise it seems to last 1-2 million years frozen. So could we send a complex starship hundreds of millions of years to somewhere and expect it to read its instructions? Probably not.

So building a Dyson swarm 1 AU out from a star may be doable, in the sense that we’ve sent probes that far. Sending an unscrewed probe a few light years as a dead hulk appears doable. Sending a working star probe even a light year is something we don’t know how to do. It’s quite possible that 1000 ly is too far for any functional hunk of complex matter to fly, period.

So maybe dump the Fermi paradox into a bin with all the other stuff physicists say when they haven’t done the math?

 kiloseven replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 14, 2024 03:27
606:

Pigeon wrote in #359:

"I don't even know what "flash hook a phone" means"

I don't either. I strongly suspect the term is a piece of US-specific vocabulary. I therefore also do not know whether or not the actual procedure is also specific to the US phone system, of course.

Any wired phone on the Public Switched Telephone Network anywhere on this planet will allow dialing by flashing the hookswitch, the button(s) depressed when the handset goes back into the cradle of the phone. The term was well known to phone phreakers worldwide, as my discussions with fellow phreakers planetwide confirms. This picture shows why that part of the phone was originally known as the hook. https://c8.alamy.com/comp/T0K897/antique-candlestick-telephone-receiver-on-switch-hook-T0K897.jpg

When you spin the dial of a old rotary phone, you wind a spring. Release the dial, the spring forces the dial to return to its stop, and a spinning interrupter mechanism driven by the dial disconnects and reconnects ("breaks and makes") the phone line n times, where n ranges from 1 to 10. If you stuck your finger in the 1 hole before pushing the dial around, you get one break. The 2 hole gets two breaks, and so on. The 0 hole gets you 10 breaks.

The switch back at the central office sees the breaks and makes, and registers which number was dialed, for each spin of the dial. Push button dual tone multiple frequency ('DTMF') system was grafted on to the phone switches, but 'pulse' dialing still works.

The art of hook switch flash dialing was a skill highly praised when phone calls were expensive, and the dial was locked to prevent calling without permission. You could, with a little practise, tap out the number on the hook switch button, bypassing the dial lock.

 Heteromeles | June 14, 2024 06:16
616:

Back to the Fermi Paradox…

This is riffing off Brin’s novel Existence, which, like “Lungfish” had some really cool ideas not well dramatized, alas.

Anyway, let’s assume the obvious: it’s possible to launch something into interstellar space, but it’s not possible to get a working, uncrewed probe to a system even a light year away. By the time it arrives, say 500,000 years later, there’s going to be nobody back home for it to report to, even if it could talk. It’s a time capsule for a long-gone civilization.

So what to do? Send golden records on deep space probes. Messages in bottles, attached to missions that ended millennia before. If somebody finds it, they’ll know you existed long ago, even though you’ve almost certainly been forgotten on your home world.

Could be worse. This form of interstellar civilization could even come alive, in a way Brin noted, if the messages become like viral chain letters, increasingly optimized to get more copies of themselves made and sent out. Unless someone is stupid enough to use a big photon cannon to announce the launch and scream “here I am universe!” at the same time, deep space missions that incidentally carry messages will be hard to spot unless they’re in the system, so the galaxy could be teeming with spacefaring life and more or less maintain radio silence simultaneously.

 Moz replied to this comment from Tier2Tech | June 14, 2024 06:36
617:

90psi is 6 bar, so 5.4-ish? It's a question of persistence, I think. I've topped off truck tyres with a floor pump before (x6!), that was fairly tedious. Getting there from zero would be very, very boring. OTOH even the silliest US car is likely to have smaller volume tyres.

My main advice is to oil or grease the pump. You want the sliding seal between the plunger and the body to have actual lubrication rather than hopeing there's still something left from whenever you bought the pump.

If you're using a mini pump then I do wonder whether you'll wear out the pump before you throw it away in frustration. I buy mini pumps aiming for volume because I'm happy to ride a 6 bar tyre at 4 bar, but I'm not really keen on spending hours on the side of the road with a tiny little "high pressure" pump going into a 60mm wide load bike tyre.

 Moz replied to this comment from JHomes | June 14, 2024 06:43
618:

Lots of corporations have shared drives at random letters. S: for share being common, but also M and Z for whatever reason.

These days windows supports virtual mount points so I have also seen shenanigans there (redirecting "My Documents" onto the network, for example, as part of making it harder for users to save anything to their local machine at all). Viz, C:\Users\You\My Documents where C:\Users or C:\Users\You points to a location on a shared network drive. Something like that, I assume there's a management tool that lets people do this shit by enabling a policy rather than poking round on individual machines.

At work people talk about "the S drive" even though we have had I think M and Z drives for going on a decade now, trying to get people to stop vomiting crap onto the one common repository of all the things (featuring a collection of "New Folder (12)" and "Document (18).docx" in the root, of course). I vaguely recall that M is per-user and Z is read-only copy of the old S drive, but I access it via Linux so what would I know (~/nas and ~/moz)

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 14, 2024 07:05
620:

»I'm pretty sure that well before you found yourself needing to hack MSDOS to support more drive letters«

Twenty years ago i demolished and rebuilt how FreeBSD handles chr & blk devices with DEVFS, and disks, partitions, mirroring, raid etc. with GEOM.

As part of my testing, I created (on FreeBSD) a disk with a couple of hundred "extended" MBR partitions. There's no upper limit to those, their metadata forms a linked list, which incidentally makes the latter ones slower to find and more prone to disaster.

As an experiment, plugged that disk into various W95, W98 and NT3.1 systems, and as I recall it, the first bunch of partitions appeared as drive letters up to Z and the rest were nowhere to be found, including in the FORMAT program.

My guess is that the drive letter lookup in M$ products is an array of 26 pointers.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Scott Sanford | June 14, 2024 09:44
626:

»Speaking of third-party utilities to do trivial things MS didn't make standard, I while back I wanted to check how much memory was being used for what on a hard drive. Easy under Linux, surprisingly hard under Windows.«

I'm working on restoring a Rational R1000 computer in datamuseum.dk, very special beast in so many ways, including being object-oriented all the way down to hardware. (Also: instruction set are Ada primitives, bus is 64bit type + 64 bit data, and everything is bit-aligned.)

I had never thought about it before, but with a /truly OO/ system, you cannot just run "fsck", "rm -rf" or "du /" and get a quick reaction out of the filesystem: You have to traverse every single damn object, and ask it to do this thing itself.

The equivalent of "du /" took a full week on a 75% full 2GB object store.

 Moz replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 14, 2024 09:57
627:

That's a design decision, though, mostly about metadata. And presumably there's a root object that you can just delete :)

I used an OO database/language built by mainframe people once and that was kind of fun. But stuff like du were management tools that operated on metadata so were nice and quick (handy for a distributed database when networks were slow), but the equivalent of fsck could be very slow indeed, even locally. I once did the obvious thing and filled the DB disk on our test server and that revealed some exciting assumptions in the beta version of the system. But once they had a production version we never managed to damage it.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Mr. Tim | June 14, 2024 11:56
630:

About Dyson Swarms: It seems like Dyson Swarms (or Spheres) are never depicted favorably in Sci-Fi

They're just too big for fictional purposes.

(Remember, fiction in general is about human behaviour, and hard SF specifically tries to focus on human behaviour under circumstances that are plausible if you make a couple of changes to the known scientific rulebook then extrapolate. But you don't get human behaviour inside the Earth's inner mantle because it's just not an environment humans can plausibly exist in. And megastructures have similar problems, as settings for fiction ...)

After a couple of early attempts to grapple with them in the 70s (notably Ringworld by Niven and Orbitsville by Shaw) authors figured out that an actual fully-maintained ringworld civilization, never mind a Dyson shell, is simply too huge to contemplate. Niven's ringworld had roughly 3 million times the land area of Earth, so at our current population density could support about 24,000,000,000,000,000 humans and still have wilderness areas. And a Dyson shell would be roughly six orders of magnitude more surface area again!

We vaguely understand nations and empires as superorganisms of humans that operate on larger scales than, say, corporations or provinces: but we have no yardstick for extrapolating from a nation of roughly 100M people to an entity with a million subunits that populous. They'd have to solve coordination and dispute resolution problems arising on scales we can't even recognize, and never mind cultural diversity, there'd be a strong likelihood of speciation (at least Niven noticed that, although his handling of evolutionary biology is risibly bad in general).

At least Banks' solution -- to make them smaller (still vaster than planetary land areas, but a bit more tractable) and put superintelligences in charge -- was vaguely plausible.

(NB: I tackled this topic in Missile Gap, a novella you can find in the Wireless collection. Not a happy fun optimistic story!)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Moz | June 14, 2024 12:06

The Gaza war is nothing to do with lebensraum and everything to do with distracting the Israeli public from going after Netanyahu with pitchforks and torches for allowing October 7th to happen in the first place.

He's so deeply unpopular that if he downshifts from a war footing or signs a ceasefire he will be hounded out of office within days (and immediately prosecuted on corruption charges, which is his main motive for clinging to power at all costs -- he has immunity for now).

The Gaza War is to the Israeli Right what overturning Roe v. Wade was to the Christian Right in the USA -- a very handy carrot to dangle in front of the base for some indeterminate time in the future, not intended to actually happen on anybody's watch (and the eventual blowback will be intense).

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 14, 2024 12:13
632:

Sending a working star probe even a light year is something we don’t know how to do.

That's what the DARPA hundred year starship symposia in 2010-2015 was chewing over. Nobody knows how to do it, but let's get a bunch of folks from different disciplines into a conference hotel for a weekend to probe one anothers' ignorance and hope to strike some sparks.

What became clear was that the challenges of sending a small robot probe as far as proxima centauri within a century (so, 4.25 light years) are beyond daunting with today's technology, or even anything we can envisage developing by 2100 or thereabouts. Never mind slowing it down at the other end, and having it send data back.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Moz | June 14, 2024 12:21
633:

»That's a design decision, though, mostly about metadata. And presumably there's a root object that you can just delete :)«

Nope. It is a /truly/ object oriented machine. If you delete the root object, it has to ask any inferior objects to kindly piss off, before it can self-destruct. Those inferior objects have to do the same.

Interestingly, some of the objects refuse to go away, because they are part of a cross-compiler interface which runs the compiler on an RS/6000 they cannot "currently" contact.

I call them "the lemon-soaked napkin" objects :-)

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from David L | June 14, 2024 15:06
642:

There is a line at the end of an older B&W US western movie: "No, sir. This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend."

Just to point out, the cowboys of the Wild West were young, badly paid, and fairly frequently black or immigrant, so the level of myth making going on around cowboys is actually even bigger than you might expect.

But wait, it gets worse. The American West was colonized through deliberate subsidies, often in the form of dams. The philosophy embraced by Washington was “rain follows the plow,” meaning that if farmers settled a desert, it would become rainier. They were warned from the get go that it wouldn’t last, but as you might expect, the warnings were ignored.

So the Republican cowboy: independent American living on the frontier by his skills along, protecting his women, children, and land with his gun, and loudly praising Jeezus the whole time, is almost entirely mythical and heavily subsidized by the government. It’s no coincidence that Reagan, who was a Hollywood actor during the peak of the Western movie era, ran on this myth and curdled the Republican Party around it.

In case you’ve ever looked at archeological remnants like the Great Pyramid and wondered what the frack they were thinking in building them, this is how it happens. And dams are bigger and less durable than pyramids.

Read Cadillac Desert if you want the more on this story. I’ve often thought that it would make a decent base for a bleak SF story or series, with off world colonies—or construction of a Dyson Swarm—being the equivalent of the dam building frenzy of the 20th Century, and What Were They Thinking being the through line as all the colonies fail unless heavily subsidized, or unless they move on every few decades to build a new colony after the old one fails.

 David L replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 14, 2024 15:15
643:

The American West was colonized through deliberate subsidies, often in the form of dams.

Oh I know. But you skipped the first wave. The northwest territories act for the upper Ohio valley which was extended to much of the west.

Then the railroads. Which was really a real estate play. Build AND OPERATE a rail line and you get 1/2 of the land 5 miles on each side of the track. So they built water stops and bigger towns along the tracks, convinced settlers to move out along the tracks and create/settle in these towns and/or start farms and ranches out a bit. Then the rail roads serviced the transportation needs for supplies in and crops out. It was a great system based on "free" dirt.

 Tim H. replied to this comment from Tier2Tech | June 14, 2024 15:31
644:

If the recommended inflation pressure is 80 psi, consider a small barreled pump, otherwise the effort can be punishing, as well as tedious.

 David L replied to this comment from Tier2Tech | June 14, 2024 15:41
645:

use a bicycle air pump to get a small spare tire for an American Monstrosity up to 80psi (or whatever that is in civilized units)

American Monstrosities have full sized spares. Which typically are inflated to between 24 and 36 or so PSI.

Bicycle tires tend to be more in the 80psi range. Take the total area of a tire in contact with the earth and divide that into the weight of the vehicle. That gets to to the air pressure of the tire. Well close.

So if the pump can do a bicycle tire to 80psi it can do a full sized tire to the mid 30s. It just might take longer. And if you are doing one of those "bicycle spares" at 80 psi, the pump will work fine. Just longer.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 14, 2024 17:43
655:

Yes indeed - jack it up if possible. Even if this means using a manual jack. Although you're still supplying the energy for the lifting from your own body, it helps a lot to supply that chunk of the total energy in a separate operation, and it does make quite a noticeable difference to how hard the pumping is.

I agree with Moz that the best thing you can do with a bicycle pump (or any pump) is to put some lubricant designed for the purpose on the piston seal. I also agree that while a bicycle pump will achieve any pressure you're likely to need, you'll probably wear it out long before you've put any decent amount of air into the tyre; also the heat generated by compression may well be enough to make any crimped connection on whatever you've got to connect the pump to the tyre get hot and soft and come apart.

(I'm assuming this is the kind of tyre that is so huge that anyone short of a big manual labourer is going to struggle to even move the thing; am I right?)

If you are intending to use an electric compressor make sure you have some spare fuses for the thing, and know where it's hidden the fuse, too.

Whatever pump you intend to use it is more or less essential to give it a good try-out for its ergonomics before you buy it (if they won't let you, don't buy it). I've been using an electric compressor since long before I physically had to use one, because of finding far too many different muscle-powered pumps that look great but have been designed with no regard at all for how real human bodies mechanically operate, and are so bleeding awkward to use for a real task that you'd almost be better off sticking a tube up your arse and farting the tyre to inflation.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from David L | June 14, 2024 19:31
672:

And to be honest until the old guard in the Kremlin died off over a few years, it wasn't really possible.

Anecdote, ganked from I-can't-remember-where: in the late 1950s, Nikita Kruschev got to witness a megaton-range atmospheric H-bomb test.

After which, he couldn't sleep for three nights: I can't possibly order one of those things dropped on an inhabited city kept him awake with anxiety-induced insomnia.

Then on the third night, he realized: obviously I can't order one of those dropped on a city, but we don't have to tell the Americans that.

After which he was able to sleep again.

I suspect there was a huge amount of that sort of doublethink going on, probably on both sides, by the more responsible or non-sociopathic adults in the room. As witness the fact that on the American side, both General MacArthur and Curtis LeMay were involuntarily "retired" after they sidled too close to the big red button while drooling copiously and sporting wood.

 JohnS replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 14, 2024 20:55
678:

Charlie Stross @ 632:

"Sending a working star probe even a light year is something we don’t know how to do."

That's what the DARPA hundred year starship symposia in 2010-2015 was chewing over. Nobody knows how to do it, but let's get a bunch of folks from different disciplines into a conference hotel for a weekend to probe one anothers' ignorance and hope to strike some sparks.

What became clear was that the challenges of sending a small robot probe as far as proxima centauri within a century (so, 4.25 light years) are beyond daunting with today's technology, or even anything we can envisage developing by 2100 or thereabouts. Never mind slowing it down at the other end, and having it send data back.

Did they at least come up with some sort of list of problems that have to be solved before it would become possible?

I'm expecting any such list would be woefully incomplete for identifying all of the problems, but at least it would be a start towards developing ideas.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from kiloseven | June 15, 2024 03:32
688:

"Any wired phone on the Public Switched Telephone Network anywhere on this planet will allow dialing by flashing the hookswitch, the button(s) depressed when the handset goes back into the cradle of the phone. The term was well known to phone phreakers worldwide, as my discussions with fellow phreakers planetwide confirms."

That a piece of the internal jargon originated by a group of US nerds became used worldwide among the diaspora of said nerds does not refute its being a piece of US-specific vocabulary. It's an American word being carried around the world by speakers of American.

It's not just US vocabulary, it's US use of language. If pressing a button makes a light flash somewhere, we might invent jargon terms based on "flashing a light", but we wouldn't invent jargon terms based on "flashing a button", because it doesn't make sense. The verb ("flash") does not refer to a thing that you can do to the object ("button"), so we don't say it.

(Unless the thing we are using "flash" to refer to is "exposing to view for a sudden brief glimpse", which it obviously can't be in this case to begin with, and even if it was referring to that it would only be meaningful if the "button" was the one in the middle of your belly.)

We did have phones that looked like that but only at a time when hardly anyone had a phone at all, and at that time phones didn't have dials. The way you used those phones was to pick up the receiver (earpiece), and joggle the bracket (the thing on the side you hang the receiver on when you're not using it) up and down, which would let the operator know you were waiting to speak to them. When they answered you, you then asked them for the number you wanted ("Fellside, seven five... No... Not nine... FIVE. F for fool. I for idiot...") and hope they connected you before the fire got too big.

(That is an authentic representation, written at the time, of how ordinary British people naturally speak about this matter.)

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from alantyson | June 15, 2024 13:17
707:

as another example of how fiction/myth/narrative can have a more outsized influence on actual policy than maybe we'd like

A number of technical reports have deliberately included fictional vignettes about imaginary characters because stories are how humans learn, and what we remember best. IIRC, we've discussed that a time or two on this blog.

Cohen & Stewart used that technique in Collapse of Chaos and Figments of Reality, as well as their Science of Discworld series.

Stories are easy to understand; easier than technical reports, certainly. Add in the visuals of a movie and you get an emotional impact and urgency that 'mere' data doesn't have. That's why one death is a tragedy, a million deaths a statistic. People remember the story long after they've forgotten the numbers.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 15, 2024 15:11
716:

No point etching DNA onto diamond; DNA is a medium, not an encoding, so by drawing it on a more durable medium you are simply getting the ordinary durability of that more durable medium, not any kind of extra improvement on top. (Well there is a very minor degree of extra, but it's from factors which are present kind of accidentally, and you can get far better results using those factors by deliberately designing them in.)

DNA is really an unusually bad medium for long-term data storage because the entropy barrier to flipping a bit is designed to be low (yes I know but it makes it so much easier to talk about); it has to be manipulated by low-energy biochemistry that can only muster up a comparatively small entropy change per reaction, so if the barrier is too high the DNA would be as immutable from the organism's point of view as ROM is from a computer's, and we now know organisms/evolution don't work like that. We have only found examples of it lasting 150 million years because there has been oh so tremendously huge a number of instances scattered around the place over the history of the planet that sooner or later we're bound to find a bit that happened to end up in some place that protects it so amazingly well it did manage to last that long, and we haven't found examples of anything else lasting that long because there isn't anything else from that long ago to find in the first place.

To maximise the height of the barrier (durability of medium) you do best by going for sheer size. If you represent a bit using a big chunk of metal or rock which you make either long and thin or squat and flat, you have a vastly higher entropy barrier against changing it from one to the other than is possible for methods like changing the shape of a molecule or swapping defects/heteroatoms/isotopes in a crystal lattice. But of course your storage device is then a huge great clumsy thing.

To maximise the chance of being able to understand data from a medium that hasn't survived perfectly (durability of encoding) you need to use an encoding that records a given sequence of bits as a pattern of changes in the medium which is good at telling you where it's wrong and how to put it right. That sounds weird because it is weird and working out how best to do it is a lot of heavy maths. (Having multiple copies is a subset of this aspect.)

How to balance these factors against each other and against other things like your capabilities and resources is unfortunately not really something that we can discuss on this blog and get any answer that is meaningful for actual serious purposes, because it's just too bloody complicated. I've got a book about that sort of thing (relating to different desired outcomes, but the fundamental topic is the same) - it is full of mathematics, because it has to be, and it's pretty brain-melting stuff with a fair number of highly non-intuitive aspects.

We can certainly get somewhere useful in SF terms, though, since "has to look plausibly like an optimal solution to a knowledgeable reader" is a far looser constraint than "has to really work". So for instance I find heteroatoms in a diamond lattice a useful idea for a durable medium, because it does make it possible to get a high entropy barrier in comparison with other methods that operate on that kind of scale, it's dense enough that you can use massive duplication as an easily-understood means of increasing the durability of the encoding, it's already possible with known technology, and the idea of immense numbers of altered diamond crystals carried on spaceships or scattered around planets is pretty cool and makes for some attractive imagery.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 15, 2024 15:23
717:

"I suppose DNA is a good, rugged information storage material"

No, it isn't - see above: it's a distinctly non-rugged one, it has to be for biochemical and evolutionary reasons; living organisms run error-checking-and-correction/deletion processes on it to achieve a useful level of overall robustness; it doesn't matter if it gets corrupted once the organism is dead, and the reason we do find incredibly ancient examples that still work is a statistical consequence of massive, massive duplication and distribution.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 15, 2024 15:37
718:

thanks... based upon wikpedia entry... this is nightmare fuel

"The War Game" is basically why the UK gave up on civil defense after 1972 (at the latest).

The UK is geographically compact and roughly 90% of the population (some 50 million people, back then) lived in roughly 120,000km^2 (actual land area of UK is 240,000km^2, but about half to two-thirds of that is Northern Ireland, Wales, and the Scottish Highlands, with a combined population of maybe 10% of the total). That's about the area of Pennsylvania, but with the population of California crammed into it.

Now bear in mind the UK was within range of Soviet tactical weapons -- short-range bombers and missiles -- of which the USSR had 3x to 5x as many as they had strategic weapons. And that the UK was NATO's unsinkable aircraft carrier in the Atlantic, and the supply convoys in event of WW3 would be heading from the US eastern seaboard to British ports before moving on to the continental theatre.

As of 1972, they expected about a third of the population to die, and another third to be wounded, within the first hour of a war with the USSR. And 90% death within six months. The UK hasn't been self-sufficient in foodstuffs since the Napoleonic wars, and would face agricultural collapse in the wake of a nuclear attack (no more fuel for the agricultural tractors, disrupted logistics to prevent food distribution, high level fallout blanketing farmland, and so on).

The phrase "the survivors will envy the dead" was quite applicable.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 15, 2024 15:46
720:

The equipment on Voyager is holding up surprisingly well, but it has to be rebooted from Earth on occasion. That won’t be possible on an interstellar probe, so….

Actually, we're a lot better as designing fault-tolerant computing systems than we used to be. And don't underestimate the importance of lessons learned from the Voyager missions, which have now been running for nearly 47 years.

The Voyager flight computers were incredibly austere by modern standards -- about as powerful as a Commodore 64, but slower. And weight constraints meant they could only shove one CPU on each probe. Today we can make processors arbitrarily small, which is not necessarily a great idea for ruggedization ... but we can also cram a whole gang of them together and organize them to monitor each other, use watchdog timers to schedule hard resets if they stop responding, do all the memory self-test and remapping stuff internally using redundant hardware, and so on.

A 100YSS computer wouldn't bear much resemblance to your current laptop or smartphone, either in weight or architecture -- it'd be a lot less performant and have a lot of esoteric error-correction features -- but I'm pretty sure we could develop a machine that would have a credible chance of running for a century, or even five to ten of them, in a high radiation cryogenic vacuum environment.

It won't run Windows or macOS or Android, though, or indeed anything most people would recognize.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from David L | June 15, 2024 17:03
723:

"I've not seen a hand piston with long rod air pump for anything but sports balls in years."

Really? That's a standard bicycle pump to me. I've got one. I could pop down town right now and buy another one. (Unless the bicycle shop has gone bust in the last few years - I haven't been that way for a while.)

It works fine for inflating my bicycle tyres. I agree about the ergonomic advantages of other formats (at least if they are designed to express them; if they're not, they can turn the advantage negative). But the internal volume of a bicycle tyre is (estimating) only a single-digit multiple of the swept volume of the standard hand pump; it takes (I've counted) <100 strokes to pressurise the tyre, which isn't enough for the ergonomic suboptimality to become really significant.

I have used one for a motor tyre, but although the pressure is lower the volume is so much larger that both the user and the pump itself need several rest and maintenance breaks and both are knackered afterwards, and the adaptor tube that connects the pump to the valve may even fail terminally and need replacement. It is viable-ish as a move of desperation but no more than that.

I have seen electric pumps with their own batteries on sale but I'm not sure that many people are using the serious ones such as you describe, although we do have them. People do use Christmas cracker ones that run on torch batteries and basically just shift volume for inflating airbeds and other beach/water toy things, because they're cheap and easy, they're the sort of cheap-shit electrics people are happy to take on the beach because you don't have to care much if they get ruined by sand and salt water, and it's no more than a nuisance if they do pack up on you, but they aren't what you meant - they're made for toys, they are basically toys themselves, and toys are all they can cope with.

For proper pumps that can handle car tyres as normal business the popular choice is an electric pump that runs off the car's battery, because the advantage of one that uses its own proper rechargeable battery is not usually big enough to make it worth paying the extra money. I can foresee it maybe becoming worth it for me at some point, but I don't think my body's deteriorated quite that far yet.

"And either way they [spares] do not need inflating at point of use"

They don't in the sense that they are always inflated when they are first put in the car, but they tend to stay there for years and years with the owner never checking them ("check all the tyres including the spare" is pre-test driving instruction content, but nobody ever bothers), and I've come across loads of cars where the spare has gone down over the years and could not be used (at all) if you didn't inflate it.

"215/50 R17 ... 255/70 R18"

Oh dear... there's another shark watching out for the arse of a transatlantic conversation swimming past. Paws and I are used to width-diameter-aspect; you appear to be used to width-aspect-diameter. With specific examples the funny numbers make it obvious what's happened, but it looks like my attempt to describe the labelling by format to Tier2Tech still fails despite my correction.

And I see that you do (now?) get the same stupid bit of confusion that we do of the width being in mm and the diameter in inches. I thought you'd stayed with having them both in inches, like we used to until some bell did a half-arsed job of the metrication. Fortunately we are now finishing the job and going back to having consistent units again (both metric, now), but it's taken so long for that to begin to happen that the confusion is still going to be around long after it's been finished.

Commonly called a "donut spare" here in the U.S.

"• Many vehicles are provided with a "limited use" spare tire, also known as a "space-saver", temporary spare, "donut", or "compact" spare tire — in an attempt to reduce cost, lower the vehicle's weight, or conserve the space that would be needed for a full-size spare tire. Introduced in the late 1970s,[11] as of 2017, temporary spares come standard on 53 percent of 2017 models in the U.S.[12] A space-saver is typically 7 kg (15 lb) lighter than a full-sized wheel and in some cars the so-called 'space-saver' may actually save little to no space. There is also the difficulty of transporting the full-sized wheel and tire once the space-saver has been fitted. The spare is usually mounted on a plain steel rim.
They are typically smaller than the normal tires on the vehicle and can only be used for limited distances because of their short life expectancy and low speed rating. As well, due to the different size of a donut compared to regular wheel, electronic stability control and traction control systems will not operate properly and should be disabled until the original wheel is restored.[citation needed] Space saver spare tires could potentially compromise the braking (especially on cars not fitted with anti-lock brakes) and handling of the car.[13]"

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spare_tire

I recognized what you meant because they're the only tires I'm familiar with that are inflated to 80psi. Regular (full-size) spare tires are inflated to the same tire pressure as the other tires on the vehicle.

You have my deepest sympathy if you ever have to pump one up using a bicycle pump.

 JohnS replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 15, 2024 21:37
736:

Pigeon @ 723:

"215/50 R17 ... 255/70 R18"

Oh dear... there's another shark watching out for the arse of a transatlantic conversation swimming past. Paws and I are used to width-diameter-aspect; you appear to be used to width-aspect-diameter. With specific examples the funny numbers make it obvious what's happened, but it looks like my attempt to describe the labelling by format to Tier2Tech still fails despite my correction.

And I see that you do (now?) get the same stupid bit of confusion that we do of the width being in mm and the diameter in inches. I thought you'd stayed with having them both in inches, like we used to until some bell did a half-arsed job of the metrication. Fortunately we are now finishing the job and going back to having consistent units again (both metric, now), but it's taken so long for that to begin to happen that the confusion is still going to be around long after it's been finished.

I'm not sure why that should be confusing, because AFAIK, we got it from you.

That's the Euro-Metric tire specification. The U.S. can on occasion adopt a standard promulgated by another government ... when it makes sense to do so.

AFAIK, it's been used here in the U.S. since at least the early 80s. That's when I first remember seeing tires labeled that way (may have been before that, but that's the earliest I remember it).

Radial tires were introduced in the U.S. in the mid-70s and got a boost in popularity during the Arab Oil Embargo (because they could increase gas mileage). I believe they became mandatory as standard equipment in 1982.

Actually those should be 215/50R17 (no space) ... 215mm tread width, section height (the rubber part of the tire) is 50% of the tread width, 107.5mm and it's made to fit a 17" (431.8mm) diameter wheel. The tire mounted on the wheel will be 646.8mm or 25.46456692913386 inches in diameter (the only number you need to remember is 24.4 - the number of millimeters in an inch).

... and 255/70R18 - 255mm tread width; 178.5mm section height (x2 = 357mm) and a 18" (x25.4 = 457.2mm)diameter wheel, for a mounted diameter of (357+457.2) 814.2mm or 32.05511811023622 inches.

Fifty or Sixty "profile" tires usually require a deeper (thicker) wheel.

Oh, and the 'R' means it's a Radial tire rather than bias ply ...

Now if you want to know WHY the Europeans chose a mixed standard (millimeters AND inches), I can't help you. You'll have to ask the Europeans.

Like McGee he only works the minimum necessary to pursue private interests between jobs, and much to my enjoyment does a lot of reading during slack periods, sharing book recommendations such as Steven Brust's fantasy series and James Gleick's works on chaos and information.

The local library had these books, so I started with Gleick's "The Information: a History, a Theory, a Flood" and got to a part on the Turing Test about guessing who is or isn't an A. I., which I quote here:

"Turing offers up some imagined questions and answers: Q:  Please write me a sonnet on the subject of the Forth Bridge. A:  Count me out on this one. I never could write poetry."

My improved version would have been:

A: I don't even know what a sonnet is, maybe I could try a limerick, how's that. Q: That'll be fine, I guess? A: The Firth of Forth needed a crossing      So designs back and forth they were tossing      Engineers oft derided      But never decided      Their plan needs a man good at bossing.

The woke formulation would have been SOMEONE good at bossing but without emphasis on both syllables it doesn't scan right.

And I couldn't think of a rhyme to express Victoria's sorrow at the mass casualties, when a bridge failure derailed a train into the Firth in actual history.

Rejected stanzas: Back and forth to the Firth                          Sally forth to the north                           From the first to the fourth                            There's a dearth at the Firth

 paws4thot replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 15, 2024 22:38
744:

Uhuh!

Crossply tyres were sized in inches, decimal fractions for width and whole numbers for wheel size. For example 4.1x10 for a (real) Mini.
Radials were sized in mixed units for the highly practical reason that it became instantly obvious if some fitted a crossply and a radial to a single "axle" because the radial would be 135R10 for the same Mini, and there was no need to change the wheel size because the tyres were being made so that either type would fit the same wheel.

 Robby replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 15, 2024 23:09
745:

I think something along the lines of FPGAs would be good for your interstellar probe computer. Lots of them, with an awful lot of clever error correction stuff built in. A few gates got fried? Route around them. Scientists on earth want to completely reconfigure the computer after a few decades? Send up the new configuration. Generally, design to be redundant, not rugged. Shielding is heavy. Rugged means a low transistor count. Easier to design so that you can lose 99% of your transistors, anywhere, and still complete the mission. Parallels with cheap drones versus expensive aircraft.

@ 728: "whose vocabulary do you think should have spread around the world along with the invention?"

I don't. The kind of vocabulary and usage normal for the local language will do much better. There are trees and candles and lots of other peculiar things in French cars, because they are using the words that are natural for them to use, whereas if they used the French translations of words other people use they would find them awkward and silly. "register recall"

Haha, that's a third different thing, that nobody has brought into the discussion yet! (or if they have I haven't noticed.) I've no idea how anywhere else approached it, but in Britain that was always really obscure. It was not available on a line unless you specifically asked the Post Office to enable it at the exchange, and they would charge you extra for having it - I don't know exactly how much, but it would have been a lot. So you would be up to fairly large businesses before you began to find people using it at all, and it was never something you'd find on a domestic line.

"North America (which I again remind you includes nations OTHER THAN the U.S.)"

If you're saying that for the reason I think you are, then my point was that the commonly-used term "American English" is wretchedly inaccurate because it elides the areas of mutual incomprehensibility, one of which began this sub-conversation by blatantly existing at us (see two British people and one Australian all having the same reaction of "what the fuck is that supposed to mean?"). So I used the usual term, but in a modified form, without the word which causes the inaccuracy I'm unhappy with.

@ 733: "Who, in turn, will defend us from those determined to save us?"

I recently had personal cause to attempt some research into an area of that. I am not happy that I didn't find a bloody thing, or even a clue how to proceed. Some vague hint that very carefully hiding or disappearing might have a non-zero chance of being useful - none of that stated explicitly - was the most positive thing I could dig up.

Some of "those determined to save us" can be dangerous cunts.

@ 736: "I'm not sure why that should be confusing, because AFAIK, we got it from you."

The context quotation you provided for your reply comprised two paragraphs relating to two different sub-aspects, but your reply seems to refer more obviously to the second paragraph, so I'll start with that one:

Yeah, I was hoping/expecting you would have determinedly managed not to.

Using two different sets of units to refer to the same dimension - especially in a manner which cobbles both sets of units together adjacently, in the same expression, which doesn't label either unit, is bloody stupid, because it's an obvious and fulminant source of confusion. You could hardly say I'm unfamiliar with it, but it still manages to confuse me about one in three or four times I have to deal with tyre sizes. Sometimes more than once in the same day.

I don't know what idiot thought it would be a good idea either, but they need to be placed in an environment where they randomly encounter unlabelled interminglings of different units for the same dimension, in lots of different contexts, all the time, until either they understand what they did wrong or their brain starts to dribble out of their ears.

Now I'll take the first paragraph: For years and years in the context of British domestic motoring, aspect ratio just was not part of a tyre size specification. You specified tyres by width and diameter only. For a given pairing of width and diameter, you just got whatever the standard aspect ratio for that pairing was, and the only people who needed to know the actual figure were the tyre manufacturers. You didn't get three numbers moulded into the side of the tyre, you only got two. When all of a sudden there did appear some tyres with a non-standard aspect ratio, the natural way to amend the format of the spec was simply to not really amend it, but just say you can stick the third number on the end if you're talking about a case that needs three numbers.

So when Paws and I started talking about tyre sizes using examples of "real" specs, width-diameter-aspect was what we used. But when you and David L joined in, you used width-aspect-diameter. Until then it had never occurred to me that you might have arrived at the need to specify all three figures by some other path that made it more natural to put the aspect ratio in the middle, but now - just after I'd corrected the cockup in my reply to Tier2Tech - I suddenly discovered that I might still have ended up quoting a wrong format for reasons I'd never suspected.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from paws4thot | June 16, 2024 04:19
766:

Oh, yeah, I'd forgotten about that "reason" - never convinced that it was really true; there's a rather strong "Just So story" flavour about it, in that it makes enough sense to serve as a basis for telling an amusing story that purports to explain a peculiar thing, but no more than that; it's too vague and unsatisfactory to be a sensible way of conveying a critical safety warning in real life. The size of the tyre is specified by two numbers; if the numbers look funny, that means, obviously, that something about the size of the tyre might be funny. Then you have an official pronouncement that says, no, it doesn't mean something vague about the size, it means something absolutely definite about something that has fuck all to do with the size - but is critically important, so be sure and remember this, kiddies.

Now if I was trying to convey a critically important single bit of safety information, I'd choose a new, unique, unambiguous binary marker, that does not resemble any marker already in use, and has some characteristic that naturally associates it with the meaning of the safety-critical single bit strongly enough that you can expect even people who've never been told about the marker and never seen one before will still know what it means.

And they did do that. Radials have a big "R" for Radial and the word itself in smaller letters, and crossplies don't. So using funny numbers to drop vague hints as well now just looks completely daft, and its value as a real-world explanation drops to zero. I can't conclude the story is true because it doesn't make sense; but if in fact it nevertheless is true, it must be true for a reason that doesn't make sense. (Some close relation to the nature of the Top Cat/Boss Cat Britishism might be a plausibly likely candidate.)

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 16, 2024 05:23
769:

You can't use that to recapture all the information you are losing, no matter what you do; the best you can do is partially compensate, and the more effectively you do manage to compensate the more wibbly-wobbly and impractical your device gets, in ways like waiting for it to complete recording something being worse than a Windows update, and it being liable to start forgetting again if you look at it funny. If I remember rightly the very best "known achievable" would be under 10% using DNA under ideal conditions; it would be a pretty tough job to match the way DNA works to the way you need your conscious memory to work in any useful way, achieving any useful approximation to the "ideal conditions" lands you in a recursive mess of the same kind of problems, so you basically can't, and anything we have the vaguest clue how to do with technology is many orders of magnitude worse.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from paws4thot | June 16, 2024 06:58
770:

"The original US name of the show was "Top Cat". After a few weeks (Wikipedia says 4) it was renamed "Boss Cat" in the UK because "Top Cat" was the name of a popular brand of cat food, and the BBC could not carry advertising."

Yes, I know that; it's exactly the kind of extent of coverage you would expect something like wikipedia to constrain itself to.

My point was firstly that while "the BBC can't carry advertising" is basically a good idea they did have a distinct tendency to carry it to ludicrous extremes, and stretch the definition of "carrying advertising" to include things where you struggle to find even the most tenuous justification for even thinking about calling them "carrying advertising". Often they would end up calling more attention to a product than if they'd just been normal about it, because they would be so obviously tying themselves in knots trying not to have to say a particular word that everyone knew anyway exactly what word it was, and knew the reason they were being so uptight about not saying it was that in addition to the meaning they were actually intending, it happened to be a word you often saw on labels in shops. Certainly it's a bit of a stretch to say that because another country happened to pick the same words for the name of a show that a British company happened to pick for the name of some cat food, then simply calling the show by its correct name must be "advertising".

Then secondly, the half-arsedness comes in because in this case they didn't go to extremes to avoid broadcasting a particular word. Instead they only "changed the name of the show to Boss Cat" in the sense that they called it that in the Radio Times and similar. As far as the actual programme went, they didn't change a thing, they just showed it in plain unedited form straight from the US. The title card said "TOP CAT" in great big letters, the theme song sang "Top Cat" loudly multiple times, all the other cats addressed the title character as "Top Cat" in the dialogue, it was Top Cat Top Cat Top Cat solidly all the way through. Using a different word for it in the Radio Times just looked silly, and how they can claim with a straight face to have "changed the name of the show", or genuinely believe there was any point doing what they did do, I fail to see.

"It's not so much a "real world explanation" as a rationalisation and statement of the real world facts in the case."

Not entirely sure what you're getting at here. My point is that dropping nebulous hints by having some numbers which mean something entirely unrelated look funny is a fucking stupid way to convey a piece of critical safety information; using a specific and unique symbol that obviously relates directly to that piece of information and does not remotely resemble any symbol in use for other purposes is a good and sensible way to convey it; they did use such a symbol; and because they did, to say the funny numbers were for that is just daft, and although it often is said it's too silly for me to believe it's true.

I think it's far more likely that the funny numbers are to indicate that although both tyres do fit on the same wheel, the dimensions in fact are not exactly the same; but the difference is so small that it has no noticeable effect, so it's not information that anyone actually needs to know, and it doesn't matter if you don't understand the message or don't bother/know the factor to convert the metric figure back into inches to find out what it actually is.

I also don't understand what premise the piece of evidence that people very rarely did it wrong is intended to support. It can't be "the funny numbers were there to show it's a radial", and I can't work out what element of the discussion it can be.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from DeMarquis | June 16, 2024 17:27
785:

Did they consider laser sails? That's almost doable today.

Laser sails are not in fact doable today.

For a pure photon rocket you need roughly 3GW of continuous power to provide 1 newton per second of thrust. While we can build lasers that emit more than 1GW, they're pulsed -- and our lasers max out at about 25% efficiency currently, so a 3GW continuous wave laser would be dumping 9GW of waste heat, which is roughly 10% of the total power consumption of the UK (for 1N of thrust, which is enough to accelerate 100 grams at 1G).

 Troutwaxer replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 16, 2024 18:53
