 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 16, 2024 19:42
787:

As noted, STL warp drives are looking better. Obviously we can't make these yet either, but if you look at some more recent theoretical papers, if I read them right, it looks like it might be possible to build a warp drive out of positive mass materials only, provided it goes slower than C. Depending on practicalities like power input, this might mean that a 100 year probe is possible.

As for the mission profile, I think 'Oumuamua had the right idea (yes, I've read the book that claims it was an alien ship). Anyway, probe enters star system at ca. 15 km/sec relative to the local star, maneuvering as little as possible while passively scanning the system. If there are signs of a technological culture, set a course for a cometary pass, go flying through the system like a comet while using passive sensors only, then set a course to go home once its back out in interstellar space.

What I'm thinking about is that it's doubly stupid to actively broadcast from a life-bearing stellar system. On the one hand, the local inhabitants might catch you. On the other, some more advanced civilization might pick up your communications and get to the system before your controllers back home do. If a ship is fast and smart enough, flying out and back before dumping data may be the safest option. And if warp drives aren't especially detectable, so much the better.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 16, 2024 20:01
788:

»For a pure photon rocket you need roughly 3GW of continuous power«

All the "artists impression" graphics I've seen, put the laser in orbit, powered by solar panels.

Most people who do the math on that configuration seem to stop before they get to the really interesting stuff, for instance Stefan-Boltzmann law.

The bad news is that we must dump all heat via radiation.

The good news is that as long as we point our radiator away from the sun, we can ignore the contribution from the cosmic background radiation.

If we assume semiconductor lasers, they must be kept below 120°C, call it 400K

If we fill 400K into S-B's law, we find that we can dump 1451W/m².

9GW will take around 600 FIFA regulation soccer fields, which is within an order of magnitude of the solar panels required to produce the power.

The obvious design then becomes millions of independent space vehicles, each one a solar panel pointed at the Sun, with a black alu-core PCB full of semiconductor lasers, each of which are mounted on some kind of MEMS structure so it can be pointed with sub-microarc-second precision.

We hinge the PCB and solar panel together, that allows us to point all the lasers at anything well clear of the orbital plane, and distribute the satellites as trojans in Earth's orbit, that way they won't bump into anything and Earth will never shadow the target.

I'll leave it as an exercise for the reader to figure out how to make the light from all the lasers arrive phase-coherent at the target's sail, though an unknown and undefined interstellar medium.

 Vulch replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 16, 2024 22:02
791:

Worth having a read up on "Starwisp" which was a project to design a light weight Maser launched interstellar probe. Much easier to make a phased array at microwave frequencies than optical, and the sail becomes a wire mesh with spacing to match the wavelength of the maser.

Many of the maser and laser based launcher projects involve the arrays being located on the far side of the moon using either nuclear or stored solar power, and running launch campaigns during the Lunar night. If you can put multiple GW of power into a lightsail at astronomical distances people tend to worry about you putting multiple GW into the centre of their city. You tend to want to launch away from the sun anyway, the dark sky lets you radiate the heat away more easily and being on a common solid surface makes it easier to keep your phased array in sync.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 16, 2024 22:54
795:

"...each of which are mounted on some kind of MEMS structure so it can be pointed with sub-microarc-second precision. ... I'll leave it as an exercise for the reader to figure out how to make the light from all the lasers arrive phase-coherent at the target's sail, though an unknown and undefined interstellar medium."

Don't need to give each emitter its own personal mechanical pointing unit: they're lasers, just lock them all together and operate the thing as an optical phased array antenna. You avoid having to do awkward things like (potentially) trimming each mechanical unit by shaving precise numbers of atoms off it to match them all perfectly with each other or whatever, and you get the additional advantage that you automatically get to launch a perfectly coherent planar wavefront in the first place, which is surely going to be a very important first step if you're setting out to make it arrive like that.

It's the kind of technology we're already quite remarkably bloody good at, and being embedded inside a common solid block with perfectly uniform mechanical properties makes it...

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 16, 2024 23:57
798:

»operate the thing as an optical phased array antenna.«

Sure, if we a allowed to make the lasers out of elemental Handwavium, would could do that, and we might as well make their efficiency 98% while we're at it ?

To make a phased array, you need to be able to control the phase for each transmitter individually.

As far as I know, nobody has even managed to control the frequency of two lasers well enough to generate an interference pattern between them, without intentionally or accidentally injection locking them.

So never mind controlling the phase: We cannot even measure it (yet).

Once we have figured out how to control the phase, we need to invent an optical "isolator" to prevent backscatter from the 3GW beam from injection-locking all the lasers.

Now scale that up to hundreds of millions of individual laser sources.

And even if you build your magic laser, that can do all that fancy stuff out of Handwavium-121, it is still not enough to launch it coherently, it must hit the sail coherently.

If the interstellar medium is homogeneous over the beam width, you can in principle do that with a phased array, except for the fact that steering a laser at sub-micro-arcsecond phase increments takes you into the territory where both the plank-time and plank-length are not ignorable.

But dont worry about that, because the Fresnel zone is going to be so huge that that inhomogeneities in the interstellar medium will be nontrivial, and it is going to be particular bad in the near field due to the solar wind, and who knows how much turbulence in the "bow-shock"

That adds an Adaptive optics system to the shopping list, an AO system where the sensors are located five to ten times further out than Voyager 1 has gotten to.

As I said: People stop their calculations before they get to all the fun stuff...

 DeMarquis replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 17, 2024 00:01
799:

"The problem with a laser sail is aiming the laser at any reasonable distance. For instance, tagging a sail that’s a mile in diameter from 1AU away (93 million miles ish) means you have to be accurate to a tiny fraction of a second of arc. Not counting beam dispersion.

Then you’ve also got to worry about what Chuckles McVamos, laser sharpshooter, wants to shoot at when he’s done booting probes. Flyby lasik surgery maybe? Mosquito control from orbit? High energy extortion?"

I would aim for developing a much larger sail than that. Regardless of that, here is a possible solution: angle the edges of the sail such that they provide some degree of sideways thrust. In addition, the laser array is such that the center of the beam is the hottest. Near Earth, it is easy to place the probe in the center of the beam. As it proceeds, it will begin to drift. As the edge of the sail approaches the center of the beam (which is inevitable) it heats up, pushing the probe sideways and back into the center of the beam. I's self correcting with no moving parts.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 17, 2024 00:47
802:

I am assuming a communist Germany would become authoritarian in due course, because that seems to be the way communism fails. Any reason not to assume this?

In my darker moments I wonder if that's the way every model of government eventually fails.

A key question is how long since its formation are you thinking of? A generation? More? Less? Most organizations change as the founding generation is replaced — some of your own country's founders would be aghast at how modern generations (including the originalists) have twisted their dream (And others would be aghast at how modern generations are chaining themselves to an imaginary past.)

Is our world's East Germany an adequate model, or is it too shaped by WW2, Stalinism, and Nazism? If East Germany isn't a good model, what are the key differences I need to think about? (this is basically about early 1920s post war Germany versus late 1940s post-war Germany). This is the part I'm struggling most with.

East Germany was profoundly shaped by WWII (and Stalinism and Nazism). I think it would have been quite different if established sooner. Precisely how I'm less certain, because a lot depends on precisely how it was established. How much interference was there from non-Communist neighbours? Remember that the western powers, including America, invaded Russia after WWI in support of the Whites — it would have been much easier to invade Germany.

Also, which faction are you assuming ends up winning the revolution and subsequent power struggles? The KPD? The KAPD? Would a more literate and educated workforce give council democracy a chance at working? Several Irish soviets were successfully formed in the early 20s during the civil war but eventually quashed (amid claims that they were more loyal to Soviet Russia than the Irish Free State).

Which is a long disjointed way of saying that communism took different forms outside Russia, so I think that a communist Germany would also have looked different. The Bolsheviks took over chunks of the Tsarist government —the Cheka inherited the techniques and many of the agents of the Okhrana, for example, which accounts for some of the similarities between Tsarist Russia and Soviet Russia. Similarly German communists would be inheriting German governmental functionaries, with all that implies.

What would be the relationships between a 1920s communist Germany and its neighbors?

Likely bad. Military forces were sent to Russia the previous decade to oppose Communism there, and now Germany goes Communist? The dominoes are falling and we have to do something!

In America you had the first Red Scare around 1920 (more to follow!). It petered out, but if Germany had turned Communist it would likely have re-ignited. Would labour organizations have taken inspiration from a Communist Germany? Would the authorities have seen it as enough of a threat to clamp down even harder on organized labour? Remember that America was deploying machine guns and airplanes against strikers; modern strikes are pale affairs compared to the Battle of Blair Mountain, the Anaconda Road Massacre, the Columbine Mine Massacre, and many more. And that's with an ocean protecting you and no prospect of invasion — anyone sharing a land border with Germany would have been very concerned.

Hate to ask this, but what form might antisemitism take in such a scenario? I'm thinking, of course, about Nazism in the 1930s and trying to figure out what would happen absent Hitler. I'm also thinking about how the exodus of Jewish intellectuals under Hitler shaped western physics.

What form did it take in Russia at the time (pre-Stalin)?

Much might depend on which faction of Communists managed to take power. If Luxemburg hadn't been executed and had some power then probably things would be less antisemitic (given she herself was Jewish, although secular). OTOH Hitler tapped into existing antisemitism so maybe "not as bad as the Nazis" is a big win?

For those who care, what would communist German agriculture look like, at least at first. Collectivization a la the USSR? Would there be a potential for famines, as in Russia in the 1930s?

Would agriculture be as big a focus as it was in Russia? Germany was far closer to what Marx saw as the place Communism would start, being industrialized and capitalist. (Lenin had to change quite a lot of Marx to explain how Russia could skip the industrialization step to get to Communism directly.) Would the German Communists have nationalized everything, or would they have concentrated on the big factories and ignored smaller traders/farmers (at least at the beginning)?

The Irish soviets were quite literally workers councils centred around workplaces, rather than top-town control organizations. Could something like modern German corporate governance evolve, with workers having a seat on the board? (Yes, I know that was imposed by the Allies after WWII to hamper German companies, but it seems to have helped them instead.)

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 17, 2024 01:50
806:

Thanks Robert!

I’ll be interested in what there’s have to say.

For what it’s worth, the conflict between authoritarian top-down power and democratic bottom-up power seems to be endemic in societies. They flip both ways, typically depending on how inept the regime is. This is why the current crop of authoritarians is so bent on destroying democratic institutions, of course.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Tier2Tech | June 17, 2024 02:07
809:

"255/55R18 (32-33psi) 165/80R17 (60psi)"

Cheers, those are recognisably familiar sorts of figures, and as well as that, the two different size/pressure pairs each make sense in the context of the other, so you could say the specification is automatically kind of self-checking, and it's reporting success.

And by a happy chance, the second one isn't much different from the tyres on my car pumped to twice the normal pressure, while the first one isn't much different from putting my car's normal pressure into twice as big a tyre, so my personal experience has a degree of real relevance, as an unexpected bonus.

So I can be usefully confident that I've more or less posted the right things already, but the two different tyres make a bit of an update necessary. You could, as an emergency last resort, successfully do either of them with an ordinary bicycle pump; but it's important to keep it internally lubricated with something formulated for the purpose, you would do well to have some spare adaptor tubes, and it is strictly an emergency measure because the pump might not survive well enough to be much good for anything in future, and you will feel like you haven't.

The first one is comfortably within the range of the ordinary kind of foot pump sold for blowing up car tyres, but you will have been glad to have paid some attention to things like ergonomics, efficiency and general constructional quality. The second one isn't (too much pressure); for that, I would go for the kind of pump which is a steel cylinder held vertically upright by a wide and sturdy baseplate on the floor, and operated either by a handle on top which you work up and down with both hands or a pedal on the side to work with your foot. That high pressure tyre is similar to an abnormally large motorcycle tyre, and this pump is basically a high-end motorcycle tyre pump as bought by people who naturally incline towards buying tools "of dependably high quality and if that also makes them expensive well so be it" (though I'm sure you can also get nastily shit ones that look the same, and with tools like this such things may quite well have a price deliberately based on the looks being deceptive, so do not even think about using price as a proxy indicator of quality). And such a pump will also be just as good for the other tyre.

With both of these and particularly the two-hands version, do physically check out how the dimensions match your body from an ergonomic point of view, especially the low end of the range of movement of the handle. You want to be able to comfortably get all the way to the low end, so it's natural for all your strokes to go all the way down, but you don't want to be finishing your strokes with your body having a goodly amount of shove left to give; for a start, you'll be hammering the piston into the bottom of the pump all the time, which is damaging to the pump and wasteful of your body's effectiveness (ie. you will end up a lot more knackered). You also want to be able to derive most of the downforce passively from your body weight, kind of leaning over it a bit and transmitting your weight to the handle by straight and vertical arms; obviously you can't do that for the whole stroke, so optimise your match on the basis that its importance becomes greater the closer you get to the end of the stroke. Inevitably there will be moments when you will accidentally go off centre and push the handle asymmetrically, which makes it try to bend sideways instead of going down, so pay attention to how the stem and its bushing in the end of the cylinder cope with this; you don't want to bend the stem or lever the thing sideways in the top of the pump body - with permanently destructive effects, and you don't really want it to keep going down but really stiffly, because (again) it's damaging to the pump and wasteful of your own input. Hard to describe because it's a "feel" thing, but you want to feel confident that you're not going to break or damage things (or feel like you are), and you want the physical feeling of getting it wrong to be a kind of feeling that encourages you to stop, reset, and try again, not a kind of feeling that encourages you to just shove a bit harder and carry on. (I find that pumps that respond badly in these terms are significantly more physically tiring to use, because I'm constantly worrying that an erroneous stroke is going to develop into fucking the pump catastrophically and I don't use my body properly because I'm concentrating too hard on not doing it.)

For the ergonomics of the foot-operated version there is already a lot of good advice all over the place, because the kind of leg movement you're trying to achieve is the same as the standard maximum-efficiency movement for a bicycle pedal - pressing with the ball of your foot, knee nearly but not quite straight at the bottom of the stroke, that one - just without the rotary motion. (There are people who seem to have a mission to stop people pedalling like that, but they are flat wrong, basically, and idiots.) So read the stuff about how best to set that up - height of arse in relation to limits of stroke, etc - and just ignore any bits that are clearly only about optimising the horizontal component of the rotary motion (there won't be a lot anyway).

As far as battery-powered electric pumps go, the only ones I've used have been the ones powered from the car's battery, and while they all claim capabilities that would see them doing three of either of those tyres in succession scratching their arse plus a couple extra while they're sniffing their finger, either the manufacturers have arrived at those figures in the same sort of way mobility scooter manufacturers arrive at a figure for maximum range*, or they are just plain telling lies and trusting to luck to avoid prosecution (sadly, they are probably OK doing that). In practice they might just handle the first one without overheating too much, if you're lucky, but for the second one just forget it. The maximum pressure they can achieve is about 40psi and they creeeeeep up to that groaningly slowly, with increasingly long and increasingly frequent periods of being switched off completely while they cool down, without which they will start blowing fuses or tripping breakers. Useless: avoid.

On the other hand David L says Makita make variants powered by their own rechargeable batteries, and going by the Makita gear I have used or owned, I feel safe just assuming that if Makita say it will handle it, then it will handle it, calmly and peacefully and without any fucking about.

(He also mentions Ryobi, but with Ryobi I feel safe in assuming that if Ryobi say it will handle it, it will get half way there and then spectacularly combust.)

*The manufacturer claims a range for my scooter of 40 miles, which is just so obviously not true it's silly. Looking at the other figures in the book, it's also dead obvious exactly how they've got it; they have done this:

The capacity of the scooter battery is 1kWh: that's the specified capacity figure for that battery in the manufacturer's catalogue.

The motor consumes 200W: that's the rated "power" figure quoted on the ratings plate.

Therefore the battery will run the motor for 1000/200 = 5 hours.

By law the maximum permitted speed for a scooter of this class is 8mph and it must be enforced by a speed limiter.

At 8mph, in 5 hours the scooter will travel 5*8 = 40 miles.

Therefore this scooter has a range of 40 miles.

And since all the figures we've used are the officially-stated standard figures for the quantities concerned, I can't see how Trading Standards can argue with that, right chaps?

Pigeon: Using the scooter entirely within all the officially stated permitted parameters, with a freshly fully charged new battery, I have driven it 2 miles and then reached so low a state of discharge that the scooter goes into fault lockout and will not move. Therefore your "range" figure all calculated from official figures has an observed maximum useful accuracy of 2/40 = 0.0005%.

 Pigeon replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 17, 2024 08:28
818:

"To make a phased array, you need to be able to control the phase for each transmitter individually."

That's a convenient method for things like radar antennas where the number of transmitters is small. What you're trying to achieve is the kind of variation over distance that image editing programs call a "gradient". When your spatial sampling is only a few pixels per unit of distance, as with a radar, individual control is as good as anything. If you're sampling at millions of pixels per unit of distance, mass control by some kind of field gradient method is what you want.

"As far as I know, nobody has even managed to control the frequency of two lasers well enough to generate an interference pattern between them, without intentionally or accidentally injection locking them."

That's a hoary old problem in radio terms and a standard teaching example. The pattern you're generating that way is not an "interference pattern" in the sense needed for a phased array, it's a beat pattern - a heterodyne, a frequency sum-and-difference signal. You pass two different frequencies through a non-linear mixer and you get the sum and difference of those frequencies as components of the output signal. Superhet radio receiver tuners vary in sychrony (mechanically, originally) the centre frequencies of two resonant circuits such that the frequency of one is always some given amount different from the other. One of these tunes the input signal and the other tunes a local oscillator. You then pass the signals from those two through a non-linear mixer and select the difference signal from the output, which is always at the same frequency: the heterodyne method produces a signal which is always at the same frequency no matter what the frequency of the station you're receiving is, other stations always come out at the same wrong frequencies, and now you tune the radio by matching the frequency to a fixed resonant circuit instead of matching a variable resonant circuit to the frequency. The fixed circuit is far easier to make and set up to rigid levels of sharpness and accuracy than a variable one is, so your ability to distinguish between different stations broadcasting on similar frequencies (selectivity) gets an important improvement.

Yes, certainly if the difference between the frequencies of two differently tuned oscillators is made too small in relation to the amount of mutual coupling that they have (never zero), they will lock together and both will operate at the same frequency. At radio frequencies this is tractable and it is trivial to set up an experimental lashup that lets you twiddle knobs and watch them ping in and out of lock as you vary frequencies and coupling factors. At optical frequencies it is not tractable so you don't use heterodyne methods to modulate a phased array.

"So never mind controlling the phase: We cannot even measure it (yet)."

You don't need to measure the phase in any direct sense, and you don't care about the absolute phase; what you want to do is control the relative phase, which is trivial. For instance/simple example, you can have two beams at the same frequency one of which passes through a crystal whose refractive index varies under an electric field. When it comes out the other end, having gone a wee bit slower for a small distance it will now be in a different phase relative to the unmodified beam. By varying the electric field you can vary how much slower it goes and thus vary the relative phase.

Then you can, for example, mix the two beams to produce your interference pattern, which will be spatially static. Therefore you know that any given point in space in the pattern will be at the same intensity for the same input beam power. You can monitor a suitable selection of these spots with photocells and use the output signal to modulate the electric field applied to the variable refractive index crystal, and then you adjust the various scaling factors in the feedback signal path such that the system automatically adjusts itself to produce whatever pattern you have set up. You don't need to "measure the phase" in any more direct sense than the system automatically self-adjusting to produce a correct output, which you can then analyse to see what the relative phase actually is if you still want to.

I've used a simple example to explain the basic principles. There are a whole raft of different methods that monitor and adjust different parameters in this kind of way, the actual principle remaining the same; it's a well-covered problem, and the main difference between a working explanatory example and a real application is that the real one would not be a lashup.

"Once we have figured out how to control the phase, we need to invent an optical "isolator" to prevent backscatter from the 3GW beam from injection-locking all the lasers."

No we don't. You just don't use methods that depend on avoiding mutual locking. Here we are using a method where having them all lock together is exactly what you need to happen, so it matches the situation perfectly.

"Now scale that up to hundreds of millions of individual laser sources."

Hundreds of millions of sources I have already assumed. They are not "individual sources" in the sense of being able to pick up single units one at a time and count them into a box, like you can with light bulbs. They are more like the "individual transistors" in an integrated circuit. (The whole thing is based around the methods we use today for making integrated circuits: methods which are more precise and controllable than anything else we do. We are already shit hot at them with silicon, we are remarkably good at them with some much more difficult materials, and we've been making demonstration models that work at the scale of individual atoms for decades.)

Nor are they individually controllable at the level of being able to use them to draw pixel patterns like a computer screen does.

"And even if you build your magic laser, that can do all that fancy stuff out of Handwavium-121, it is still not enough to launch it coherently, it must hit the sail coherently.

I know that; I said basically the same thing, expressed with a different focus of emphasis: if you are trying to make sure the beam gets to the other end in a coherent form, then launching a coherent beam in the first place has got to be a jolly good place to start.

I'm not addressing the problem of how to make the beam get all the way to the sail and be coherent when it hits: I know that that's a problem which involves far too many areas that I know more or less fuck all about, so I'm not going to bother with it (though if I spot some specific sub-point that only involves areas I do know about, I might chip in to talk exclusively about that one point).

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Pigeon | June 17, 2024 10:50
827:

»You don't need to measure the phase in any direct sense, and you don't care about the absolute phase; what you want to do is control the relative phase, which is trivial. For instance/simple example, you can have two beams at the same frequency one of which passes through a crystal whose refractive index varies under an electric field.«

As I said: We have yet to tune two lasers close enough in frequency to make fringes, so your "to beams of the same frequency" is a non-starter.

But assume we figure that out, then assume a solar sail 1000km(!) diameter where Voyager 1 is now (24.5e9km), this is just past the solar bow-wave and where we can seriously start to accelerate our probe.

Seen from the Sun that sail is 40 nano-radians wide - call it 0.0084" if that works better for you.

Next, assume one million 3kW transmitters, each one a square meter (very optimistic) and you have an antenna array 1200km in diameter.

Now you calculate the phase adjustment granularity you need on those lasers, to be able to position the beam in increments of 1/10th of the target = 4 nano-radians. Feel free to assume the antenna array is perfectly orthogonal to the target.

How far is that phase shift at the speed of light ?

And mind you, that is at the start of the acceleration phase, if you push the probe ten times further out, all those numbers get ten times worse.

Even if Handwavium-121 also solves all that, everybody assume interstellar space is empty.

Spoiler: It is not, so the larger the sail the larger the drag. At some point the probe will stop accelerating, because the drag on the sail balances the force imparted by the beam from back home.

Wanna guess how far out that is likely to happen and at what speed ?

Laser-sails are like nuclear power: A brilliant idea until you do the math.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Troutwaxer | June 17, 2024 12:27
829:

An RPi has a bunch of spurious peripherals. Do you really think an interstellar probe is going to have a 4-port USB-A layout USB 2 hub? Or even a regular layout RPi PCB complete with the GPIO header pins?

Look at modern chiplet technology, which mounts a bunch of tiny (single mm scale) sub-chips on an interposer inside a regular-looking package. Functions like a single insanely complex CPU (bearing in mind that CPUs these days may have tens of billions of transistors and internal buses, caches, MMUs, specialized GPUs, and a bunch of other stuff that used to be separate PCI card mounted peripherals).

The real problems are keeping the beam collimated and keeping the tiny probe's laser sail aligned with it and undegraded (bearing in mind it's being hit by gigawatts, this is a hard problem: any tiny imperfection and the whole thing is going to evaporate like a snowflake in hell).

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 17, 2024 12:54
830:

Note that the question is NOT how post-war Germany could have become Communist, but what would 1920s Communist Germany look like? Assume I waved a magic sickle and gave certain communists the brains they needed to win their revolution.

Okay.

To get a Communist Germany you need to not have a Communist Russia, but that's easy. Lenin's putsch barely happened -- and it wouldn't have happened if Trotsky, who was ill with flu at the time, had been too sick to get out of bed. (Lenin wouldn't move without T at his side.) Thereafter we handwave a successor to the Kerensky government, or maybe a Tsarist succession under Michael, or something.

You also need a decisive defeat on the Western Front that puts allied boots on the ground in Germany, to stomp the dolchstosslegende flat before it gets its jackboots on and goes marching. This nearly happened -- maybe someone slips Ludendorf some discovered-six-months-early crystal meth in August 2018 and he decides to go for broke and runs up against Plan 1919 (the Anglo-American plan for a spring offensive using what later became known as Blitzkrieg tactics).

You then send off to the alien space bats for a different ending to the German Revolution of 1918/19, which leaves Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht running the show (with the added legitimization of being able to say "I told you so" about the whole nationalist mess of the preceding five years).

--I am assuming a communist Germany would become authoritarian in due course, because that seems to be the way communism fails. Any reason not to assume this?

Yes: it depends on how addicted to Theory the revolutionary government is. There's a book urgently climbing my to-read pile called Late Soviet Britain: why materialist utopias fail, by LSE professor of political economy Abby Innes. She compares the eerie structural similarities between Soviet Communism and the past 50 years of neoliberalism in the UK, and points out that the UK was a one-doctrine state: since Thatcher, every government excepts as axiomatic truth a bunch of economic metaphors derived from 19th century physics and clearly unmoored from observable reality. Similarly, the USSR relied on fantasies of rational New Soviet Men and the perfectability of the state planning system (the equivalent in the UK is the self-interested, perfectly informed consumer and the perfection of the market as a system to mediate supply and demand).

Authoritarian personalities cleave to determined, firm, reductionist explanations for complex phenomena even when they're obviously not working, in the face of evidence to the contrary. This damaged the USSR (not so much under Lenin but under his successors after Stalin kicked out Trotsky and purged the Politburo), and it also damaged the UK (first by Thatcher expelling the "wets" from her own cabinet, then the increasingly unhinged insistence on privatizating anything and everything, cut-backs of any state agency that might interfere with the market, refusal to consider any solution to a problem that couldn't be framed favourably in terms of the prevailing doctrine, and so on). (Note for Greg, Pigeon, etc: this is why I'm so gloomy about Kier Starmer -- he's more of the same. At best he'll be the UK's Gorbachev -- too little, too late.)

Luxemburg in particular was a fierce intellectual and stood firm on principle -- so much so that she spent most of the war in prison for her internationalist, anti-war stance. She was a prisoner of conscience, and could well have gone the distance if she hadn't been murdered by Friekorps head-bangers -- think in terms of a Lech Walensa or Nelson Mandela figure. (I hesitate to say Aung San Suu Kyi because her history is very mixed indeed.)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from David L | June 17, 2024 13:03
831:

The NASA deep space network with its 3 earth sites is having trouble keeping up with data comm requirements now.

Did you see the streaming video from the last couple of SpaceX Starship test flights?

The obvious solution for coordinating lots of satellites in near-earth space is a constellation of high bandwidth comsats in LEO, which is exactly what SpaceX are using Starlink for in these flight tests. Currently it's to supplement the DSN, and Starlink as-is won't replace the DSN for long range comms any time soon, but something like it's n'th generation descendant -- in a very different bunch of orbits, too -- is exactly what we'd need to coordinate the platforms in a laser array out past lunar orbit.

(The key aspects of Starlink in this respect are (a) ion-propulsion active station keeping, (b) Starlink-to-Starlink laser communications to form a mesh network, (c) ability to transfer a connection between nodes (satellites) in the mesh because it's packet-switched. This is not your grandpa's Telstar, to put it mildly, and while all these things are finding their way into other comsats already, Starlink shows it working at scale for insanely high bandwidth -- streaming multiple 4K high-def video signals from a re-entering spaceship while avoiding its plasma wake, for example.)

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from David L | June 17, 2024 13:03
832:

It doesn't really matter what the form of the government has been, just that the society has preferred authoritarianism for 500 to 1000 years.

Talking about the spirit of a nation seems very appropriate for a century ago, but let’s put some mechanisms on that particular Ship of Theseus.

One is that the Soviets inherited much of the Tsarist bureaucracy, military, and intelligence service. Inherited, in this sense, meant they co-opted them during the Revolution and the Civil War that followed, then got stuck with those rather authoritarian institutions. Same thing happened when Russia took over from the USSR. That cultural continuity will last until those institutions get abolished and replaced with new ones with new personnel and new rules. Comparisons with the Chinese Mandate of Heaven (a story created by the bureaucrats to help them survive regime change) are rather apt.

Another is that the Russians around 400-500 years ago swiped a taxation scheme from the Mongols or their successors: create government-owned bars, tax each drink, and make it hard for the peasants to make their own beer and wine. It worked great as a way to raise revenue. Problem was, they couldn’t afford all the tax collectors or the bureaucracy to keep them honest, so they farmed out tax collection. The tax farmers bought permits and split the proceeds from their saloons with the state. Ripe for corruption begins to describe this situation, as does corrupt oligarch/aristocracy. And they settled on the cheapest, easiest, strongest alcohol they could produce: vodka. Corruption aside, vodka taxes paid for the Tsarist military for centuries. Encouraging alcoholism became a national duty. Starting in the 19th Century, Tsars, Stalin, and apparently even Putin all tried to change this system, but corruption and enforced complicity (we go sober and you lose your military) defeated all reforms. Typically the reformers ended up embracing the system, possibly in despair or tyrannical rage. I predict we’ll break America’s parallel addiction to oil before Russia stops taxing vodka, mostly because oil isn’t renewable.

Going back to a hypothetical German Communist state, one of the key questions is what the Commies would be forced to incorporate intact from the Kaiser. Probably the military, as happened with the Weimar Republic. But what about things like taxes, bureaucracy, and intelligence? This is a big part of the historical contingency issue we’re all wrestling with.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 17, 2024 13:16
833:

East Germany was profoundly shaped by WWII (and Stalinism and Nazism). I think it would have been quite different if established sooner.

Reminder that East Germany was never de-Nazified -- while the Soviets shot a lot of the senior Nazis, the low-level party members often just swapped armbands and joined the Communist Party. The Nazis made party membership compulsory for professionals, so short of shooting all the doctors and teachers and architects, what were the NKVD going to do?

In any case, the personality type of the low-level members -- authoritarian followers, per Altermeyer -- were broadly similar regardless of ideology. There's a maximum leader who tells us what to do, a bunch of slogans to memorize and repeat, this is what an Enemy of the Party looks like (and here's your hotline for reporting them), and so on.

So in some respects the GDR carried on just like the Third Reich. (In other respects, not so much.)

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 17, 2024 14:28
838:

My take is that Lenin was an intensely polarizing force in Russia, and without him there wouldn't have been a communist revolution there -- socialists, maybe, but willing to go into coalition with other parties.

And the Russian revolution is what sensitized the West to communism and led to eg. the Red Scare in the USA in 1920, British military aid to the White Russian side in the Civil War, the hard backlash against the communists in Germany after the 1918 revolution, and so on.

(The old monarchies were afraid that Communism would be, as you say, an Arab Spring, so violently suppressed it. Or rather, that it'd be a re-run of 1848, and maybe a dose of the Paris Commune on top.)

 Troutwaxer replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 17, 2024 15:54
851:

"Do you really think an interstellar probe is going to have a 4-port USB-A layout USB 2 hub?"

Obviously not. (Did you wake up on the wrong side of bed today?) A Raspberry PI just makes a useful starting point for thinking about size/weight issues. But imagine you need to defend a (much more sophisticated) board of that size/weight... the shielding alone for four lightyears of interstellar media plus radiation is prohibitive, much less the question of attaching a bunch of sensors which would actually be useful, or the necessary gear to navigate once the probe was actually in-system at Proxima Centauri, or a radio which would usefully send data back towards Earth.

Even if you accepted 1/10 G as reasonable acceleration and went to a kilogram you still wouldn't get anything useful to Proxima Centauri. You might do okay with 1/100 G and ten kilograms, but I'd have my doubts: How do you keep it from ablating, and how do you decelerate?

The expense of doing anything useful in interstellar space so utterly dwarfs the expense of building a telescope with a 1 kilometer mirror and simply pointing it at Proxima Centauri (then everything else you might want to look at) that you might as well howl at the moon.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from David L | June 17, 2024 16:14
854:

Women were frequently excluded from universities until the second half of this century -- pretty much universally excluded, before the second half of the 19th century. See for example Clara Immerwahr who became the first German woman to earn a PhD in Chemistry in 1900. She -- unwisely -- married Fritz Haber who wanted a barefoot-and-pregnant stay-at-home wife and claimed much of her research findings as his own; she shot herself in 1915, possibly in protest against the war. See also Mileva Marić, Albert Einstein's first wife and collaborator. (There was a longstanding and deplorable pattern of male researchers taking credit for their wives' work.)

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from JohnS | June 17, 2024 16:59
858:

Yeah, sorry about the typos.

The point about something like 'Oumuamua is that it most likely got ejected from a stellar system at some point, and has been orbiting the galactic center ever since. If you're doing paranoid basic security on an interstellar probe, you don't want anything about it to lead back to its origin. So don't travel in a straight line (kink the trajectory when entering the target system, don't decelerate with something insanely noticeable like an Amat or fusion torch, or a big solar sail, look like a piece of interstellar junk*, don't loudly livecast from the target system, and if under detectable surveillance, act like a piece of interstellar junk, which means kinking the arrival vector into a hyperbolic escape path that will passively take around the star and out without any active thrust being necessary.

Now, it's also possible to have the above be the mother ship, and have it eject a loud, noisy probe to attract attention, while the mother probe coasts through, collects the output data, and escapes with it as necessary.

*One important thing about space junk like 'Oumuamua--it survived who knows how many eons between the stars. Modeling the cladding of an interstellar vehicle on materials like that is not a bad idea, simply because we know it can survive.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 17, 2024 17:18
861:

Women were frequently excluded from universities until the second half of this century -- pretty much universally excluded, before the second half of the 19th century.

Apropos of that, may I recommend Shohini Ghose's book Her Space, Her Time?

Dr. Ghose is an excellent writer. (Not to mention an engaging speaker and fascinating conversationalist: if you get live near Waterloo grab any chance you can to go to one of her public lectures. She was the person who first explained quantum physics in a way I could actually understand.)

Women physicists and astronomers from around the world have transformed science and society, but the critical roles they played in their fields are not always well-sung. Her Space, Her Time, authored by award-winning quantum physicist Shohini Ghose, brings together the stories of these remarkable women to celebrate their indelible scientific contributions.

In each chapter of the book, Ghose explores a scientific topic and explains how the women featured in that chapter revolutionized that area of physics and astronomy. In doing so, she also addresses particular aspects of women's experiences in physics and astronomy: in the chapter on time, for instance, we learn of Henrietta Leavitt and Margaret Burbidge, who helped discover the big bang and the cosmic calendar; in the chapter on space exploration, we learn of Anigaduwagi (Cherokee) aerospace scientist Mary Golda Ross, who helped make the Moon landings possible; and in the chapter on subatomic particles, we learn of Marietta Blau, Hertha Wambacher, and Bibha Chowdhuri, who contributed to the discovery of the building blocks of the universe, and, in doing so, played a crucial role in determining who gets to do physics today.

https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262048316/her-space-her-time/


Also, if anyone has Apple TV and has watched Lessons in Chemistry I'd welcome their take on it. I have it in my 'watch next' queue, but watching TV isn't really my thing so I haven't got to it yet. I haven't read the book it's based on.

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt13911628/

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from JohnS | June 17, 2024 22:22
878:

»What were the educational opportunities for German women in the immediate post-WW1 period?«

In most of northern Europe women were allowed to attend university, or pretty much any other education, if they had the resources to do so, but they could not sit the exams. Having attended for instance math at university, even without the exam, opened job opportunities where those skills were valuable.

Sigh. More Torment Nexus time.

Here's a modest proposition for a MilSF/Horror mashup.

Background: We all know that nuclear war is a no-win situation, and we're stuck with Mutually Assured Destruction. However, so long as nuclear war doesn't happen, it's not so bad.

That's not true with conventional war, which is petrochemical-powered. If we fight an all-out conventional war, everybody loses: it's Gaza, Ukraine, and/or Sudan and Ethiopia on a global scale. However, if we don't fight, everybody still loses, because the US DoD and its foul step-siblings are the biggest single sources of GHGs on the planet, more so when you count in their symbiotes in the Military Industrial Complexes.

So we need a less ruinous alternative to conventional or nuclear war.

THE FOUL PLOT NOTION: somewhere in some Red State, a MAGAt's beautiful daughter is in despair. She's suffering through another hellish heat wave, she knows it's only going to get worse, she's read her Bible and knows her Prosperity Gospel 'rents are buying a load of bilge that's closer to what Satan tempted Christ with than what Jesus actually preached. Worse, her dad's red-pilled to the gills, collecting guns and preparing to arm his own Brigade when Civil War 2.0 turns violent. And he obviously wants her married off young, serially pregnant and working two jobs to support some good-for-nothing wannabe Johnny Reb she once had a fleeting crush on.

So she creates a suicide note video, posts it, and kills herself with daddy's favorite gun.

And the video goes viral, the more so as well-meaning authorities try to suppress it. The wave of copycats and Romeo and Juliet spinoffs is terrifying to watch.

Now the MilSF kicks in. Enemies of the US see this viral meme and use AI to weaponize it against their greatest foe. Not only do they pump the meme, they push hard to increase division, using all the new buzzword-y tech to make anyone with a gun think they're in the End Times and it's time to kill thy meme-infected neighbor-zombie, before their memes infect you or your children. These enemies include both nation states and their transactional allies among the super-rich.

The US and allies see what's happening and return fire, pumping up the AI jam to encourage suicide by multi-drug cocktail in Russia, literal ghosting in China, and so forth.

Pretty soon, WW3 rages, entirely online, as all sides work harder and harder to get their foes to kill themselves. And so humans find a more environmental way to wage total war on each other.

OBVIOUSLY, this story is a horror story about the dangers of social media and propaganda. But, like the torment nexus, what do you think people will take away from it?

Terrifying, no? Might even be an award-worthy story. Maybe even...a profitable one?

 darkblue | June 19, 2024 06:49
952:

With regard to light sails...

My understanding is that light sails work by transfer of momentum from the light photons to the sail. There's no requirement for the light to be coherent, so no need to worry about phase alignment of multiple light sources. The only reason for proposing lasers as the light source is that they are good a generating a well-collimated beam that spreads very little, such that most of the light gets to where is is pointed, instead of being wasted illuminating the surrounding empty space.

The sun does not generate coherent light, but it's an adequate source of light to drive a light sail.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from darkblue | June 19, 2024 07:47
955:

Even if we drop the requirement that the light be coherent when it hits the sail, you still need to hit a 40 nano-radians wide target, and only phased-array methods stands /any/ chance of doing that, so coherence is not optional.

Some of the best collimated lasers in existence are used as Laser Guide Stars in large astronomical telescopes, and while most of the dispersion in that application comes from the atmosphere, they work hard to reduce the contribution from the launch optics, but they are nowhere near nano-radians.

 Moz replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 19, 2024 08:09
957:

I thought the broader/less complex option was a bigger mirror array with a bigger beam? If you're basically building a parabola with the star at the focus you can afford to have 99.99% of the beam miss the target because you've got a ring of "big dumb mirrors" orbiting the star as close as they can tolerate with the orbital plane at right angles to your proposed exit course giving rather a lot of radiation heading vaguely in the right direction.

You wouldn't want to do this around our star, obviously, because any number of "minor" problems could cause the beam(s) to intersect stuff you care about. It might be only 1000 suns worth, and only for a couple of hours, but it's still going to be a be tricky to explain to Australia is on fire now that you're really sorry.

Another advantage of that is that you can keep building mirrors after you leave, so your beam drops off with distance but not as fast as you'd expect due to there being more of it as time goes by.

 icehawk | June 19, 2024 10:43
960:

"There's a current fuss in academics teaching CS about how current/new students fundamentally don't understand directory structures, or computers in general "

Its not obvious to me that using a computer teaches you how they work, any more than flying in an airplane teaches you how they work. And the more advanced the airplane, the less you see about how it works.

Back when I learned about computers, I was told (and believed) that a program was executing an algorithm one step at at time. That's only kind-of true, but it's a very useful simplification, and it certainly seemed true as I'd run various little things from the command line to do stuff .

But that is not the experience kids have of dealing with computing devices. Computers for them are interactive and reactive in ways that don't make "an algorithm is computing a function" an obvious model, and processing occurs in parallel at many levels. It's not clear to a user where webpages stop being 'pages' and start being 'apps', and many apps deliberately try to hide from them when their data is local or not.

Concepts like interrupts, threading and networking used to be segregated off as separate things to do late in one's degree after you'd mastered writing a single-threaded program computing an algorithm. These days I'm seeing event-driven programming taught earlier because that's a model kids understand, and frankly I've no idea how you teach threading in the modern age of MapReduce.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from JohnS | June 19, 2024 11:04
962:

Two questions about using a "Laser sail" to return a probe: Who's going to manufacture a sail for the probe at the far end? Where are the lasers to power the sail going to come from?

In theory you can use staged sails. That is: you accelerate your probe using sail 1. Nearing the destination, your probe drops sail 1 and it's control mechanism, and unfurls sail 2. The launch laser then fires up again. Sail 1 has to ride the beam, accelerating past the target, and meanwhile reflects the light back at sail 2, which is used for retropropulsion to allow the (now lighter) probe to decelerate towards the target. Like a Cassegrain reflector, only with light sails.

For real shits'n'giggles you pack a couple more light sails to use for the return trip.

Of course, the precision aiming required for even the 2-sail deceleration stunt at interstellar distances is insane ...

 Moz replied to this comment from icehawk | June 19, 2024 11:40
966:

It's less MapReduce and more async, I think. It seems to be slightly easier to teach kids that "set off a chain of things then wait for them to finish" and just make them use thread-safe containers/queues etc, at least these days where lots of cores is the answer to everything. But the other 99% of code is just psuedo-async event driven stuff where no-one really cares anyway. You write an event handler, all your state is a local copy, so you write single-threaded code and it works. Mostly.

Admittedly I deal with mechatronics kids more than CS, and the ones we get have usually done a bit of RTOS stuff so are at least aware of interrupts etc. But these days even tiny embedded stuff has multiple cores, including the secure enclave, and there are libraries for bloody everything if you have the memory+storage for them (tick a few boxes and watch your executable grow from 100kB to 4MB!) So it's very easy to say "the dedicated encryption core does DTLS handling so we just treat everything as UDP" and then "normal interrupts are handled by the spare core" and it's not your grandparent's RTOS any more.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from icehawk | June 19, 2024 12:29
974:

Its not obvious to me that using a computer teaches you how they work, any more than flying in an airplane teaches you how they work

Correct, but modern computing devices hide the core functionality with multiple layers of abstraction -- I think we add maybe one abstract level per decade?

Being a passenger in a Boeing won't teach you how airplanes work, but learning to fly a hang glider will definitely get you up close and personal with the basics of aerodynamics, and being a passenger in a two-person microlight (basically a motorized hang glider) is a lot closer to the flight surfaces than that airliner I aluded to.

If you learned how to use a computer in the 1970s or earlier, or even in the first half of the 1980s, you probably had to grapple with filesystems and a REPL stack of some kind (even if it was only Microsoft BASIC) at a level alien to pretty much anyone who isn't a developer these days.

 Poul-Henning Kamp | June 19, 2024 12:53
976:

The place I see this difference in depth of understanding most is debugging.

There are basically two ways to debug:

A) Slog through a detailed trace of everything which happens, spot the first time things go wrong.

This sounds menial, and it is, but the "spot the first time things go wrong" is non trivial and almost always requires multiple iterations before the true first time is identified.

Almost all developers can do A, but it can quite literally take months for them.

B) Formulate a likely hypothesis, test it with experiment or inspection, repeat until success.

Good developers can do B, and the better they understand the situation, the better they are at coming up with hypotheses which bring them closer to the answer.

I used to think that people got better at B as a result of experience, and they do, to some extent.

But OGH's observation about having started early, I would say before 1990, makes you "computer-hipster" and understanding the more "primitive" levels of the computer really inspires creativity in the "what could go wrong here" stage.

My own personal "secret weapon" I call "the PHK-test", where I ask myself: If I had to implement this behavior, how would I do it?

 JohnS replied to this comment from David L | June 19, 2024 18:41

David L @ 1002:

Don't your electoral districts have the same population? In Canada we have a few ridings with significantly less population than the rest

Within each state equal population yes. But districts have to exist in one state so there is some fuzziness between Wyoming's single district and California's 50 or so. But still here in North Carolina we are a 50/50 (well 50.2/49.8 both ways depending). There is no rational looking map that gives our 13 Congressional districts anywhere near a 50/50 split that doesn't meet the standards of being Gerrymandered. Our D's and lean D's are mostly in the 2 major urban areas and a few smaller cities. And the R's and lean R's are mostly in the rural areas. So for our delegations to Congress to come out even you have to split out cities up and tie them to rural areas 100 or more miles away. So both parties go all out depending on who controls the legislature. I think that NC has the most redistricting lawsuits filed in the last 40-50 years of any state. The D's had a district drawn 20 years ago that had PARTS of two mid sized cities tied together via a 50 miles stretch of highway median.

The way it should be done is start in the North East of the state (Currituck County) and start adding precincts along the edge until you get a population of 745,671 (more or less)1 and don't consider party. That's the 1st District. Do the same to create the next 13 Districts ending with District 14 (Cherokee County).

That gives 14 geographically "contiguous and compact" districts. The Interim Congressional District map imposed by the State Supreme Court actually comes close.

Do the state House & Senate districts the same way and let the chips fall where they will.

But so long as ANY political party controls the Legislature they're gonna' try to Gerrymander as much as they can get away with.

1 North Carolina population in the 2020 Census was 10,439,388 which gives us 14 seats in the House - dividing 10,439,388 by 14 gives 745,670.57 persons per House district.

 whitroth replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 19, 2024 19:03
1031:

Um, nope. Allow me to offer a third.

Back when I was with Ameritech, two of the young contractors came to me - I was the "senior resource" - with an issue: the library kept crashing in the linked-in third party library, and they didn't know why.

I attached the Sun debugger to it while it was running, then did something they'd never known: I used the "s" command to step into the linked in library. Then I used "next" to go through until it crashed. Then I stepped into the function that it was crashing in, until it crashed.

Now, I didn't know Sun's assembly language, but I'd had assembly (IBM BAL), and could see it was moving some data into a location. Then I, having the authority, could email the third party (Tuxedo, by BEA), and tell their developers that it was crashing in function MyName, around so many instruction in, moving data to x.

They got back to me that day, to tell me an environment variable wasn't set.

So, not a trace, but focus in on where its crashing, then figure out why. Far less tedious.

 JHomes replied to this comment from Greg Tingey | June 20, 2024 10:10
1054:

'Anarcho-captilasim is not "Anarchy" ( is it? )'

IMHO anarcho-capitalism is pretty much a contradiction in terms.

Capitalism is based on owning things, which means that there has to be some way to decide who owns what, and to sort out disputes thereof. Experience suggests that just hoping that everyone will spontaneously agree on it just does not work. They don't.

So, we need a mechanism for deciding questions about ownership, and some kind of institution to implement that mechanism. Such an institution is (part of) a government, like it or not, simply by virtue of what it does.

So much for the anarcho- part.

JHomes

It's fairly commonly accepted that libertarians and so on are only loosely anarchists*. Similar to "democratic capitalists" being not very democratic. One theory I've heard is that capitalism is based on the free exchange of value. Anarchism, in other words. This is where you get ideals like free markets, freedom from unnessary taxation and regulation, right of free association and so on.

The essence of anarchist organising is voluntary cooperation. Non-coercion. Consensus. Whatever you want to call it.

So anarchy includes such movements as the Presbyterian Church, the Rural Fire Service in Australia, and SF fandom. Not to mention Aotearoa's ideals of kotahitanga in contrst with kīngitanga. At the heart of most volunteer groups is a whole lot of anarchist politics. As soon as you can't coerce people to join your group and contribute to it you have to start using consensus and persuasion.

 Heteromeles | June 20, 2024 17:21
1065:

Re:Anarcho-statism

The Pedant on ACOUP is going into how they think Celtic society worked right now. It’s relevant to this discussion. Here’s part 2: https://acoup.blog/2024/06/14/collections-how-to-raise-a-tribal-army-in-pre-roman-europe-part-ii-government-without-states/

A couple of basic points. One is that a state is a society where the government, in whatever form, claims and enforces a monopoly on the use of force, in both what we’d call policing and military roles. It’s not a subtle difference, either.

The opposite is what the academics call non-state, which is a society in which the central government, whether it exists or not, neither has nor claims a monopoly on the use of force. In the Celtic example, Big Men (as Bret calls them so you don’t think of them as feudal nobles) tend to raise and support war bands through familial, patronage, and customary relationships, and they have to have arms and the skill to use them to do so.

I’d argue three things: one is that it’s entirely possible to hav an anarchist non-state, but I doubt it’s possible to have an anarchist state, precisely because of that monopoly on the use of force thing. How you put violent people under state discipline to obey orders, while simultaneously letting them be equal governors of their free actions, is a hard needle to thread.

The other, as Bret points out, is that there are a lot of similarities between how a Gallic Civitates is organized and how Rome is organized, with councils of elders, elected magistrates, and the like. Thing is, Rome was a state, while the Celtic societies were not. As a result, Rome could scale up the violence to a degree that ultimately none of the Celtic non-state societies could match. That’s a problem with non-state societies in general. So if you can’t figure out how to create a viable anarchist state, whatever you do create will likely get pounded by a state, simply because their violence is an organized monopoly, not a pick-up team of whoever shows up.

One problem we have today is that many corporations are as big as nation-states, and within themselves, their management has a monopoly on the use of coercion if not lethal violence. One of the big problems we have is that these state-scale corporations overlap with traditional nation-states, and I suspect this is where a lot of the anarchy-capitalist ideas are coming from. Sorting out complicated and competing loyalties and power structures is a very different problem from figure out which ideology is best.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Moz | June 22, 2024 14:04
1159:

There's people involved, nothing is straightforward or simple.

We can start with the old book

No, that's not where it starts.

The commandments were a collation of the high points of a whole bunch of laws (per Orthodox Jewish doctrine there are 617 in total) drawn from an oral tradition descended from a polytheistic religion (Yahweh was king of the gods and thunderbolt-thrower-in-chief, a semitic counterpart of Zeus).

A lot later the laws got written down and transmogrified during a mass migration process and at least one language shift -- by the time the earliest written copies of clearly rabbinic descent get to us the patriarchal monotheists had buried the other gods and goddesses (but not completely: hints at Yahweh's wife Asherah, queen of the gods, remain buried in the text) and switched to Aramaic as the written language.

The Christian bits (originally a bunch of heretical Jewish variants of Pharisaic origin) got translated into Greek, then Latin, and the bit the Screaming Jesus People cleave to is a fourth or fifth generation translation into 17th century English (which is not semantically identical to modern English) then bodged around by other sects and cults.

Some of the English translation bits are highly dubious, too. For example: "thou shalt not covet thy neighbours ox, nor his ass, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant ..." is basically wall-to-wall euphemism. It almost certainly started out as "don't get grabby about your neighbour's chattels", bearing in mind that "chattel" has the same semantic root as "cattle" -- the manservant and maidservant are slaves, livestock-that-talks.

And the first commandment ("I am the lord thy god, and thou shalt have no other gods before me") -- that is a dead giveaway that this is a patriarchal cult asserting primacy and dominance over a previously polytheistic polity.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 22, 2024 14:15
1160:

because there's nothing glamourous in successful investigations leading to arrests of scammers... whereas drug busts

It's not glamour, it's ease of raising your performance metrics.

Most drug busts are of users or low-level dealers: the latters tend to be only marginally competent and, faced with a long sentence, can be induced to give away their supplier. That, or they observe poor COMSEC and once in possession of an unlocked phone -- even a burner -- and a subpoena for the phone company, the cops can roll up the chain (at least until they run into a semi-clueful wholesaler). Who can then be offered a plea deal in return for their entire address book of customers. Etc.

Scammers ... there's usually no chain to roll up, so at best, you get one scammer. If they're smart, they're running the op through an offshore call-centre, which makes getting your hands on them a job for INTERPOL and the FBI or equivalent, which is heavy lifting (the FBI are generally more interested in terrorists and serial killers). There's no industrial supply chain for scams, so it's an endless chore -- you can't hope to eventually nail El Chapo or Al Capone. Finally, the most effective scams are high value creative one-offs, such as arbitrage hacks that boost the value of some commodity in a manner that doesn't fall foul of SEC intervention.

 JohnS replied to this comment from David L | June 22, 2024 21:19
1180:

David L @ 1176:

There are government forms in the US which still have to be filled out by a typewriter. Makes for fun times when the need occurs without expectation.

When we first started getting computers in the National Guard, the Army still had a lot of those forms. We had a program just for filling out forms, and an IBM Selectric typewriter with a Centronics port. You could tell the program which type ball was installed on the typewriter so it could tab over correctly to fit text into the blocks on the form.

The program had a "mail merge" function so you could do things like update the SGLI elections for the whole unit all at once (printing new forms for service members to sign was an annual pre-mobilization requirement).

Unless something like Desert Storm or Iraqi Freedom/GWOT came along the likelihood of being mobilized was pretty low, but the paperwork had to be updated annually

... and then when mobilization finally DID come it all had to be updated again anyway.

SGLI = Service-member's Group Life Insurance

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 22, 2024 21:21
1181:

There are a couple of football stadia in my city. With capacity up to 65,000 fans, it is normal to expect 0.5 deaths and a couple of heart attacks at every major soccer match. And that's in just a 90 minute fixture (plus penalty time and time to get in/out of the grounds).

1.8 million people undertake the Hajj, which takes 6 days. Assuming a life expectancy of 80 years, and an average probability of death, you expect a roughly 1/5000 probability of any given pilgrim dying during that week. (Obviously the very elderly and very young are more vulnerable but they're also less likely to be on the Hajj at such ages.)

So I'd expect roughly 300-400 deaths during the Hajj in any year with that many pilgrims.

This year's death toll is higher than that, but you've got extreme weather combined with an ongoing COVID19 pandemic that causes a higher probability of cardiovascular accidents (stroke or heart attack) in the 3-6 months after infection.

TLDR: this is being blown out of proportion by the press.

 Bobh replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 22, 2024 22:16
1183:

1159 "nothing is straightforward or simple."

I can speak somewhat to the early Xn part. Long time ago (1970's) my wife was on the road to being a biblical scholar. Convoluted ain't the word. Jesus likely existed and got executed by the Romans for being an agitator. Like many Jews, he thought the end of the Roman dominated world was coming. There are stories incorporating his sayings, but nothing was written until 20/30 years after he died, and not by any eyewitness. Nobody KNOWS what he said or what really happened.

His body seems to have disappeared, but a few followers claimed to have seen him after he died. So, God MUST have raised him from the dead! What started as a reform sect akin to the pharisees gradually separated from mainstream Judaism. Their take: Jesus got executed instead of leading an army, and who believes he rose from the dead?  JohnS replied to this comment from Bobh | June 22, 2024 23:40
1187:

Bobh @ 1183:

"1159 "nothing is straightforward or simple.""

I can speak somewhat to the early Xn part. Long time ago (1970's) my wife was on the road to being a biblical scholar. Convoluted ain't the word. Jesus likely existed and got executed by the Romans for being an agitator. Like many Jews, he thought the end of the Roman dominated world was coming. There are stories incorporating his sayings, but nothing was written until 20/30 years after he died, and not by any eyewitness. Nobody KNOWS what he said or what really happened.

The gospels, written about 10 years apart become more into Jesus being godlike until he became god, and more hostile to mainline Jews, who eventually got labelled God killers. (A scholar named Bart Ehrman covers this pretty well https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yte-ad6Y31s. )

Paul appears to have started writing his epistles to the various christian communities in Asia Minor, Greece & Rome starting about 20 years after the execution of Jesus.

The canonical gospels appear to have been written between 30 and 70 years after his execution - written down just about the time the generation who had actually known Jesus or listened to his teaching would have been dying out ... including Paul who was a later convert and hadn't actually ever known Jesus*.

So Paul's epistles appear to predate the canonical gospels.

The New Testament appears to have been assembled in its current form in approximately 390 CE (late 4th Century). Those "early" writings underwent A LOT of revisions in the 300+ years between.

* Best guess is Jesus would have been about 10 years old when Paul was born in Tarsus. His Jewish name was Saul, but as a Roman citizen "Saul" also had a Roman Name - Paul. Saul/Paul would have been about 25 when Jesus was executed.

Anyway, to answer your and Greg's points, pantheism is more Stranger in a Strange Land. "Thou are God." "I know, what isn't?"

AIUI, the Trinity is a weird half-compromise with that. It's three examples of general cases of what humans worship: Jehovah kind of cognate with both Jupiter and Zeus as a (symbolic) deity, whose correct worship is more important to belonging to a group than belief. Jesus is the righteous human teacher worshiped by his followers (see also Buddha). And the Holy Ghost is the Spirit That Moves All Things in New Age usage, but basically He(?) is that spark of the divine in everything that causes miracles and other strange things. Or Buddha Nature. Or the Tao, kind of.

A pantheist might say, basically "Yup, those are all examples of the divine at work in the world," and structure their spiritual practice around that. But in Christianity, only the class examples are considered divine, and nothing else in the classes is. Probably a theologian can tell me what's unchristian about what I just wrote, but that's my understanding of it at the moment.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Bobh | June 23, 2024 15:12
1211:

I can speak somewhat to the early Xn part. Long time ago (1970's) my wife was on the road to being a biblical scholar. Convoluted ain't the word.

I'm glad you brought this up.

I've seen interviews with Elaine Pagels, and I'm glad she's speaking out, for all the good it's doing.

One thing I'd add is that we know as much about Jesus as we do about Zoroaster, Lao Tzu, Buddha, Abraham, and Moses, among others. It's a pattern, but an important one.

It's said that humans learn through stories, and more generally through art. So if you want something remembered, embed it in a memorable story or something similar. I suspect that's what we're seeing at play here: if you want something remembered, embed it in a good story. The strict truth might actually get in the way of the initial learning.

This, of course, causes problems. One huge one is that people are better at creating stories than they are at understanding complex subjects, so over time the proliferation of misunderstandings and bullshit tends to drown out any useful message.

One current example is the Louisiana attention grab with the Ten Commandments thing. As others have pointed out, if they'd really wanted to be Christian, they'd be publishing the Golden Rule and the Beatitudes, not eleven of Moses' Ten Commandments. But most Christians can't recite all nine of the Beatitudes, and probably a bunch who label themselves as Christian would think they were weird and Unchristian if they actually read them carefully. The bullshit has drowned out the teaching they're notionally pushing.

Another problem is embodied in the "Don't create the torment nexus" meme. And for SFF, this is a really important point: stories really help people learn and remember things. So if you want to propagate the Torment Nexus, one of the best ways to do so is to write a story about it. The concept will stick better than the subtleties of the story will.

It's been showing 90°F (32.22°C) all of last week (around this time of day), but it was still pleasant outside - I think because the humidity was fairly low (~40%) ... but for some reason it feels a lot more oppressive outside today.

I'm about 10 miles NE of where I used to live in downtown Raleigh, with a fairly well shaded back yard. Local weather reports say it's about 93°F with 44% humidity, so I don't know why it feels so much hotter out there today?

* I've experienced a lot worse, so it's kind of relative. Not complaining, just noting I've been reading about the "heat wave" for the last week or so, but not feeling it around here.
