 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Dramlin | June 24, 2024 00:35
1229:

"You can even combine the two and ask how it is that Dreaming cultures didn't spread across the whole planet but capitalist ones metastised like fucking cancer?"...If we could answer that question maybe we could work out how to eradicate the cancer... I suspect there were a lot more Dreaming type cultures but, as you said, swallowed up by the people who felt the need to show everyone they knew the One Truth sigh.

I think you've got it backwards, but don't worry about it.

First, I'll give credit to the Aboriginals, in that "Dreaming" is a bunch of different practices, and it's all been termed "Dreaming" because that's what immigrant Aussies could get their heads around. Critical point here is that not all aborigines practiced precisely the same set of skills. Globally, there's documentation for Dreaming-type skills from every continent.

Second, people spontaneously reinvent Dreaming techniques like songlines. So-called eidetic memory, at least in some cases investigated, seems to be Dreaming techniques spontaneously reinvented, at least for those who aren't savants. Songlining in a nutshell is combining our spatial memories, our memories for songs, dances, stories and art, and our memories for objects, in order to remember information.

Third, Dreaming probably is the default for how humans retain information in the absence of writing. Given that it uses whole landscapes, it works best at low population density. Lynne Kelly made a good case that megaliths, like Stonehenge, are mnemonic devices that come into play as populations get denser, and people no longer can use long treks between sacred sites (e.g. good water wells and campsites) to remember things. So they set up permanent shrines, then temples, then architecture, and use rituals within the space to take the place of long treks. Writing doesn't become the default information storage device until the printing press means its hugely available and cheap.

So why did some societies stay at low densities and keep the Dreaming? My guess is that basically they lived in areas that couldn't support the high population densities that forced people into the endless compromises that we call civilization. Resource abundance can be a curse sometimes.

The good news, if you're into the Dreaming, is that we seem to be hell-bent on crashing civilization. If this happens, the survivors will have learned to rely on their memories and not computers or books. Sucks for a hyper-literate person like myself, but it might be what it might be.

As a side note, the Medieval European version of Dreaming seems to have ended up as the basis for Renaissance ceremonial magic. If you really want to get twee, you can prepare children for their post-crash survival by, perhaps, getting a copy of Lynne Kelly's (https://www.lynnekelly.com.au/ ) Memory Craft, learning some of the skills, then teaching those skills to kids under the guise of teaching them the secret family magic tradition. You can even use graded initiations to set up a curriculum for learning techniques, to assuage parental fears that you're corrupting their kittle lids. Dr. Kelly goes into medieval mnemonic devices, and if you ever played D&D, they might ring a few bells.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Moz | June 24, 2024 01:30
1232:

High populations and resources: Let's compare modern countries. I like to compare Australia and Mexico, because they're in the same size range, the same latitude range, and neither was particularly tied to Eurasia until after 1492 (yes, I know the Australians weren't totally isolated. Go with it).

Anyway, currently, Mexico has a population of almost 129.9 million people, Australia has pushing 27.3 million people.

Since both places have a history of people domesticating plants and landscapes, and Australia was settled long before the Americas, I'd gently suggest that the difference isn't because Aborigines are stupid or primitive, it's because Australia has some of the poorest soils on the planet. Seriously, your soil scientists had to invent your own soil system because what you consider decent agricultural soil people in the US think of as unfarmable--although we're trying to turn our good soil into stuff you'd recognize, because we're that kind of stupid. Mexico , in contrast, is geologically young (Ca. 5-10 million years IIRC), geologically active, and has or had some really amazingly good weathered volcanic soils.

Anyway, the biggest pre-Contact Aboriginal settlement that I know of was on order of 500-1000 people, and I think it was inhabited seasonally for harvesting farmed eels? Meanwhile, Tenochtitlan, the Aztec capital, had a population in excess of 100,000, even though they were only starting to get into metallurgy thanks to contacts with the mad stone-cookers of South America who sailed balsa rafts up the coast to trade with them for centuries and teach them a few tricks. It's not really about technological superiority (both were technically stone age), it's about who could feed 100,000 people and who could feed 1,000, because of where they lived, not who they are.

So this isn't a criticism of Aborigines, just a comparison. Just as one tends to find really long-lived plants and animals in really marginal places (like the bristlecone pines in the White Mountains, or Greenland sharks in the Arctic deep water), I'm beginning to suspect that we find really sustainable societies in really marginal landscapes, like Australia or pre-Contact California. It's a good enough pattern that I think it's really worth thinking about as we look at our future, in SFF or otherwise. Civilization as we know it pretty much requires abundance, and the only way we're going to keep civilization around is to keep the abundance. Since we're running out of high grade natural resources for just about everything, we're either going to crash, or we're going to make abundant reuse of all the garbage we've generated. Hopefully we'll have enough energy remaining for the latter. And so it goes.

Ranching kangaroos is hard because they're very mobile and they don't understand fences (except in that 'things to pass over' that seagulls also understand fences). I understand that herding them is also difficult.

Ah, yes, Yahweh's wife. Of course, in modern usage, that suggests him on top. And God's pronouns...

There's a book I would strongly recommend: The Hebrew Goddess, by Rafael Patai, Wayne State Univ Press. Originally published in 1963. (Yes, I own a copy).

Let's start out with him noting that in Genesis, with God "brooding over the waters", is not mulling it over, but the word used is the same one as a hen brooding over her eggs.

 ilya187 replied to this comment from whitroth | June 24, 2024 21:51
1265:

crucifixion was NOT a punishment for "theives", it was reserved for treason against Rome. Which means that the two "thieves" were rather Zealots (terrorists in that part of the world? Noooo....). So the "King of the Jews" suggests that he was convicted of treason, as a leader of the Zealots.

AFAIK, Romans saw no distinction between an armed rebel and an armed bandit -- both were crucified. They did have a distinction between a bandit and a thief -- if you only stole without violence, you could count on being merely hanged, -- but as soon as you spilled blood, you were bound for the cross.

So it is entirely possible that the "thieves" crucified alongside Christ were self-serving bandits rather than ideological rebels.

I have a financially successful friend who is a distributor of bottled wolf urine (yes really). One assumes that in that particular industry sales is a much safer gig than harvesting. It is a real time saver to buy bulk rather than collect your own, as wolves are fast runners and a little bitey.

I have dealt with the deer in our neighbourhood by building a 6-foot fence with 8 foot poles. I strung some thin wire at 6-inch intervals above the top of the 'fence'.  Damian replied to this comment from David L | June 25, 2024 06:29

I will usually still happily mow on days up to around 38ºC. You have to make sure to remember to drink enough water. But that's part of living with the climate, and not really anything all that special (we talk about extreme heat waves here when it's more like 40ºC). Inversely, the outdoor restaurants here put the space heaters on when it drops below 20ºC.

So yes, while I completely appreciate things are different and there are real built environment factors at play, I still find it a challenge to see 23ºC as hot. I think there a lot elided over when simply talking about what people are used to, some of it probably cultural. The weight of clothes, and especially clothing that breathes versus clothing that blocks the wind, number of layers considered normal or even respectable, social markers associated with that, etc. It's been a relatively cool winter for Brisbane, I found myself buying a new jumper (aka sweater for the North Americans) for early morning walks. The thing is it's too hot to wear during the day when the sun's out and it gets above 20ºC. So for me it's the jumper that is hot, not the weather, which is normal (or even cool). But I can see how the expectations about this might be different.

Then there's the argument I've read in a number of places: Rome was anal about records. Why are there zero records of the traitors execution?

"In that connection, I should reiterate that it is a complete “myth” that Romans kept detailed records of everything and that as a result we are inordinately well informed about the world of Roman Palestine and should expect then to hear about Jesus if he really lived. If Romans kept such records, where are they? We certainly don’t have any. Think of everything we do not know about the reign of Pontius Pilate as governor of Judea.  David L replied to this comment from Kardashev | June 25, 2024 14:27

In that connection, I should reiterate that it is a complete “myth” that Romans kept detailed records of everything and that as a result we are inordinately well informed about the world of Roman Palestine and should expect then to hear about Jesus if he really lived. Slightly different take.

The Roman republic/empire went on for well over 500 years. And encompassed vast amounts of territory even by today's standards.

We have vast amounts of paper like things from them. But I have to ask. If you take all of it and divide it by year and territory/major city, just how much per year across the entire empire is left? 1%? 0.01%?

In the US we have issues with county courthouses being where most of the public paperwork is kept. And there are now a non trivial number of gaps in the records due to fire (electrical or cat overturning an oil lap or ...), flood, war (1860s anyone), etc... And even if there is a minor fire in judges chambers the records are almost always in the basement. Where all the water used in a fire fighting incident winds up.

I can just imagine roof leaks, minor riots, whatever over the few 100 years of record keeping in a province of the Roman empire. And for a while maybe no one gave a damn and used the piles of paper to start cooking fires. Or ????

It is possible and normal to adapt to significant temperature changes. The built environment can be an issue, for certain. And that might have to be adapted as temperatures rise. But the human body can adapt to some degree.

 Mr. Tim | June 25, 2024 17:43
1292:

To revive the space probe sub-thread:

It occurs to me that we are thinking too small. Small probe attached to solar sail being pushed by multi-terawatt lasers.

Instead, use a (really big) rail gun to launch packages to the retreating probe. The packages are "caught" by a (fairly big) rail gun on the probe and momentum is exchange (accelerating the probe). The packages can have course trimming capability (so the accuracy requirement at launch is more reasonable), and even have their own booster to provide a bit of extra speed (especially when the probe gets going really fast).

The packages could also have useful payloads, like fuel, that could be used by the probes engine for additional boost or deacceleration. The (empty) packages could also be used the by the probes rail gun for boost/deacceleration.

Of course, this would be just the opposite of a small probe. I suspect it would have to be pretty damn big and probably have to have a least one nuclear reactor to power everything.

I am also pretty sure I read about this quite awhile ago, but no idea where.

 whitroth replied to this comment from Damian | June 25, 2024 18:19

 Kardashev | June 25, 2024 18:20
1294:

Instead, use a (really big) rail gun

About 30 years ago I attended a seminar at LLNL where gun-launched systems were being discussed for getting stuff to orbital altitudes. In the course of the discussions, it was noted that electronics capable of withstanding 30,000 g were off-the-shelf for military systems and the designers didn't see any problem with getting to 100,000 g.

100,000 g is 1000 km/sec^2, so I looked at what an accelerator capable of, ah, accelerating a 1 kg package to 0.01 c would look like. (Relativistic effects are small and ignored.) 0.01 c is 3,000 km/sec so the package would only need 3 seconds to get to that velocity at constant acceleration. S = 0.5 x a x t^2 = 500 x 9 = 4500 km in length. At the exit end, the accelerator needs force x velocity power to accelerate the package. Force is 1e6 N and velocity is 3e6 m/s, so 3 TW power. For larger packages the exit power scales with the mass.

That sounds formidable but perhaps doable in a century or two. 0.1c gets into Kardashev 1+ territory.

See also 1022 above: I'm just waiting for an update of Hoyle's Black Cloud reimagined as an interstellar probe. It's got big bits (magnetic field generators), and smaller bits (functional bots, mesobots, microbots, nanobots, and molecules and ions for shielding).The probe/cloud is fired out of the shotgun from hell (a big-ass linear accelerator), configures itself to get a boost from the solar wind on the way out to the heliopause, pulls itself into a fuzzy lump to coast towards its destination, where it makes itself into a plasma sail to slow down and steer. It comes in like a comet, drops in-system probes to gather data, goes around the star, them boosts itself on a somewhat slower ride back home as it collects telemetry from the probes it dropped. It might well scoop up plasma and dust to replenish its shield. At this point, the design is powered by wishful thinking and made of narrativium, but that's at least as durable as millennia old, laser-blasted mylar sails in interstellar space.

 Vulch replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 25, 2024 21:14
1301:

Slaves who murdered their masters were also crucified, along with all the other slaves the master owned (including women and children).

In more modern parlance that would be Petit Treason, Grand Treason being against the state. Under English law, servants killing their master or a wife killing her husband were guilty of Petit Treason. Being hung, drawn and quartered was the punishment for either treason although it was considered to be undignified for women to be treated like that so they got burned at the stake instead.

 Moz replied to this comment from Vulch | June 25, 2024 23:07
1308:

Under English law, servants killing their master or a wife killing her husband were guilty of Petit Treason.

We still have remnants of that today, with weird crimes like "theft as a servant" attracting harsher sentences than other theft, and "theft was a master" (eg theft) not really being crimes at all. I mean, de jure they are, but de facto on the rare occasions things get to a guilty verdict prison is (almost) never considered appropriate.

https://www.unsw.edu.au/newsroom/news/2024/06/recovering-lost-wages-nearly-impossible-australias-underpaid-migrant-workers

The widespread underpayment of migrant workers in Australia is now well-documented. The vast majority never recover the wages they are owed.

In 2009, the federal “small claims” court process was established in the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia. The idea was to give workers a simple and accessible forum to claim unpaid wages and entitlements from their employers – without needing a lawyer.

But our new research has found that in reality, this process is virtually impossible to use without legal support.

We've seen a slight reversal of that recently with the "battered woman syndrome" at times succeeding as a defence. Worth noting that this very definitely does not extend to abused children who will generally be found guilty of murder and if they escape will be captured and returned to their abusers.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from JohnS | June 26, 2024 05:07
1320:

Still, crucifixion was a ROMAN form of execution ... if the Jews had killed Jesus he would have been stoned to death as specified under Jewish law. But he hadn't violated Jewish law ...

Not exclusively Roman, by any means.

Judea was occupied at the time. Would a Jewish court be allowed to sentence a man to death without the Romans weighing in?

Would it have behooved the Jewish authorities (or some of them) to use the romans to do their dirty work for them, by setting someone up? A lot of scores get settled by proxy during an occupation, and Judea back then was as politically complicated as it is now, with the Romans dependent on locals for a lot of the day-to-day stuff (including what we would call intel).

Years ago Dr. Trevor Hodge (Carleton University) created a lovely series on Ideas (CBC radio) called The Court of Ideas, where he and a cast taught history using the form of mock trials. The first I heard was "Pontius Pilate vs. St. Mark", which had Pilate suing Mark for libel. They brought out a lot of the inaccuracies in the biblical narrative, as well as the politics of not only the time of the events, but also the time that the gospels were written and later codified as part of the christian bible.

My search skills aren't up to finding that episode online (if indeed it's online), as all the results are from biblical 'scholarship' (scare quoting because I don't consider baptist schools particularly reliable), but if you can find it I think you'd enjoy it. (And others in the series, like Alexander the Great being charged with misleading advertising.)

 Nojay replied to this comment from Ed Seedhouse | June 26, 2024 17:13
1353:

Crucifixion is a complicated way to execute someone. It was reserved by the Roman authorities to demonstrate a very visible outcome for crimes against the State like slave revolts and uprisings. A local rabblerouser like Jeshua son of Yusuf would have been taken round the back of the barracks and dealt with summarily without getting the star treatment accorded to him in the Bible.

Hanging, hacking someone's head off, slitting their throat or a quick spear into the ribcage was usually sufficient if the Romans simply wanted to execute a criminal or war captive. Enslavement was a more likely option for transgressors, especially those who were not of Roman heritage to begin with.

 ilya187 replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 26, 2024 19:03
1369:

"Civilizations die from suicide, not by murder."

...is a pithy slogan which is absolutely, 100% false. No civilization in history ever "died by suicide". Civilizations transform, not die.

Historians consider 476 AD to be the end of Western Roman Empire, when barbarian Odoacer, son of Attila’s sidekick Edeko, was crowned king of Italy. But as far as population of Rome and Italy were concerned, nothing terrible happened that year; if anything, it was more peaceful and prosperous than previous several decades. (Such as when the new king’s father and his boss invaded.)

Mayan civilization declined dramatically in the 9th and 10th century as cities were abandoned due to persistent drought and poor harvests, but when you realize that this process took almost 200 years it becomes much less dramatic. It’s not like millions of people starved to death at once. Rather, little by little, as scribes, administrators and professional warriors died of old age, their children would take up farming, as there was not enough surplus to support these civilized professions.

What really causes great loss of life, knowledge and culture are wars. In other words, civilizations (sometimes) get destroyed from outside, not collapse from within. Or you can say "Civilizations die by murder, not suicide".

The Maya collapse took centuries across the whole area. In any specific site it is abrupt and dramatic.  Heteromeles replied to this comment from Moz | June 27, 2024 00:19
1390:

What I think about Rapa Nui, or the Mayans, or the Aborigines, etc. is that we white folk have to remember that there are fairly nasty political elements to most collapse stories.

In the cases of the Maya and the Rapa Nuians , the stories of prehistoric collapse rested on the notion that the little brown-skinned people that explorers like Thor Heyerdahl interacted with could not have built the big ruined monuments they found. Therefore it was okay to exploit the brown people and ignore the histories they they remembered.

Australia’s Terra Nullius concept had similar grounds, I believe?

The Incan collapse story allowed Pizarro’s folk to backstab all the Andean allies who helped them overthrow the Inca (and ignore the suits those former allies filed in Spanish courts at the time).

Gibbon’s Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire conveniently ignored the fact that the Byzantines called themselves Romans, not Byzantines, and were the actual Roman Empire. By claiming that Rome had fallen, Gibbons made it possible for western empires like Britain and the Holy Roman Empire to claim to be the heirs of Rome and the Catholic Church, as opposed to those supported by the Byzantine Orthodox Churches, like the Russian Czars.

I used to be a lot less critical of collapse theories. Problem is, I think there’s a big element of politics in most of them, so it’s worth asking who benefits from them. This isn’t to say that pro-collapse researchers are political hacks, but it is to say that whether or not they realize it, they’re working in a politicized field and their findings will be spun.

A final example is Trump, who’s being supported a massive messaging claiming that the US is collapsing, it’s all the democrats’ fault, and only he can save the day. I don’t think this is supported by the data, but he’s doing absurdly well.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Ed Seedhouse | June 27, 2024 02:45
1401:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messianism

Messianism is a human phenomenon that occurs in every major religious tradition, North America ( the Ghost Dance ), Melanesia (cargo cults, John Frum), and especially, for whatever reason, in montane Southeast Asia.

Jesus’ life story is kind of the template for it, and it’s pretty close to stereotypical: man in an oppressed minority has mystical experiences, becomes convinced his mission is to make the world holy again. This messiah gathers a following, teaches them to live right, convinces them that the divine will be on their side when they go against their oppressor. They rise up, get massacred, the messiah dies, and his cult disappears when his disciples die off. Christianity was on this track until Paul showed up, messed with the script, and the rest is history, more or less.

Variations on Jesus’ story have happened so many times that I think Jesus’ life pretty much happened as written, minus the miracles. What’s bizarre about Jesus is that Christianity is the only major religion I can think of that was “founded by” a messiah, and I’m pretty sure that was actually Paul’s doing, mostly.

If you want to dig deeper into Messianism, one place you might look is Scott’s The Art of Not Being Governed, which is about highland South East Asia and has a chapter on messianism there.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Guy Rixon | June 27, 2024 14:43
1434:

Alternative reading: Yesuah ben Yousef (or whatever he was actually called in his lifetime) did start a cult. That cult died out normally with his direct disciples, then Paul of Tarsus built a different religion from the remnants.

Not quite. Paul interacted with the original disciples. Peter became the original bishop of Rome, for instance, which is why the popes (the bishops of Rome) claim an unbroken line of spiritual descent from Jesus. Paul never physically knew Jesus, after all. What he did do was to get Christianity spreading throughout the Roman world, so it stopped being just a schismatic Jewish cult.

…

And for Greg and others in the peanut gallery, there’s a big difference between a prophet and a messiah. Messiahs stereotypically start a revolt and get killed doing so, because apparently “trust your feelings” is bad tactical advice and Gods are lousy strategists. Prophets are spokespeople for the divine, and far more varied. Moses and Mohammed count as prophets, not messiahs.

As for Buddhism, it does have a messianic tradition, because messianism seems to be one of those things humans do. That said, Buddha was a yogi, not a prophet, and Buddhism is a yoga system that has spawned a bunch of non-prophet religions n the Mahayana side.

 Bobh replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 27, 2024 15:34
1436:

1356 "why Louisiana Xtians are trying to put the Ten Commandments on walls"

We're living in dystopian times similar to jesus'. The anxiety caused by “end is nigh” thought gets dealt with by some by puttting up the 10 Commandments, and for others, reading Charlie's CASE NIGHTMARE xyz stories. (I'd like some with a bit less dystopia, please.)

To follow the Way of Jesus, you need to pick your version. There’s what’s in the canonical Gospels,(which change meanings over time) and what’s in a range of “Gnostic” scriptures. The bare bones of the story: Like a lot of Jews, Jesus thought the end days were coming, and he was the messenger. The universalist “be nice to one another, and everybody” flows from that, but it’s not clear that meant social justice as we think about it today, or more likely, the world ending and restarting in a better version.

Whatever… We didn’t get to see that play out because Jesus got executed. For his followers that was a crisis. In a stunning reframe, the gospels main message is that Jesus triumphed over death, and that his believers could as well. But the nature of Jesus changes over time (See the link to Bart Erdman up-thread) In Mark’s gospel, God raises Jesus. By John’s, Jesus IS God. (For other changes, see sidebar below) There’s another set of stories that depict Jesus as a new age guru with secret knowledge for his inner circle.

Disagreement!!. Big arguments over who got to define Truth, framed as who was a real apostle. Anybody else became a tool of the devil. Eventually that resulted in a priesthood, the codification of the nature of “Christ”, and a canon of authentic scriptures. That all came together under Roman Emperor Constantine. The Church literally was the Ministry of Truth and ruthlessly suppressed heretical beliefs and writings. The Emperor was the voice of God in the world; priests controlled who had an afterlife That set a pattern of theocratic totalitarianism though Thomas Hobbes Divine Right of Kings

Back to putting up the 10 Commandments. Bart Erdman (mentioned upthread) said he began studying the Bible, because he was afraid of going to hell. So in a time when the world is collapsing it makes sense to revert to deep seated beliefs. The promise of a good afterlife, or the threat of going to hell is a powerful motivator.

Sidebar: The responsibility for Jesus death, also changes. Pontius Pilate, according to Josephus(?) is corrupt and arbitrary. He would have had no second thought about executing a troublemaker. In the gospel stories he becomes more and more a well meaning dupe of the scheming Jews. Jesus followers are becoming a separate religion that does not want to threaten Rome. Remember, this is soon after Jerusalem is sacked, and St Paul's marketing has given "Christianity" a foothold in the Greco-Roman world. By the time of Constantine, anti-Judaism was a feature, not a bug.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Bobh | June 27, 2024 16:19
1437:

Ummmm… the multiple Christianities started early and never went away. The one holy Roman Catholic Church was really only a feature of Europe (and not all of it!) during the high Middle Ages. Prior to that, there were fights between the Arians, the Orthodox, the Nestorians, the Copts….

Ministry of Truth is a modern notion. Until the Enlightenment, there was no split between Church and State, and which sect or religion you belonged to was very much about choosing your allies and/or enemies, as much or more than how you wanted to get to heaven.

The joke I read about the Council of Nicea (convened in 32 under Constantine’s order) is that Constantine declared himself a Christian and under that sign won the critical battle and conquered the empire. Like the smarter born-agains, he then wanted to know what he’d gotten himself into, so he called in a bunch of Christian leaders and asked them what Christianity was. After listening to them for awhile, he basically said unto them, “my dudes, you all need to go sit down amongst yourselves, figure out what it is you all agree that you believe and practice, then come back and tell me.” So they met in Nicea for months and did what he told them, and that’s more or less where orthodox Christianity came from.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 27, 2024 17:42
1445:

»Prognosis: if he doesn't get to declare a victory in Ukraine reasonably soon Russia will go the way of Yugoslavia after Tito (or Iraq after Saddam) when he dies.«

While I agree with the overall conclusion, neither of those historical parallels are relevant: In both cases the various factions all could "go somewhere else", not much of Russia has that option.

So much of the Russian transport infrastructure is star-shaped with Moscow at the center, that only a few of the areas closest to EU has a realistic chance of surviving, literally, without being on good terms with whoever controls Moscow.

But precisely those areas are vitally important to whoever controls Moscow, because they will control all bulk transport to the rest of the world.

I guess China has enough money that they could make a play to become the New Best Friends of everything on the far side of Yekaterinburg.

But apart from that, it is very hard to see major slices of Russia being able to walk away, and be allowed to walk away, by whoever controls Moscow.

 Heteromeles | June 27, 2024 17:46
1446:

Oh well, since OGH gets Christianed out so easily these days, I’ll toss an alt-history out there for the D&D cognoscent to get annoyed about.

The little flea in my ear is about Buddhism. When Alexander marauded into India, he created an interesting vacuum, and Buddhism flowed west into that hole. Primarily into Persia, but there are symbols of the eight-fold path in the graveyards of Ptolemaic Egypt.

So the what-if is what would have happened if Buddhism had taken root in the classical Mediterranean? It would have been an interesting fit. In the Hellenistic period, there was a lot of thought that the old gods weren’t real (people noticing that rituals often didn’t work), and a very familiar search for new deities who did work (like Fortuna, as well as foreign imports).

I’m not clear about who all believed in reincarnation or metempsychosis in the classical world, but it certainly was present, at least as a minority view, and breaking the cycle might seem worthwhile to a lot of people who were getting tired of state cults, imperial Roman geniuses and the like.

So anyway, roll it forward a bit to the BCE/CE split. Buddhism is an established thing in the Mediterranean, Rome is going imperial, and the Mahayana movement is cranking along in India and elsewhere. Instead of Jewish messiahs as we know them, Buddhist Pure Land monks are coming out of the woodwork here and there, declaring themselves Pure Land messiahs and getting crucified for their pains. Crank forward a few more centuries and some of the Pure Landers we’re getting as active as the Ikko Ikki were in Medieval Japan ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ikk%C5%8D-ikki ).

At this point, all we have to do is throw in some New Agey Roman Druids who are practicing Celtic spirituality the same way modern Europeans hold Powwows and Rainbow Family Gatherings (complete with a solstice Wickerman), and you’ve got D&D: monks, druids, fighters, clerics, mages, and rogues. No dragons though. Gotta work on that. All starting with a few monks going west and getting lucky.

Game on?

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from David L | June 27, 2024 20:15
1454:

For the majority of the people in the US there is confusion over the changing country. To their parents and earlier the world was mostly ordered and repetitive.

Was it, though? My grandfather went from horse-drawn carriages in London to watching a man walk on the moon. From women not being able to vote to seeing a woman as prime minister. My parents saw Russia go from enemy to ally to enemy in a few years. They lived through the greatest change in British society in generations.

Was America so different? In the 20th century you went from pitched battles between labour and companies (complete with machine guns and the army being deployed against strikers) to a president stating that increasing union membership was a sign of American industrial strength to another president vilifying organized labour. From arsenic as a legal ingredient for children's candies to the idea that the federal government can regulate food safety.

I'm old enough to have seen a lot of changes (got grandniblings, after all), and yet I wonder at how people who long for the "good old days" have no idea what those days were actually like and somehow think they were timeless — because the once constant in my (and my parents' and grandparents') life has been change. Mostly good change, and I say that as a white male — if I was female or non-white the changes would have been even better.

But leaving aside the question of whether the changes were good, there have always been changes. People who yearn for s simpler unchanging past are yearning for an imaginary world, not the one that was actually there.

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 27, 2024 22:23
1463:

»Was it, though? My grandfather went from horse-drawn carriages in London to watching a man walk on the moon.«

Yes, and try as we might, if we are born before 1980, we cannot intellectualize an understanding of the mental state of people born thereafter.

I say this because one of my regular duties is to try to guide visitors through the impact of "the digital revolution" in datamuseum.dk, and the more you know, the more dramatic it seems.

I could write at length about this, but I will restrain myself to two things:

First your grandfather grew up with childhood friends who all lived within a couple of km radius, as did you and I.

If you were born after 1990, you had childhood friends all over the country, and as soon as you learned more languages: All over the world.

Second: How many times in your life did you think "If I die here, nobody even knows where to look for my corpse" ?

It was a real risk, and therefore we mitigated it, almost without thinking about it: We left a copy of our planned route in the hotel room. We wrote name, nationality, date & time in the guestbook in the shelters, or we left it on a piece of paper under a stone, if there were no guestbook.

Computers and telecommunication has /fundamentally/ changed our relationship with time and space, and try as we might, we will never get an intuitive grasp of how the post-1990 generations perceive time and space, because our own formative years were /so/ different from theirs.

This is why most parents and grandparents fail to understand why Kids These Days™, experience a dead mobile phone as traumatizing sensory deprivation.

Scolding them "Pull yourself together!" is not very helpful, for somebody who has never been that isolated before, for someone who has been under constant (presumably benevolent) surveillance, every single minute of their entire life.

So yes, being born after 1990 is probably even more different than you can even imagine.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Retiring | June 27, 2024 23:05

Okay, now do that for 1780 vs. 1680. Yes, some differences: but far fewer than betwixt 1880 and 1780, let alone 1880 and 1980.

If you go back before roughly 1600, in most places there were relatively few differences between one century and the next, for most people -- modulo the odd war or famine, and slow-changing fashions in clothes, change was very slow: a generation might see as much change as we expect in 12 months.

 Heteromeles replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 28, 2024 01:05
1476:

Change over time....

It jumps, like going from eating wild boar to eating potatoes in England (there were maybe 200 years when you could conceivably have eaten both, including the reintroduction now). Things like the printing press made a permanent difference. So did the Romans introducing rabbits to the British isles, or the whole Columbian crop exchange (potatoes, sweet potatoes and corn were responsible for a population boom when they hit Eurasia, for example). And there's the whole thing about colonial tea and sugar (and coffee, and chocolate, and cotton, and...). Change doesn't happen very evenly.

And there's the things we don't normally think about. I'm cleaning out my mom's house right now, and she didn't throw much out. So I've got the boards she used to make a brick and board bookcase when she was in college. They're clear heart redwood, been sitting around for 60 years. When she bought them they were cheap wood from a local shop. Now they're around $100 per board foot, because almost no old growth redwoods are harvested any more. Now I get to figure out what to do with them. My dad's old fishing tackle box has these enormous ocean fishing lures. When he was in his 20s they were perfectly appropriate. Not many fish that big left now. And so it goes. At least the whale oil lamp was a cheap reproduction, bought ironically.

I think the thing that most concerns me about now is planned obsolescence. The Casio FX 702p calculator that's almost 45 years old still works (as do the slide rules that are decades older), but the phone that's five years old is bricked (telecom went out of business). I've been told by my family that old media shall be digitized and discarded. I'm suuuuure it's going to last longer that way. But whatever.

And I think that's the point right now: change is fast, but it's not necessarily in a good direction. We all have to watch out for that. Maybe it's a good idea to take kids to phoneless areas so that they develop some disconnected skills while they still can?

 Kardashev replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 28, 2024 01:14
1477:

Much like 1890. Telephones, electric lights, radio, moving pictures, automobiles, airplanes!

Yes, things are changing very fast and at an accelerating rate. Back somewhere on the blog someone expressed it as "history is now decorrelating every dozen years". That is, politics, science, important technology change on that timescale and cannot be predicted from where things were a dozen years ago. We've got about six or seven decorrelation times to go before hitting 2100 CE

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from Troutwaxer | June 28, 2024 06:27
1482:

»One of my friends was born after 1980. We tried showing her Dr. Strangelove and the only joke she got was "You can't fight in her, this is the war room!"«

My ex-wife was USAnian, so my daughter also got the "You will be held accountable by the Coca-Cola Company!" one too, but yes, that and many other good movies take a lot of setup to young people to get the joke.

»Maybe it's a good idea to take kids to phoneless areas so that they develop some disconnected skills while they still can?«

Never a bad idea, and why both my kids were scouts.

But it is not just that they lack some scout-badges to survive in the world we knew as children: They live in a fundamentally different world than we did, good and bad.

And yes, a lot happened between 1890 and 1990, almost all of it trivial force multipliers: News got distributed faster, transportation was faster, you could communicate faster with people 1-to-1 and so on.

But all your interactions with the world were human-to-human interactions: You called a telephone (Then: A place, Now: A person!) and hoped some human would answer it, you bought your tickets from a person, you ordered your goods from a person, you asked the reference librarian to find information.

Computer miniaturization and connectivity reintroduce roman-style slavery en masse: The person at the other end does not actually have to talk to you on the phone, because we have instant, mass-less, world-wide and free textual communication. You buy tickets from machines. You order goods from machines. Machines find information for you and so on. Machines even carry your money for you.

We even have trains driven by machines now, and the only reason why cars and planes are not there yet, is that we have not fenced the erratic humans out of problem yet.

On the surface, that sounds just like more force-multiplication but where the automobile were ten or maybe hundred times a horse, here we are talking many orders of magnitude better, in particular the "instant, world-wide and free communication" and the "money-carrying machines" which can transact across that communication.

Most people can look at a car going 100km/h vs. a horse going 5km/h and sorta predict what that will do to a society.

But five orders of magnitude faster, practically instant, flat-rate communication, between both humans and machines ?

That is a very different world - good and bad.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Heteromeles | June 28, 2024 12:21
1497:

GPS is safe from Kessler syndrome: the navsat constellations are redundant (most phones can long onto both the US GPS signal but also Glonass (Russian) and Galileo (EU), never mind the Indian cluster that's going up soon) and they orbit much higher than LEO, meaning Kessler debris would have a vastly lower probability of damaging them.

If you double the orbital radius you roughly cube the volume of space inside that orbit (minus the volume of Earth, which is constant). So while Kessler syndrome would poison low earth orbit for a while, it probably wouldn't reach stuff orbiting more than 10,000km out or significantly out of the plane of the ecliptic (which is most navsats).

In fact, now that I think about it -- if you want to still launch satellites after a Kessler cascade, you'll need big boosters than can do direct-ascent to high orbits, much like the way the US Space Command uses Falcon Heavy to do direct ascent to GEO for classified payloads (to stop other folks getting a good look at them on the way up). SpaceX's Starship would be perfect for that job -- in disposable mode, Starship v3 is going to be able to throw 250-300 tonnes right out of Earth orbit. (It's a stretched version of the current model's successor, already under development: bigger fuel tanks and third generation Raptors, so evolutionary rather than revolutionary.) So we're unlikely to lose access to space in event of a Kessler cascade, although it'll make some activities difficult and everything more expensive.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Poul-Henning Kamp | June 28, 2024 12:37
1498:

We even have trains driven by machines now

Eh, not exactly.

While there are some driverless train systems (London's DLR has been mostly-driverless since it was built in the mid 1980s; any number of airport people-movers are driverless) they generally need purpose-built fully grade-separated track systems and also a central monitoring and control centre with human supervisors in the loop. And when it throws an exception, the default response is to stop everything until a human troubleshooter can get out to the scene.

So we're not going to see driverless trains operating on the existing track networks (which were mostly built out from the 1830s onwards) any time soon. Maybe on next-gen Shinkansen or other high speed rail networks, which have high bandwidth communications and no grade crossings (and also very high fences with alarms alongside the track to prevent incursions). But not on your boring everyday belt-and-road freight train that runs across 10,000km of China and Asia, for example. Or the US network (which is a mess).

I don't think we're ever going to have pilotless airliners for the same reason we're never going to have passengerless airliners: it's a life-safety critical role (if the airliner malfunctions you can't just pull over and call the AA) and you can't count on external comms to allow a drone pilot in a call centre to take over either (too many extra potential failure modes). A pilot on the flight deck is insurance against the automation failing, and the first officer is insurance against the pilot having a fatal stroke at the controls (which happens a few times a week).

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 28, 2024 13:28
1504:

from horse speed (10MPH on dry roads in daylight) to near-lightspeed (NYC to San Fran in seconds; oft required repeated send to ensure it reached so not milliseconds)

Not quite that much of a jump: you missed out the optical telegraph, which was in service from 1792 and allowed Napoleon to get orders and reports from one side of the French empire in Europe to the other in a matter of single-digit hours and remained in use until the 1850s. Much slower and more labour-intensive and costly than the electrical telegraph but it was an enormous step-change in signaling speed.

 Charlie Stross | June 28, 2024 13:36
1507:

Incidentally, the current fuss about Starlink is about the potential damage to the ozone layer caused by de-orbiting 50-250 tons of mostly-aluminum satellites every year, resulting in a lot of metal vapour at high altitude.

For those who're worried about this, bear in mind that the metal in question is mostly structural. And the Japanese space agency is testing a possible solution in September, in the shape of LignoSat, a test satellite where the structural material is magnolia wood (they've already run long-duration tests of structural samples on the ISS).

Given that wood is readily oxidizable, a comsat cluster built using this technique would reduce the high-altitude metal dispersal by upwards of 90%.

So no, the sky is not necessarily falling.

 David L replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 28, 2024 13:49
1508:

Was it, though?

Same life day to day.

Yes it was. Day to day. But also no it wasn't. Piling onto PHK and Charlie's comments.

The tech my grandfather worked with and saw changed dramatically during his life. 1885-1982. He went from horse to model T to ICE trucks/tractors and such for his farm. And the land was settled by his great (x2 or 3) grandfather in 1824. I lived on some of that dirt for 10+ years and have second cousins still living on it.

He got up in the morning most of his life to the same day. Milk cows or have a paid hand do it. Plant, tend, or harvest crops. Deal with needed supplies. Buy animals. Breed and slaughter them. Sell the meat. Raise chickens for eggs and meat. And so on. And was doing it until he was 92. Oh, church on Sunday.

My father went to a school built in 1922. Ditto my mother. 12 grades. I went to some of the exact same classrooms 30-40 years later.

Even by the 60s when we got Newsweek or Time, most of our news was 30 min to an hour daily (but with commercials) on the local TV station. A daily afternoon newspaper. 20 to 40 pages but with well over 1/2 of that ads. National news outside of what the local paper editors wanted to print was 15 minutes of national TV with commercials.

The 60s were a shock but it settled down a bit. Then cable TV hit. Then 24 hour news channels. Then the Internet.

Prior to that the tech changes made life very different in getting work and life done but didn't change the basics of WHAT you did. Or why. The changes of the 80s and 90s changed society and daily life. Totally.

Prior to that most of us had a horizon of the 5 to 50 miles around us. After that it was the entire planet. All kinds of people suddenly "showed up" who didn't act, think, dress, or believe like like those in our prior horizon. And they didn't fit into the preconceived slots we had all been raised to understand.

If you want to see a movie example of this watch the last episode of "Band of Brothers". It is an episodic 8 part or so WWII movie that follows Easy Company of the 101st Airborne from training till VE day. Based on a book by Richard Winters. And not a "War Is Glorious" story. There are two great scenes at the end. One of a German General saying good by to his remaining men. But the one I'm leading up to is Winters talking about what happened to the survivors of Easy Company. How they went back to driving a taxi, tending a farm in Arkansas, becoming a lawyer, etc... The point being that even after fighting the Germans in Europe they were able to go back to the life they had hoped to live. And for most it was simple and they could ignore the world they had seen in those WWII years.

Now that is not just possible unless you become a near hermit.

Now what I've written is based on life outside of NYC, Boston, Philadelphia, and Chicago in the US. But I'm guessing it was similar in Europe and other parts of the world. But different.

 Greg Tingey | June 28, 2024 14:09

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 28, 2024 14:18
1510:

If you go back before roughly 1600, in most places there were relatively few differences between one century and the next

And you're back before there was an America. I was questioning David's statement that:

For the majority of the people in the US there is confusion over the changing country. To their parents and earlier the world was mostly ordered and repetitive.

From what I know about American history, the country has always been changing, and I doubt that it was as ordered and repetitive as the current generation thinks it was.

I kept running up against this with younger colleagues; they had no concept of what the world was like when I was their age and how much change I've seen. They didn't understand the threat of nuclear annihilation during the cold war. They didn't understand how limited your options were if you weren't a white male. Etc. To them those were ancient times, back when people drove horse-drawn wagons before they were born, and the modern world had always been the way it was when they were in school and started to learn about it.

Toffler wrote Future Shock in 1970 about the rapid pace of change and its effect on society, so commenting on it goes back at least that far. I would argue that mid-century America saw just as big a change as we are seeing now: working conditions changed enough that ordinary blue collar workers could afford their own detached house with a stay-at-home wife, something that was previously affordable only to well-paying white collar workers. Multi-generational households, roommates, scrimping on food, etc was normal a hundred years ago (just as it's becoming normal again).

And I'm back to my working-class grandfather. Grew up when horses were the primary transportation within London. By the time he moved to Canada to live with us air travel was common and cheap enough that ordinary people flew to other continents for fun, when back in his youth only the rich could afford the time (and money) to travel across oceans for fun, while the poor did it only when emigrating. You could pick up a telephone and talk to your relatives across the world, while in his youth you wrote letters and waited for a reply, and emigrating meant you would never hear their voice again.

Another large factor is uncertainty. The world right now is uncertain, because we don't know how things are going to work out. History is certain, because we know how events unrolled. We know what was important and what wasn't. So when looking at the past we discount all the uncertainly and distractions that people living then experienced. We know there wasn't a nuclear war. We know that the civil rights movement made major changes and the country didn't end. We know the country pulled through the Great Depression. We know that order didn't collapse in 1967. And so on. I'm certain there's a scholarly term for this 'certainty in hindsight', and that people brighter than me have looked at the subject.

 David L replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 28, 2024 14:47
1515:

From what I know about American history, the country has always been changing, and I doubt that it was as ordered and repetitive as the current generation thinks it was.

For most people in the US and I suspect Canada out side of big cities, the details of how they led their lives kept changing. Yes.

But their social lives pretty much stayed the same. Who they were likely to marry. Where (within a few miles) they were likely to live. Who they would see at church. Etc... They might talk via phone instead of a meeting at the feed store but it was still mostly the same folks.

This started changing a bit after WWII due to the US military service of vast swaths of US males. But it really didn't start changing until comm tech made the world smaller. Movies might show a rural Paducah boy (me) what an "American in Paris" might look like in the 1960s, but it was also more of a fantasy that reality. Cause after I came out of one of the two movie theaters in town, reality had not changed. I was still in the same area where my family had lived basically the same lives since 1824.

Let's see. My father went into business with a friend who was married to the pastor's daughter. His financier was the father of my 6th grade teacher and also owned a local lumber yard. And all of us were at the same church. I mowed fields for someone who went to grade school (preteen) with my grandfather in the 1890s. My kids saw none of those kinds of local community ties.

So to PHK's point, life before 1990 was rapidly changing in HOW we did things but we still mostly did the same things. Socially. After 1990-2000, social norms just blew up.

And that is driving the politics of this decade.

A whole generation of working-class Britons had their horizons opened — for those young people it was a massive change, having access to information and opportunities they were previously shut out of.  David L replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 28, 2024 15:19
1518:

I'm not arguing that the world hasn't changed in the last 40 years, but I am arguing that those changes aren't uniquely transforming.

I guess we disagree. I think your recent ancestors were more of an exception than the usual.

While thinking about this let me tell you how a young couple would get a mortgage for their first home in in most of the US in the 70s and even the 80s. They might have been married for a few years. He a not too long out of school accountant or maybe engineer. She working as a grocery clerk or maybe as a office clerk in an accounting or engineering office. They'd show up at the bank and talk to the loan officer who had gone to school with their parents. Or maybe was the scout troop leader for one of their fathers. He'd collect information and call some friends asking about the upstandingness of this couple if they knew them.

Now take today. But let's roll the clock back to that same time. A couple making $80K to $150K together, living together, planning to be married in a few years are looking to buy a house. Maybe they have a baby. They put down an offer and go to the same banker. The banker politely takes their information. Then he calls the parents and wants to have a meeting. Then he calls his priest or pastor and asks if giving this couple a mortgage is a sin. Maybe mortal. And he calls his manager and asks if they are even allowed to write this mortgage. Or want to do so.

Life has changed. And not everyone likes it.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from David L | June 28, 2024 15:36
1520:

For most people in the US and I suspect Canada out side of big cities, the details of how they led their lives kept changing. Yes. But their social lives pretty much stayed the same.

Despite our reputation (and self-image), Canada has been a majority-urban country since about 1920. America made that switch even earlier. Small town life has been a minority experience in North America for over a century.

Bowling Alone came out in 2000, based on a 1995 essay, and chronicles the decline in the kind of civic connections you mentioned since the 1950s, and IIRC mentions 1965 as the year the change accelerated. The Middletown studies from the 1920s are interesting too, documenting how new technologies (radio, cheap automobiles) changed people's lives and how they behaved. I haven't read them in years, but IIRC they discuss the same idea just putting the change point earlier.

https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.156473/

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middletown_studies

 Heteromeles | June 28, 2024 15:42
1522:

I'm not arguing that the world hasn't changed in the last 40 years, but I am arguing that those changes aren't uniquely transforming.

I respectfully disagree, because of exponential growth. The world human population has already doubled during my lifespan, and it’s likely to triple before I die. That’s nothing, you might say, because it quadrupled during my grandmother’s lifetime (1.6-6.2 billion), but the fact that there are so many people does actually matter. We didn’t used to worry about globally running out of potassium or phosphorus, for example. In the early 1900s, we did worry about running out of nitrogen for two billion people, but nitrogen fixation not only kicked that can down the road, it made high explosive, machine gun warfare available to the masses. So now we have to worry about nitrogen for eight billion instead.

The basic point is that technologies that are minimally impactful when a few people do them—hunting whales, jet setting, or using social media, to pick examples—do have severe impacts when a lot of people do them. And we’re at the point when a lot of people do everything.

It’s hard to see that in individual experiences, but it’s easier to see it in aggregate.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from David L | June 28, 2024 22:17
1571:

Yes: the correct solution is for the USA to pass a Public Lending Right law, and for the Internet Archive to stop pirating books.

There's a long and acrimonious history behind the big publishers not liking libraries (they get paid once, for one physical copy of a book that 20-50 readers then get to read) and for it getting worse with ebooks (buy once, read infinitely many times) which led to them setting up DRM/license management software for library edition ebooks, so that they'd get paid for a new copy every 20-30 readers. Then the Internet Archive just said "why bother" and started pirating whatever the hell they liked, buying a single retail (not library) copy and then letting an unlimited numbers of readers download an ebook copy of it.

Bear in mind that books historically average 4-5 readers per sale because (a) some folks are collectors, and (b) lumps of paper fall apart. So historically library copies (sold to libraries at a special -- higher -- price to reflect the larger number of readers) were a thing.

What PLR systems do is, they replace high-priced "library" editions with a system whereby authors are paid a small amount per library loan -- a bit like streaming via Spotify. (I believe publishers can also register for a kickback via PLR to reflect their share of the production costs.) So the publisher/library conflict of interests goes away.

TLDR: this is a US-specific problem that can be fixed easily enough, as has happened in a lot of other countries.

https://gizmodo.com/interpol-fraud-scams-ftc-operation-first-light-2024-1851566535

Police around the world have arrested 3,950 people and seized assets totaling $257 million in a coordinated effort to crack down on online scams, according to a news release Thursday from Interpol. Dubbed Operation First Light 2024, the scammers engaged in a variety of online crimes, including phishing, investment fraud, taking in money from fake shopping sites, and romance scams, the international law enforcement agency says.

The international effort from March to May of this year spanned 61 countries and included the combined seizure of $135 million in fiat currency and $2 million in crypto. Police seized roughly $120 million in assets, including real estate, luxury cars, and jewelry. The operation also identified an additional 14,643 “other possible suspects,” according to Interpol.

 SFReader replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 28, 2024 23:57
1581:

Re: '... link to Nate Silver's discussion of his model and what it means'

Not sure whether Silver mentions* that polls can bias potential ordinary voters - the common folk.

Silver mentions that DT currently has a 60% chance of winning - if that's all that people see/read, then they're going to act to make that happen, i.e., the MAGAs will go out and vote so that they can claim having made the victory possible, the DEMs will say 'my vote won't make a difference so I may as well stay home'.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0176268023000277

'If a party’s popularity is systematically ‘inflated’ in the polls, does this result in an electoral advantage for that party? Our results suggest that this is indeed the case. Both in terms of the number of rounds that candidate K was elected and in terms of average vote share, candidate K performed better in the treatment than in the control condition in a robust manner. In particular, the biased feedback mechanism increased the average vote share of the favoured candidate K by 16 percentage points, 8.6 percentage points and 6.1 percentage points in E1, E2 and E3, respectively. These differences are consistent across sessions, and there is limited evidence that these effects go away as participants gain more experience.1'

*Haven't finished the article yet but whether or not he did mention this, I wanted to highlight this particular potential bias/influence on voting behavior. I'm not anti-polls, just feel that it (like many social tools) needs a warning label.

 Moz replied to this comment from SFReader | June 29, 2024 03:17
1593:

provided you're going to continue living in or near an urban area with reliable delivery of key goods

I kind of suspect that there are at least two sets of skills that are at best orthogonal. Obviously the "can survive in 1950's USA" skills rely on widely available time travel to be useful, but more broadly there's the question of what tech level you expect to have because that greatly affects the skills you will value. As noted indirectly, being able to hunt and butcher animals that are now extinct isn't a useful skill, especially if nothing like that is alive now (we have few elephant-sized animals, for example, it's not just "really big fish").

So if we confidently assume ironworking but not electricity we might also decide that railways are too hard and thus the key skills revolve around find horse-equivalents, domesticating them, taming them and putting them to work. Metalworking using recycled/reclaimed metal ditto, but outside Australia I suspect "mining" isn't going to be popular (in quotes because "shovel dirt into furnace" isn't really mining as most of us think of it).

But that exact same historical parallel suggests that teaching the very basic hunter-gatherer skills plus literacy would be a better foundation. We have many, many examples of people making the transition from there to more complex societies, but few of the reverse. Perhaps think of it as a slippery slope version of the "teach people to live in the 1950's" original argument. There's a lot more history of hunter-gatherers than 1950's (even a single 100,000 years is more than 10 years).

But... being part of an established rural community that has a degree of resilence within an industrial society will be a good start. You've got your community, but you've also got trade links and connections to other similar communities. Hopefully with enough backup people than you can survive the inevitable nonsurvivals. Which gets us back to orthogonal skill sets - there are huge costs to living in a small rural community, not least the lack of indigenous advanced healthcare. I suspect "blog posters in their 50's and other" aren't going to make it through the projected demographic transition or be much valued for their "grumpy old man telling the youth of today how they should behave" skills.

 David L replied to this comment from Howard NYC | June 29, 2024 05:17
1602:

carpentry trick: cardboard template

For most people getting all the holes correct ON BOTH SIDES of cabinet doors is a chore. Holes that are multiple sizes and depths. But not through. Tight tolerances or people will notice. Like 1/1000 of an inch or so. (Some cabinet designs are meant to hide such things.)

People who do it on a regular basis are very good at it. Those of us who do it once every 10 or so years, not so much. Templates are great. Especially if the manufacturer will sell you one or you can make one. Out of cardboard they get sloppy way too fast unless you're doing just a few doors and pulls. Many cabinet vendors now offer such a template made of hard plastic with metal ring inserts where the bits go. And marks on the sides of where to put the drill stops.

Now for real fun that makes cabinets look simple, learn to cut crown molding on a miter saw. Upside down and backwards you get to be. If you're not a regular make sure you have some extra to practice on before you do the real pieces.

 MaddyE replied to this comment from alantyson | June 29, 2024 07:58
1606:

Cars: how to bump start it, how to jump start it, check & top up fluids, top up air, replace fuses, replace wiper blades, change bulbs (if you are flexible enough to get your hand in the space to do so without dismantling half the engine first), change a tyre.

Know when and where to apply oil to bicycles, (I draw the line at puncture repairs), top up air.

Do simple DiY like re-pinning furniture, easing a sticking door, replacing cupboard handles, oiling hinges, changing light bulbs, replacing fuses, clear a blocked drain, repair a dripping tab, descale appliances (large and small).

Clothing repairs - replace buttons, stitch split seams, patch holes or darn knitwear, simple tailoring when your weight changes, (making the clothes first from fabric or yarn is a bonus), which fabrics and yarns are durable, how to clean clothes to keep them looking good.

Cook using fresh ingredients (catching or growing them is optional, as is basic processing like milling or butchery), what to do with leftovers, preserving surpluses safely, balanced diet, food shopping - what to buy, optimal freshness, storage.

In the garden know the difference between something wanted and a weed, know when to sow for optimal growing conditions, when to harvest, how to store your harvest, mow a lawn without mechanical assistance (bonus points if you can do so without a trip to A&E), prune fruit trees.

In the country know what is poisonous or likely to cause unpleasant reactions from plants, animals, and landowners.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from PilotMoonDog | June 29, 2024 13:22
1622:

One reason I am dubious about sat navs is them taking attention off the road.

They all have an option to provide spoken directions, going back a couple of decades. They're also configurable to display less screen clutter. And mostly they can provide live warning of traffic congestion/accidents ahead and re-route to divert you around blockages before you get stuck. Finally, they generally won't let you reconfigure them or fiddle with their settings while you're in motion -- a deliberate safety requirement.

The only drawbacks I can see are that if there's a GPS failure for whatever reason (and it could be deliberate -- someone with a GPS jammer/spoofer -- or a once-a-decade satellite system malfunction) you could get lost. And of course there are occasional screwups, such as single track country lanes that sometimes get flagged as a shortcut suitable for HGVs.

 Paul | June 29, 2024 15:39
1624:

On rent control and similar mechanisms: I have a strong suspicion that excess consumer money always gets soaked up somewhere, and the only question is where.

I confess I haven't got the mechanisms fully worked out, but it seems like there is always at least one "essential" that everyone has to have (housing, food, water, clothes, healthcare, bandwidth etc) which rises in cost to absorb as much money as people have, and this process only stops when a substantial minority of the population can't afford it.

Historically this was often food. In some places it was water. These days it tends to be housing. In the US its often healthcare.

If you bring the price of this essential down by price control or subsidy or something, then the money released just gets sucked up by one of the others.

I don't know what to do about this. But the standard model of "essentials" versus "disposable income" seems to be missing something.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from PilotMoonDog | June 29, 2024 15:56
1626:

One reason I am dubious about sat navs is them taking attention off the road.

I have a mount for my iPhone so it's on the front console by the radio controls, plugged into my car stereo with an aux patch cord. I mostly rely on the voice directions (from Apple Maps), but will glance at the screen to see things like which lanes of an interchange go which directions. (Something that isn't on any paper maps I've ever seen.) Glancing at the map requires almost no time (about the same as a scan of instruments: speed, tach, check no warning lights are on). Unlike a paper map the display only shows the road just in front of me (two blocks on city streets, a bit more on the highway; I think it adjusts depending the speed) so it takes less cognitive load to read it.

There's enough construction and traffic in Toronto that relying on paper maps is problematic. My last Toronto map book was over an inch thick, and you needed to flip pages frequently for any journey. And it absolutely sucked for planning a trip because there was no way to get an overview that showed enough detail to see the streets). I used to use paper maps until a few years ago, and it made travelling anywhere new in the city very stressful. I've seen a. lot more of the city since I started using my phone instead of paper maps.

I also use the iPhone when travelling a familiar route, not because I need it for navigation but because it warns me of traffic hazards ahead (like an accident that's closed five lanes of the highway) in time for me to find an alternate route (not always, but enough to be useful).

 ilya187 | June 29, 2024 16:15

My cursive is very clear and readable, I had been complimented on it many many times in my life. Having said that, I honestly think that cursive is one of those inventions (like bitcoin and social media) which are actually detriment to civilization. Sometimes fatal errors; for some reason doctors' cursive tends to be especially bad, and doctors are about the last people whose writing is safe to misinterpret.

Cursive was invented along with the fountain pen because it utilizes the way ink flows out of it. It is completely unnecessary with pencils and with ball-point pens, and should have died along with the fountain pen.

 Guy Rixon replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 29, 2024 17:07
1631:

DLR trains are remotely monitored. IIUC, the trains can't go unless a remote operator is in contact to cover emergencies. Presumably one remote operator covers multiple trains, otherwise there's no cost saving in remote operation and no reason to install it. The safety case must be built on the trains looking after themselves for some number of seconds that is rather longer then the reaction time of an on-board driver.

One could imagine remote operation working on higher-speed trains: essentially anything with cab signalling so that it doesn't go into safety shutdown if a remote operator fails to see a signal aspect. But then you need a guard to check that the train is safe to depart after a station stop, and you go from needing a driver per train to a guard per train, and save no money.

What is impressive is the automation in the signalling systems. Any entry-exit panel has a lot of automation, and it never seems to go wrong in a way that causes a crash. Further, some of the London underground allegedly automated the signalling at junctions using a punched-card system back in the 1920s. Junctions are hard, of course, relative to plain-line block-posts. And the London automation is said to have dealt with trains running out of sequence through a diverging junction; never did work out they managed that.

Some time ago you asked folks here whether they thought that 'narrative' was important. Didn't respond back then because I hadn't really thought about it and couldn't come up with an answer that felt clear, satisfactory and rational.

To me the answer is 'yes, narrative is important' - not just for a listing of interesting characters or situations but also for how various story elements do or do not mesh. The 'mesh' bit is key because it means that 'time' (sequence) is involved and the timing/sequence is where you get a lot (if not most) of the meaning. And, it turns out that 'time' is likely an integral part of our brain. (Note: Small sample study caveats apply.)

https://www.sciencealert.com/time-cells-in-the-brain-could-be-more-crucial-than-we-ever-realized

'"We are interested in exploring whether complex timing behavior tasks could be a useful way to detect the early onset of Alzheimer's disease," says senior author of the study, neurobiologist James Heys.

There's also growing interest in how 'time blindness' – a symptom of ADHD and autism – arises. Understanding how time is mapped and recorded in the brain could help progress investigations there, too.

The researchers note that while they found the MEC has a clear role in timing, there are other regions in the MTL, like the hippocampus and lateral entorhinal cortex, that also encode time.'

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robert Prior | June 30, 2024 10:47
1657:

For your uses, a Mac Mini will do fine. It's also probably more use than an iMac insofar as you already have the monitor -- I've been running on iMacs for the past decade but am moving back to separates (monitor and system unit) these days.

The one fly in the ointment is video editing (up to 4K) -- for that you need the beefiest machine you can afford, in terms of both memory and storage. Per my other half (who also does video editing on a Mac) her Macbook Air 15" with 24Gb RAM and 2Tb SSD is extremely quick (significantly beating her 10 core i9 intel iMac), and an M2 mini will do just fine, but you want to max out memory and storage because they're not upgradeable after the fact (the Apple Silicon kithas RAM and SSD soldered on the motherboard), although you can use external SSDs (or hard drives) for stuff you're not actively editing.

Apple look to be having fab level production difficulties with the M3 processor so have already moved to the M4 for the latest iPad Pro -- expect M4 Mac Mini and Mac Studio models to show up late this year.

 Robby replied to this comment from Charlie Stross | June 30, 2024 15:10
1664:

Whilst I agree that the assorted position, navigation and timing constellations should be resistant to Kessler syndrome due to sitting ~20,000km higher, I wonder about the signals getting through.

The signals are incredibly weak, I'm always amazed that a cheap mobile phone can pick them up so well. They also need to arrive on time, coming in a straight line. If kessler syndrome puts a layer of chaff in between satellite and receiver, I wonder how much the signal will be degraded.

Not an insurmountable problem to fix - new satellites with more powerful transmitters, and bigger antennas at the receiving end - but it still makes everything just that little bit worse than it is now.

Personally I would love to work on the post-Kessler cleanup. There's a lifetime of interesting work there.

 David L replied to this comment from Tim H. | June 30, 2024 16:59
1669:

Bear in mind RAM & storage are not economically upgradeable on these machines* and order according to your needs. What I do with my Mac doesn't require the pro SOC, someone else might speak in a more informed fashion than me. *It could've been designed with sockets for memory and storage, but there would've been a performance hit.

HUGE.

Apple moved the memory and storage controller onto the CPU dies. And what people call memory onto the same die. Which means that much of what you pay for in addition the bit storage of "normal" memory and storage systems is directly integrated into the CPU bus system. No connectors to slow things down and be failure points. So you tend to get much more reliability and performance or a similar traditional design.

But this means no upgrade of memory. It is literally baked into the CPU chip.

Storage is similar but different. All of the control circuits are on the CPU die. Just the storage bits are not. And since no one but cell phones use this setup they just solder it down. Again for performance and reliability. While you can't upgrade the storage inside such a Mac external storage (USB-A up to Thunderbolt 4) gives lots of options.

Some folks, mostly old farts, don't like this and refuse to buy a Mac due to it. I got over it and like the reliability and smaller size of my Mac stuff. (Says he with a wire wrap tool and other old fart things in the drawers.)

As I said, I'm in the business and about the only thing that is sure is that when a hardware design has been out for a year there is a good chance of it being replaced soon. Except when it isn't. Some designs, especially MacMinis have lasted for 3 or more years.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Robby | June 30, 2024 17:21
1675:

Chaff has to be an integer multiple of a quarter of the radiation wavelength (i.e. 1/4, 1/2, 1, or a direct multiple) -- it has to act like a dipole or it's ineffective. (I suspect it's militarily obsolescent these days due to frequency-agile transmitters being a thing these past 40-50 years.) Chances of Kessler syndrome producing lots of satellites shredded to that precise length is practically zero.
