 David L replied to this comment from Tim H. | June 30, 2024 18:50
1682:

I think we're saying similar things but from a very different perspective.

The memory and controllers (system memory) (the 8GB, 16GB, etc....) are in the same package and the Mx chips. And can't be changed. Well not at a practical level except maybe for TLAs.

Storage memory (128GB, 256GB, etc...) is external to the CPU chip but all the the control circuits are in the Mx chip package.

So, yes, you in theory can swap out storage via some very skilled de-soldering and then soldering of what is designed to be done by a machine most likely in a flow control soldering manner.

I suspect the "is it worth it" vs just selling and buying new is a thin slice of the public.

Years ago (1971?) my father and I swapped out the engine in a 64 Ford Ranchero pickup truck. Straight 6 to a V8. The 6 was on its last legs and this seemed better than getting another utility truck to beat up on. Once done, in hindsight we would not have done it if we had known all the issues before we started. I have similar feelings about this type of upgrade.

 SFReader | June 30, 2024 19:38
1686:

Re: Basic life skills (cont'd)

Since no one's mentioned this yet: assembling IKEA furniture.

Key reasons for this:

a)Mass produced furniture is here to stay mostly because it's more affordable than hand-crafted.

b)IKEA is relatively low-cost and comes with easy-to-follow instructions. The furniture was specifically designed to be as simple as possible with the fewest functional components required.

c)People are relocating more often and farther so being able to take apart furniture or leave it behind/resell it is a plus.

d)Assembling IKEA is a good review of very basic geometry and mech physics - I think of it as an adult version of LEGO blocks. (Actually kids would probably enjoy helping assemble IKEA furniture.)

e)You don't need a tool inventory that costs thou$and$ most of which you'd never use again.

Pretty amazing what a few very basic shapes and a small number of construction elements can give you.

 Damian replied to this comment from alantyson | July 1, 2024 02:15
1694:

Incidentally, I couldn't have pulled that if without a compass (a digital one on my dashboard, but still), so I'll give myself that point, too.

The thing about using a compass for navigation is not so much knowing which way is north (which is important and it's hard to use a map over a distance without ether that or signed roads), more knowing how to use it to take bearings of landmarks and get a fix on your location. Two bearings give you a point, not necessarily very precise, but three give you the famous "cocked hat", which is a small triangle on the map you know you should be within, and also gives a sense of the level of precision you are dealing with. This stuff was taught in high school when I did that in the 80s. The maths isn't hard, but it takes a little practice. See also correcting for magnetic versus true north and deviation (using the standardised compass rose on your map/chart).

 Poul-Henning Kamp replied to this comment from David L | July 1, 2024 07:25
1703:

»3 sats is the minimum for a fix.«

For a fix in N dimensions, you need N+1 signals, because the measurements are time difference between all combinations of two signals.

3 sats will therefore only get you a 2D fix which is more or less OK, provided you know that you are on the surface of the planet, but the error and uncertainty will be quite large.

Tracking more than 8-ish signals from one of the current constellations does not materially improve error or uncertainty.

Tracking 4+ from multiple constellations only improves by sqrt(#constellations) because there are systematics.

If you have an incredibly stable (Cs-territory) and synchronized clock, you can find your position with just 1 satellite. Transit worked that way.

If you have an inertial facility, you can sanity check it with a single signal, as long as your route over ground is not the plane of that satellite's orbit.

Storage is similar but different. All of the control circuits are on the CPU die. Just the storage bits are not. And since no one but cell phones use this setup they just solder it down.  David L replied to this comment from JohnS | July 1, 2024 17:48
1718:

There is now and has always been a trade off in buying now and the cost of upgrading later.

I read an article in PC Magazine in 1989 by Bill Machrone where the tag line was "the computer you want always costs $5,000." Some started referring to this as Machrone's Law. Here's an article from 2 years ago referencing that original article and the issues.
https://www.pcmag.com/news/1982-vs-2022-has-technology-really-become-more-affordable

A computer back then was made of of dozens of discrete components assembled into a "box" that was a computer. Power supply, memory sticks, a disk controller, a disk drive, maybe the same for floppy drives, a graphics card, a serial card, a parallel card, a case, and a logic board. And maybe a network and/or modem card. Careful you don't buy end of tech life stuff or you'll get to spend $400 to $1000 to keep up within a year or two. And all of these had much higher failure rates individually then than entire systems today.

As a side note there was a non trivial amount of tech consternation with SIMMs, DIMMs, soDIMMs and such taking over from memory chips.

Over time most of these things have collapsed down to just a few components. The latest Apple moves to how their Mx silicon works are just a continuation on that path.

Now to pricing. A current full price Apple MacBook Air 15" fully decked out (24GB/2TB) retails for $2500. A 16" MacBook Pro decked out (128GB/8TB) is $8000. You can get it down to $5200 by dropping to 64GB/4TB.

These laptops will outrun that $5000 desktop from 1989 by a factor of 50 to 1000 depending. You can edit hours of 8K video on these things. No video editing of any practical nature back in 1989. Well maybe on beefy mini-computers. But that was the time of linear editing.

We are all stuck in our past to some degree. Personally a new in package dress shirt for use with a suit should cost $12. Which is did in 1970. Now it costs $50 to $150. I tend to buy off the returns rack.

 Boyd Nation replied to this comment from DeMarquis | July 1, 2024 18:48
1726:

As someone who currently works with Scouts, I'd acknowledge the failures of the past and say, as David L. as alluded to, that all large youth organizations are either recovering from their historical problems or are still in denial about them. With that in mind, the Scouts as currently constituted are well down the road toward recovery - the current Youth Protection Training program is the best I've seen (I also volunteer with a church and a county school district, so I've had to go through multiple different programs), and all of the troops that I've interacted with (both the one I work with and those I've encountered during district and camp activities) take the rules seriously.

The ongoing financial difficulties at this point have more to do with trends in youth activity levels - the move toward electronic entertainment (with a dose of stranger danger panic from the parents) and the growth of travel youth sports to soak up the more active kids has reduced the overall numbers of kids (or parents) that are interested. A smaller but significant contributing factor has been conflict with older, more traditional churches, who in times past would often serve as troop sponsors in the States, as Scouting's moves toward inclusiveness for LGBT kids and leaders has caused a lot of churches to move away from BSA.

 JohnS replied to this comment from David L | July 1, 2024 19:49
1740:

David L @ 1718:

There is now and has always been a trade off in buying now and the cost of upgrading later.

I read an article in PC Magazine in 1989 by Bill Machrone where the tag line was "the computer you want always costs $5,000." Some started referring to this as Machrone's Law. Here's an article from 2 years ago referencing that original article and the issues.
https://www.pcmag.com/news/1982-vs-2022-has-technology-really-become-more-affordable

I remember a similar article in PC Mag by John Dvorak a few years later, but the price of the desirable computer had come down to $2,500 by then.

But the main point is the computer WAS upgradable later. I wanted more performance than my current computer could provide ... maybe I even NEEDed more performance.

I couldn't afford a new computer ... but with some replacement parts (which I could afford) I could have a computer that came closer to meeting my needs ... and I knew if my needs changed in the future I would be able to upgrade again.

Or at least I used to be able to do that.

A computer back then was made of of dozens of discrete components assembled into a "box" that was a computer. Power supply, memory sticks, a disk controller, a disk drive, maybe the same for floppy drives, a graphics card, a serial card, a parallel card, a case, and a logic board. And maybe a network and/or modem card. Careful you don't buy end of tech life stuff or you'll get to spend $400 to $1000 to keep up within a year or two. And all of these had much higher failure rates individually then than entire systems today.

As a side note there was a non trivial amount of tech consternation with SIMMs, DIMMs, soDIMMs and such taking over from memory chips.

They were a boon to the home builder who wanted the most computer they could get for the money they had available ... and it was possible to buy parts as they became (financially) available and build the computer after you had accrued all the parts you needed. That's how I got my second computer1.

"Build Your Own Computer and Save a Bundle"

You COULD save a bundle. I built that $5,000 (or $2,500 - depending on whether you were reading Machrone or Dvorak) computer for less than $1,000 spread out over almost a year of buying it in pieces & parts (mostly from computer shows).

Over time most of these things have collapsed down to just a few components. The latest Apple moves to how their Mx silicon works are just a continuation on that path.

Now to pricing. A current full price Apple MacBook Air 15" fully decked out (24GB/2TB) retails for $2500. A 16" MacBook Pro decked out (128GB/8TB) is $8000. You can get it down to $5200 by dropping to 64GB/4TB.

These laptops will outrun that $5000 desktop from 1989 by a factor of 50 to 1000 depending. You can edit hours of 8K video on these things. No video editing of any practical nature back in 1989. Well maybe on beefy mini-computers. But that was the time of linear editing.

I don't do video editing. I'm still trying to achieve mastery of still photography.

But I agree with Robert Prior, the screen on a 15" Mackbook is just too small to use with old, tired eyes. I have a laptop (Windoze, not Mac) I use when traveling, and its screen is just too small for editing; almost too small for just viewing images. I only use it to read the cards from my camera and save them onto an external HDD.

We are all stuck in our past to some degree. Personally a new in package dress shirt for use with a suit should cost $12. Which is did in 1970. Now it costs $50 to $150. I tend to buy off the returns rack.

A good, high quality dress shirt will last. Take care of it and it won't be obsolete a year for now.

I still have a bunch of 'em I bought decades ago and they're still wearable; some would even be good enough for business (or at least acceptable if I had to put on a suit & tie to go to court).

Today's computers are vastly better, exponentially better, orders of magnitude better than those from 40 years ago.

But I still think maybe we've lost some useful things along the way.

1 ... and 3rd, 4th, etc ... although up until I bought THIS one, it was mostly the same "grandfathers axe" of computers.

 whitroth replied to this comment from Robert Prior | July 1, 2024 19:52
1741:

Not sure of the problem, but I can definitely recommend a source for compatible toner: tonerprice.com. Good prices, and compatible is.

In '12, the Center was going to change things, and we were not going to be able to buy consumables ourselves, they would do it. So, as I'd been assigned the one to take care of all the division's network printers, my manager had me take a survey, and guess what to buy for the next three years (by which time things would probably change again). I did, and got - this is not an exaggeration - two pallets of toner. Several had been damaged in shipping, and they sent replacements with no argument. Six months later, I needed toner for my cute little HP laserjet 1018 (yes, already obsolete). Was over $80 for OEM... and about $30 for compatible. And I got exactly the same quality of service that I had gotten ordering two pallets, and it all works.

So they're one of the very few online places I recommend.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from Howard NYC | July 1, 2024 19:57
1744:

if I could stack up 10,000 of my current (generic) Dell laptop into a time machine, the DOE/DOD/Wall Street circa 1980 would get into a bidding war likely resulting in me being served a writ of eminent domain or other such governmentally approved modes of theft... by the standards of that moment, that forty tons of 'future tech' would easily be worth a billion dollars...

You are massively underestimating the amount of change!

Assuming your Dell has something like an 8 core i7 clocked at 2.4GHz (distinctly trailing edge this year), then it's able to crank out roughly 16-20GFlops (until it melts).

The Cray X-MP supercomputer, released in 1982 as a successor to the Cray-1, ran at 105MHz and had up to four processors. Maxed out, it could do 800MFlops.

So every single one of those generic Dell laptops has roughly 20-40 times the performance of the still in development next generation fastest supercomputer of 1982.

Also a maxed-out X-MP had nearly 40Gb of fixed disk storage, which is laughably small by 2024 laptop standards (my Macbook Pro currently has 18Tb of stuff hanging off it, of which 2Tb is built-in).

A fully loaded X-MP would set you back roughly $16-17M (including disks). So each of those Dells has the raw performance and storage of about 500 of the world's fastest supercomputer, retail value $8Bn except nobody has any computing tasks that need such a behemoth.

 Charlie Stross replied to this comment from whitroth | July 1, 2024 20:07
1749:

My view, that I got from my parents, was that the Boy Scouts was a paramilitary organization.

Founded by Lord Baden-Powell in the wake of the second Boer War, to (a) provide boys from the cities with an experience of healthy outdoor living, and (b) to ensure a healthy supply of soldiers trained for scouting/recon duties (rather than shoulder-to-shoulder massed rifle volleys) before the next war (a lot of the basic Scouts training would be applicable to what today we'd consider "special forces" work -- infiltrating enemy territory and doing recon).

So yes, you're absolutely right. Although the relevance is much more limited these days: armies like to train their own specops people and there are a lot of skills the SAS or US Army Rangers need that would be slightly frowned upon if exhibited by teenagers in a civilian setting.

It was specifically targeted at poorer lads, initially!  Mr. Tim | July 1, 2024 21:08
1756:

About PC performance: The 25 Mhz 486 was introduced in 1989, so using that as the baseline.

For integer performance, from what I can tell, the current Intel processors are about 10x faster clock for clock as the 486, some versions will also run at 5 Ghz. That gives about a 20000x improvement in single CPU integer performance. If you have 10 cores on the chip and they can run at full speed and are fully & efficiently utilized (all three assumptions are suspect), that gives a total 200000x improvement.

Note that 32 bit vs. 64 bit usually has very little performance impact unless you are doing something that requires a huge amount of memory or are using 64 bit integers a great deal in your code.

Now, floating point performance is a whole different ball game, with amazing increases in IPC and SIMD instructions.

 Robert Prior replied to this comment from SFReader | July 1, 2024 22:41
1763:

I thought that continual access to the 'cloud' meant that folk no longer needed to spend on ever bigger, more powerful, stand-alone, personal computing devices.

Former techie here…

That was the dream/vision/pitch back when we called it "thin client services" in the 80s.

In practice, you have to keep replacing your personal devices because "the cloud" requires the bits on your device to be updated, and somehow older devices aren't supported very long.

I have an iPhone 6. The reason I'm going to replace it (likely this year if the iPhone SE4 comes out) is that it no longer works with most of the apps I want it to when travelling. I can't use the WestJet booking app. The browser no longer opens many websites. The Apple Wallet doesn't work. So few people have old phones that it's no longer 'worth it' for companies to support older models of hardware (and the associated software). How much of this is an economic decision based on costs and how much is an economic decision based on forced replacement I'll leave to others to discuss.

I will note that people like Cory Doctorow make a good argument that a lot of this is forced incompatibility to drive sales. (Read his non-fiction book The Internet Con for more details.)

 JohnS replied to this comment from SFReader | July 2, 2024 00:14
1770:

SFReader @ 1762:

Re: 'Today's computers are vastly better, exponentially better, orders of magnitude better than those from 40 years ago.'

Non-techie here ... no snark intended.

I thought that continual access to the 'cloud' meant that folk no longer needed to spend on ever bigger, more powerful, stand-alone, personal computing devices. Any heavy lifting they need to do could/would be done and stored in the 'cloud'.

AFAIK, "cloud computing" doesn't do anything for the processing power of your computer (or other device).

I prefer to NOT have my files stored out Dog only knows where, where I might not be able to get too them.

Last Tuesday I suddenly, without warning, lost internet for at least 12 hours (I went to bed while it was still out).

But, I was able to use my Photoshop computer & work on images I have stored on my local file server even though I couldn't get to anything out there in the cloud. And I was still able to play games I have locally even though Steam was off-line.

I also don't use wi-fi here at home. I know it is possible to "secure" a wi-fi network with passwords and all that, but it is much harder for anyone to intercept signals from my Ethernet network.

That may just be paranoia on my part, but in this day & age ...

https://theconversation.com/oldest-living-culture-our-new-research-shows-an-indigenous-ritual-passed-down-for-500-generations-230782

A sequence of 69 radiocarbon dates, including on wood filaments from the sticks, date one of the fireplaces to 11,000 years ago, and the deeper of the two to 12,000 years ago, at the very end of the last Ice Age. Matching the observed physical characteristics of the fireplaces with GunaiKurnai ethnographic records from the 19th century shows this type of fireplace has been in continuous use for at least 12,000 years. ...

Local 19th-century ethnography has good descriptions of such fireplaces, so we know they were made for ritual practices performed by mulla-mullung, powerful GunaiKurnai medicine men and women. Alfred Howitt, government geologist and pioneer ethnographer, wrote in 1887:...

GunaiKurnai Elder Uncle Russell Mullett was on site when the fireplaces were excavated. As the first one was revealed, he was astounded:
> For it to survive is just amazing. It’s telling us a story. It’s been waiting here all this time for us to learn from it. Reminding us that we are a living culture still connected to our ancient past. It’s a unique opportunity to be able to read the memoirs of our Ancestors and share that with our community.

 Retiring replied to this comment from Robert Prior | July 2, 2024 17:36
1814:

So 'the cloud' is actually a software repository as much as a data store?

Well, the Web is, anyway. It's not just Javascript, either. SGML, the inspiration for HTML, was never fast or simple to process, which I'm sure has nothing to do with the fact it was designed by a lawyer who became fascinated with IBM computers. Despite attempts to simplify and regularize HTML in the 90's, it became larded down with various presentational frobs like CSS and then Javascript. Bad CSS can also be compute intensive.

Much of the Javascript out there on various Web pages is also written by folks who have no idea of what they're doing, no understanding of algorithmic complexity, for instance. Really bad code, much of it bashed into approximate shape from some example they found somewhere else (that was also badly written). So it can waste resources like crazy.

 Mr. Tim | July 2, 2024 18:59
1817:

Re: The Cloud(s)

Clouds are more than data storage.

It is basically a bunch of technologies that allow easy scale-up/scale-down based on demand of storage, CPU processing, network bandwidth, etc. To do this things like java/python/javascript/etc (languages that are potentially low start up but not particularly efficient) are used and also allow incremental real time software updates (e.g. web pages, but includes things like data base enhancements/updates). Any web facing sites (Facebook, Amazon, etc) rely on this stuff so they can keep running 24/7 no matter what.

It is all very impressive, but unbelievably inefficient IMNSHO. Definitely not something the "old guard" from the mainframe era would have come up with.

 Mr. Tim replied to this comment from whitroth | July 3, 2024 01:00
1838:

The "Cloud" are data centers full of servers. Nothing at all like a data center with mainframe(s). No, no, no...

The hardware may appear similar, but the way it is used is very different from how a mainframe (or even a VM on a mainframe) is/was used 20 years ago. The "Cloud" aspect is the fact you can float resources where you need it, and the structure of the software & system management makes that incredibly easy.

Yes, you can use cloud services as an out-sourced data center, but that is really missing the full potential.

Did you know that about 20 years ago, someone maxed out an IBM mainframe (Z-90, I think, big one) using IBM's VM to run 48,000 individual instances of Linux? The mainframe was perfectly happy, though, with 32,000 instances....

Cool, but not relevant. It is how you leverage that capability. VMware (for instance) can dynamically migrate a running VM to a completely different physical host without missing a beat. AWS can migrate between data centers thousands of miles apart if necessary. Damn impressive. I doubt IBM Z90 could do that 20 years ago, because who could afford two of them?

The point is that "the cloud" gives you capabilities that the mainframes never considered, or only dreamed about. That is because the compute boxes (and the storage boxes, and networks) are relatively cheap by historical (especially mainframe) standards and it changes the economics completely.

Sort of what Starship is about to do to the space industry.

 Damian replied to this comment from Adrian Smith | July 3, 2024 12:47
1852:

If you leave the standard ideology aside, it's used a lot and is completely accepted and well understood, it's just explained in a way that makes it sound different and compatible with neoliberal assumptions. We (mostly) only do it in situations where the very wealthy are going to suffer. The 2008 financial crisis and the 2019 pandemic are the main standout international examples. Western economies have enough reserve capacity to eliminate poverty, more or less like flipping a switch, overnight or close enough to it. The main reason we don't is that modern Western societies are still fundamentally Calvinist theocracies, dominated by the protestant work ethic, and we take as fundamental that people are poor because they deserve to be.

It's similar to the conservative explanation for tax cuts. There really is a level of taxation where the tax burden suppresses demand and economic growth, it's just MUCH higher than we're usually led to believe and a lot depends on whether it's a progressive or regressive tax system, how it's structured and so on. As far as I understand this has never occurred in the modern era (or at least in modern economies). Tax cuts themselves stimulate demand in the short term, if they are shared and benefit poorer people who are more likely to spend, simply as a sort of Keynesian stimulus. But eventually the new tax level becomes structural and the economy grows around it.

Direct stimulus spending and increasing the money supply has similar facts and myths surrounding it. The usual example of why you don't do that is Germany in the 20s, though Zimbabwe is a reasonable recent example. There is usually some special reason why a particular national economy slips into that sort of inflation cycle, deficit spending and printing money doesn't do that by itself. If it does, it's because it's MASSIVELY out of proportion to the real economy, multiples of GDP, not fractions of it. Modern Western democracies spending their way out of a recession generally do not come close to triggering that sort of effect, by a couple of orders of magnitude. Greece is used as a sort of example, but it more or less proves the rule... its situation with the Euro as a constraining factor, well it's not hugely different to Germany's post-versailles reparations situation which was its main constraint in the 20s. The point is: there is probably a level at which deficit spending is bad for the economy, but that level it much higher than we're led to believe, much higher than it's usually even feasible to reach, and in the meantime it provides stimulus and promotes growth, while (if done as part of a progressive agenda) alleviates poverty, promotes education and structural improvements in the economy that are good for everyone. Which is why every country does it, the USA more than anyone, and (sometimes) even more under conservatives than progressives.

In contrast conservative economic views have been captured by an international movement that started in the late 40s (think Hayek) but really only got its legs in the 80s (think Friedman). It's important to understand that the theories these think tanks promote are 1) fully paid for and subsidised in a manner similar to the way the fossil fuel industries promote climate denial and the way the tobacco industry has fought anti-smoking public health and legislative initiatives; and 2) often at odds with actual policy implemented by conservative governments when they need to achieve real economic outcomes. The latter is mostly because the Libertarian, "small government", hard-right-free-market theories are well known to be gibberish, for the most part. Something like what you present as MMT is actually an overwhelming consensus, it's just that if you're conservative you're not allowed to say that. And like I said, it's usually only done when rich people are hurting.

 David L replied to this comment from whitroth | July 3, 2024 21:22
1859:

Being on "the Cloud" is no different, for the user, than timesharing on a mainframe.

And on this we disagree. While it could be thought of as the same, well it isn't. Been in the mainframe world at times in the past myself.

I have worked with architects for a few decades now. Over the last 10 years, and especially with the pandemic they have almost all either become cloud based, out of business, or a boutique firm doing specially, likely smaller things for expensive clients.

Architectural projects for business situations tend to go on for years. Lots of review and coordination meeting both in design and construction. Now days most of these meetings involve Zoom and/or Teams and/or Revut and/or other cloud based things. Sharing a screen, multiple markups by multiple people at different locations with tracking of who did what. And so on. Revu and it's competition are based around a group of people, many times at multiple locations, working in a vector based PDF or collection of PDFs and generating markups and document referencing the PDF details or markups.

Now what is done NOW could have been done in the mainframe world, except the people designing such software (that I saw and interacted with) were way too centralized in their thinking. Much of what is done now in a collaborative architecture/construction world is driven from the workstation design concepts of users and small offices. Literally someone with my experience can guess correctly if most such software came from a top down mainframe approach vs. a bottom up user approach. And yes there is a lot of fuzz in this way of describing things.

Autodesk is the elephant in the room here. AutoCAD is top down in much of it's design. Revit (which is where much of the business is moving) is much more bottom up. To the extend that Revit is still almost exclusively single core in CPU usage which a lot of the processing off loaded to graphics and if you wish to the "cloud". Again, very fuzzy boundaries but they are there. (Autodesk bought Revit around 20 years ago and it still has PC roots that get exposed at times.)

 Moz replied to this comment from Damian | July 3, 2024 22:43
1865:

MMT is actually an overwhelming consensus, it's just that if you're conservative you're not allowed to say that.

It's important to note that most MMT proponents favour helping poor people, not the rich. And especially not printing money to allow for low taxes on the rich whether that be libertarian flat taxes or facilitating tax evasion (by defunding the IRS or actually writing in "loopholes").

I see it as an ongoing discussion of what sort of society we want. On the one extreme you have people lamenting the outlawing of slavery but consoling themselves with a large class of immiserated people so desperate they'll do anything, anything at all, for a dollar (but not steal from the rich, obvious that can't be allowed. They're there to be stolen from!). The other extreme is something we only see in places like Cuba, where there's a minimum standard and the goal is exoplicitly to bring everyone up to that.

The brutal summary is: Gini Coefficient, high or low? (for binary thinkers, 1 or 0!)

 Damian replied to this comment from Adrian Smith | July 4, 2024 00:39
1870:

or does everyone have to do it in unison

This is usually referred to as "capital flight". We see the same argument being used about mining royalties in Queensland right now and the mining industry is even running TV ads making the same case, since the incumbent Labor government has increased them and there is a state election due this year.

The answer is: mostly not. The argument relies on a premise that there is a more or less even worldwide market for the investment you are looking to make. Making one possible option less attractive, either by increasing the royalties therefore marginally decreasing profitability of a mining operation, therefore infinitesimally decreasing ROI, the argument goes, will lead people to invest elsewhere instead. But that assumes the existence of similarly profitable investment opportunities elsewhere, whereas the actual case is that all those investment opportunities are unique and have their own pros and cons for potential investors. For many, risk is a much more important factor than squeezing out the last drops of ROI, and even when you cost out the risk and package it all up with an actuarial cost associated to it, taking a small hit as a result of royalties is pretty meaningless. It might add up to a few million, so it's worth the money to spend a million on an ad campaign to get it out there, but it's not an existential issue for an industry that worth A$86 billion a year.

There's a similar set of issues in regard bond and currency markets. In general, it's not about whether the growth-generated ROI or the overall risk is completely optimised as best as possible, it's about how it compares to other comparable investments. As per above, the actual risk impact of the sort of changes required to eliminate poverty has (more or less, going by 2008 and 2019) been shown to be positive rather than negative. The footprint of any investors who think "that's socialism, the country is about to collapse" is going to be small, the rest will be fully aware of the situation and not "flee" as such. There are plenty of living worked examples, Northern Europe being somewhat rich in case studies.

 Moz replied to this comment from Damian | July 4, 2024 00:47
1871:

And also that the cost of moving is zero. Or "negligable" in the jargon, such that you make a net profit after less than a year.

Which given that the mining industry also demands extra-long depreciation schedules is just weird. If the cost of building a mine is so huge that it takes decades to pay off, how can it also be trivial to throw it away and build a new one in another country?

Oh, you mean profit shifting is easy, so you're threatening to do that. Financial trickery is simple, we get it. You can lie about where the profit is made and choose to pay tax on it in a zero-tax or ridiculously low-tax country. So to "be competitive" we have to charge a tax-haven level of corporate tax. Riiiight.

How about: fuck you. Mining companies pay no tax on profit, but we charge what the market will bear in royalities when we sell you the minerals you're mining. Our goal is that every year 10% of mines have suspended operations because they can't make a profit after paying royalties. If iron ore prices are low, no mining until they recover. I believe that's how "free markets" are supposed to work, that's the essence of "self correcting", no?

(I'm not being sarcastic at Damien here, but at the "poor struggling mining companies")

 JohnS replied to this comment from skulgun | July 4, 2024 17:55
1886:

skulgun @ 1873:

Fiscal conservatives love to trot out the pictures of Weimar Germans taking wheelbarrows full of deutschmarks to the store as a scare tactic against printing money and hyperinflation, while leaving out:

-Germany had just lost the first world war -Had the crushing repayments of the Versailles treaty
-Been through a revolution/short civil war immediately after the war
-Had large parts of the west annexed by France,
which was the most proximate cause of the hyperinflation crisis

And that the wheelbarrows full of marks period didn't even last all that long.

I read a learned article somewhere that German hyperinflation was at least in part by intent.

Much of the reparations in the Treaty of Versailles were specified in commodities - so many millions of Deutschmarks worth of coal, timber, grains ... and if it takes a million Deutschmarks just to buy a loaf of bread, what does that do to to reparations payments?

Seems like the period of hyperinflation lasted just long enough for the Germans to weasel out of the requirement to pay reparations.

There are many economists who write about taxes and externalities etc, but for obvious reasons they're not popular with capitalists and especially the late-stage capitalists that run many countries ATM. "Counting for Nothing: what men value and what women are worth" is a classic in the feminist economics genre, for example. There's similar work done on the economics of (not) changing the climate, but why would a fossil billionaire fund that when there's lapdogs begging to publish on how coal is good for humanity?

It's aother one of those things where the theory is at least aspriationally sound, but the practice is confused by the ease with which bad economics can be used to justify horror. Similar to the high visiblity of climate-denying climate scientists and pro-smoking doctors. Or, topically, anti-social social media proponents.
